name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 18 January 2018.

name: Le Président. –
text: Last week, we were sad to hear of the passing of our colleague Édouard Ferrand. Elected to the European Parliament in 2014, he was head of the National Front delegation within the ENF and served on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and the Joint Parliamentary Committee with Turkey. Mr. Ferrand left us because of an illness he wanted to keep to the end in absolute discretion and to which he showed great dignity. He leaves a wife and five young children. I had the opportunity to exchange with him last year during the visit to the earthquake-affected areas in Italy, where he represented his group. Although I did not share his ideas or his vision of Europe, I remember his conviction defending his political position. On behalf of Parliament, I wish to express the deepest condolences to his family, his wife, his children and to all those close to him during his life and who today mourn for his disappearance. I invite you to join me in observing a minute of silence. (The Assembly, standing, observes a minute of silence) ****

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I ask this House: can we be the target of madness and hatred only because of the colour of your skin? Shooting from a running car and indiscriminately hitting as many blacks as possible. This is the result of those who incite racial superiority, of those who instill fear in citizens, of those who use and proposes their political offer by fomenting hatred. My support from this House for all victims of hate, regardless of the colour of their skin.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Mr Kyenge. What happened in Macerata, Italy, is something unacceptable and inadmissible that all of us condemn firmly and without any hesitation.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Mr President! In this regard, I would like to ask you the following point: In view of what the President has just put forward, can we expect the Bureau of the European Parliament to review the statements of Members in the Member States? I would also like to ask, when will the Bureau of the European Parliament address Mr Verhofstadt's disgraceful statements insulting the Polish people that have fallen here in this parliament? Because this is a pretty situation. You want to assess the statements made by Members outside the European Parliament. On the basis of which article of the Rules of Parliament? (ECR Group Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Rule 21 of the Rules of Procedure requires the request to take place by three parliamentary groups representing the high quota. This is not a penalty under the regulation, a penalty which may or may not be imposed by the President. It is neither the President nor the Bureau that decides, but the Conference of Presidents. So it's a request that comes from the groups, it's not a penalty imposed under the regulation, but Article 21 applies. I was nothing more than to enforce the regulation. There was a vote within the Conference of Presidents and therefore the whole procedure was respected. So this is not sanctions, because the president cannot impose sanctions for what happens outside Parliament. I can impose sanctions for what happens within Parliament. The request to remove from the office of vice president depends, under Rule 21, on a request that comes from different political groups.

name: Manfred Weber (PPE).
text: Mr President! The honourable Member refers to free speech and no Member is calling into question free speech. But we are not talking about a normal Member of Parliament here. We are talking about a Vice-President of the European Parliament. In the same way, Mr President, as we as a candidate for the European People's Party, expect you to carry out office in a party-neutral manner — and you are doing great, President Tajani — we also expect other Vice-Presidents to behave in the way that this institution, the European Parliament. If we have a Vice-President who unacceptably denigrates a democratically elected colleague here with Nazi comparisons, if we have a colleague who compares the institutions of the European Union to the Soviet Union in an unacceptable way, then a red line has crossed. Then you have to take consequences. That is why we, as a group, will promote the election of Czarnecki. (Applause) In order to take ammunition from colleagues in the PiS right away, my group is prepared in the same breath to accept another PiS candidate as Vice-President. This is not a vote against Poland, it is not a vote against a political group or a party. We are voting for every other colleague that the ECR will propose. But in the specific case of Czarnecki, we believe that consequences are necessary. (Applause from the PPE and the ALDE)

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Bullmann asked for the floor, but it is not that we need to have a debate on Mr Czarnecki, because the decision has already been taken. There will be a vote and the sovereign chamber, by secret ballot, as required, will decide what to do. I replied only in legal terms to the honourable man because he referred to the Bureau. The bureau had nothing to do with it, and it has nothing to do with the sanctions inflicting the president. It is a decision that is taken under Article 21 and the whole procedure has been adhered to. Mr Czarnecki was also guaranteed the chance to say his. The minutes of the meeting you had with me was signed and there was no apology from Mr Czarnecki. So, everything was done in sunlight.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: Mr President! I don't want to summon a debate either. I just want to answer the honourable Member's question: no, there has been no voice in the Conference of Presidents that there should be censorship of views, and that will not exist. But there is a dignity of the European Parliament, there is a dignity of this House. And please do not forget that European unification has grown in the rejection of the war and in the rejection of National Socialism. This is a commitment and heritage. And whoever draws Nazi comparisons in this way crosses a red line. We — the Socialist Group — do not want this House to be represented by someone who works with Nazi comparisons. This does not belong in this house any more than Nazis belong in this house. We insist on that. Incidentally, we agree with the words of Mr Weber. Of course, we are at the disposal of a representative, a representative who does not exceed this limit, from the appropriate group. We are in this house for the plurality. But no Nazi comparisons, no Nazis at the head of this house! That hasn't lost anything here. (Applause)

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE).
text: — Mr President, I just wanted to support your position. I think you conducted this quite correctly. As you know, in this House, I am very committed to having conflicting debates and oppositions of ideas, and that is quite normal. But when personal attacks are used to degrade the person, as was done by Mr. Czarnecki, we go beyond all boundaries. I fight the ideas of the PiS, I fight the ideas, for example, of the far right, but you will never take away the respect of every human person from me. All the elected representatives here have the same legitimacy and are respectful human persons, and Mr Czarnecki has not been at that height. That is why it is unacceptable.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too think there must be some stakes. It is for this reason that I addressed a letter to your office, signed by more than one hundred Members, asking that political forces such as Casa Pound have no access in the classrooms of the European Parliament which self-define the fascists of the third millennium. I would like this House to respond and try to keep these stakes firm too, because, after the facts of Macerata, they must be rejected and must be firmly rejected in every place where fascism is nestled.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Forenza, there are rules that must be adhered to within this house. The President does not authorise events, if anything he can ban initiatives that are in Parliament. But when they don't get prejudiced or people who are listed on terrorist lists, I can't stop a parliamentarian... (The President addresses Mr Krasnodębski) Mr, it is pointless for you to raise your voice with me. Sit down and respect the House! Sit down and respect! Silence! Great, I see that democracy doesn't even know what it is! Did he finish making his meeting, without asking for the word? It's useless! Calm down because we don't have to fight here, we just have to express political positions. So call her to order and education. Clear? I was responding: when a person is invited by a parliamentarian, to whatever political force they belong, and there are no violations of the law, we cannot ban a demonstration. So much so that nothing was said, and then the political exposure had nothing to do with Macerata's affair. I may not share the positions, but otherwise we no longer authorize or better we prohibit demonstrations or meetings within Parliament organised by Members of Parliament. But all MPs, as Mr Lamberts said before, are the same because they represent the people. Then one can condemn their ideas, but when there are no statements that violate the rules we can't prevent these meetings. Now let's proceed because we have already said a lot.

name: Presidente. –
text: The final draft agenda, fixed at the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, at its meeting on Thursday 1 February 2018, has been distributed. Following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposal for amendments to the final draft agenda: Monday and Tuesday: No changes are proposed. Wednesday: Mr Ignazio Corrao's report on automated vehicle registration data exchange in Portugal will be added to Wednesday's votes. Are there any objections? (Parliament welcomes the request) I have received a request from the ENF Group to postpone the vote on the report on the composition of the European Parliament until Thursday 8 February or as of 1 March 2018.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, thank you first of all for your remarks at the opening of this meeting to pay tribute to our late colleague, Édouard Ferrand. We are very sensitive to the tribute you have paid to him and, of course, we will share it with his relatives and, in particular, to his wife and children. Thank you also for observing a minute of silence in his memory. We would like a slight change to the agenda of this plenary session so that the vote on the Hübner and Silva Pereira report, which deals with the composition of the European Parliament after the European elections and after Brexit, which was originally scheduled for Wednesday, can take place, if possible, either this Thursday or at the mini-session in Brussels, on march 1, because it appears that the views on this report are quite divided in our chamber and the absence of a very large number of members from the same group — which will be the case because many of us will go to the funeral of our colleague Édouard Ferrand in the Paris region — could have an impact on the outcome of the vote. Therefore, we submit this request to your kindness. Then, Mr President, if I may, I would like to say, with regard to Mr Czarnecki, that, of course, we do not share the remarks he made at all, but they were part of a heated controversy with one of his colleagues who accused Poland of being a dictatorship. There is a principle of law, if I may, very important, is that we cannot be a judge and party. However, when the Conference of Presidents, composed almost exclusively of political opponents of Mr. Czarnecki, takes a decision against him, the principles of law were violated and democracy could not be invoked while violating the basic principles of law.

name: Le Président. –
text: Democracy respects the decisions of the majority. We have made a decision by a large majority. A vote will be held by secret ballot. Everyone will therefore be able to pronounce themselves as they wish.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Parliament’s position was extremely clear regarding the fact that we deplore the death of our colleague, Mr Ferrand. This was very clear this morning. Nevertheless, are now addressing another issue, namely two very important reports on which we have done a lot of work, and on which Parliament needs to come forward with a very clear position and a very clear vote. This is scheduled for Wednesday. The S&D Group does not agree to postpone this vote. The vote should take place on Wednesday. To delay it would be a big mistake because Parliament needs to come forward with a clear position on this before the leaders’ meeting addressing the same issue. Again, we deplore what happened to our colleague, but we don’t believe this is a reason to postpone a vote on such an important report.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Jonás Fernández, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the annual report of the European Central Bank (2017/2124 (INI)) (A8-0383/2017) Pleased to welcome the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi. Before I give him the floor, I would like Members who do not intend to stay in the House to decide to do so quickly.

name: Jonás Fernández
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, it is a pleasure to start this debate, to receive the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, the Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Dombrovskis, and all the colleagues who are going to participate in this discussion on the implementation of monetary policy by the ECB. It is true that the ECB is an independent institution which, within its mandate, is implementing the target of achieving inflation close to 2%, but it is true that, in recent times, we are having severe problems in placing target inflation on that long-term benchmark. Still a few days ago we knew last month's data that reflected an additional reduction in inflation, up to 1.3%, and it is true that the forecasts place that 2% well into 2019. In turn, according to growth data, it is true that the euro area is recovering capacity, but we have an excess of potential ahead, an excess of sufficient growth capacity: the Monetary Fund, the European Commission itself collect in their output gap estimates a very wide space to continue to grow without tension inflationary. Therefore, this House, in that report, respecting — as I say — the clear independence of the ECB, I think it places where the debate should be in order to guide that work over the next year too. As I was saying, it is true that the euro area is growing better, but monetary policy is not enough: we need a proper fiscal policy, which will allow the diversification of the positions of each of the governments in the economic cycle in order to provide the euro area as a whole with a consistent fiscal policy. It is true that we also need reforms that activate, improve productivity throughout the Union: reforms that are socially responsible, socially policies with a future. But the report also points to the need to consolidate the internal market. We need to improve the consolidation of the Capital Markets Union — which is being promoted by the Commission with the support of this Parliament — and we also need to consolidate the Banking Union. It is an agenda for reforms, some already legislative proposals, which are on the table of the European Parliament, which need the support and debate of all our colleagues. We therefore call for an accommodative monetary policy in the good sense, in the right direction, reforms that are still pending. Moreover, the report contains, of course, some side effects of that monetary policy, and it therefore calls on the ECB to also monitor them on a timely basis. I am referring to the problems of redistribution of income and wealth; I am referring to the problems of financial stability to maintain a flat rate curve for a long time; I am also referring to the control and monitoring of potential bubbles that may be being identified in some segments financial markets and real estate markets. And we therefore call on the ECB to monitor these side effects of its own monetary policy. But the report clearly points to new transparency instruments, the need for the CSPP to have clear eligibility criteria to avoid problems of discrimination between large and small businesses. We need to improve the implementation of the Commonwealth, to give it credibility and robustness throughout the euro area, and we need to improve the monetary dialogue, the control that this House exercises over the work of the European Central Bank — which is an institution, as the report recognizes, which is also bound by the Paris Agreement, which has signed the as a whole of the European Union. I believe that this is a comprehensive and important report, and I hope that further input will come out of this debate.

name: Mario Draghi
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I am very pleased to be here to discuss with you the ECB’s activities and your draft resolution on the ECB’s Annual Report for 2016. Today’s debate represents a good opportunity to take stock of progress made and discuss the way forward. A decade ago, the global financial crisis was starting. Today, while further efforts are needed to overcome its legacy, the euro area economy is expanding and employment is rising. Your draft resolution points out that monetary policy has played a key role in this recovery process. The ECB has indeed acted decisively, in line with its mandate. We have addressed financial fragmentation and supported the economy, enabling inflation gradually to converge towards our objective. The draft resolution also notes that the independence of the ECB has allowed us to take resolute action within our mandate. But independence is just one of the cornerstones of our institutional framework. Accountability is its necessary counterpart. And you, as the representatives of the people of the European Union, are the heart of our accountability. Together, independence and accountability underpin our effectiveness and our legitimacy. In my remarks today, I will focus on two particular issues that have been raised in the draft resolution. First, I will elaborate on economic developments in the euro area and the role of the ECB’s monetary policy. Second, I will discuss the state of the financial sector and the measures needed to further strengthen its resilience. The euro area economy is expanding robustly, with growth rates stronger than previously expected and significantly above potential. According to preliminary data, euro area real GDP increased by 2.5% in 2017, compared to the 1.7% that had been foreseen in our December 2016 staff projections for the same year. The economic expansion is broad-based. The dispersion of growth rates across countries and across sectors is at its lowest level in 20 years. Accordingly, we see positive growth in over 85% of the sectors in the euro area economy, compared with a historical average of 75%. Employment growth has recently strengthened, as well, in all the main sectors, namely industry, construction and market services. These developments bode well for economic growth, as expansions tend to be stronger and more resilient when growth is broad-based. The number of people employed in the euro area has also increased by around 7.5 million, since hitting a low in mid-2013. Employment has now reached its highest level since the introduction of the euro. The unemployment rate continues to decline and now stands at close to a nine-year low of 8.7%, down by 3.3 percentage points from its highest level. As more people find jobs, household incomes rise. This has helped to strengthen private consumption growth, which in turn is boosting business investment. In addition, a number of other factors have supported investment. These include higher demand for euro area exports, rising corporate profitability and an increasing use of installed productive capacity. These positive developments have been fostered and reinforced by the pass-through of the ECB’s monetary policy measures, which have eased funding conditions for households and firms. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in particular have benefited from our policy measures. The growing inclusiveness of this economic expansion is partly due to the renewed vigour of small businesses, which are a key engine of income creation in our economy. While our confidence that inflation will converge towards our aim of below, but close to, 2% has strengthened, we cannot yet declare victory on this front. After increasing to 2% in early 2017 due to a rise in energy prices, headline inflation has fluctuated since May last year between 1.3% and 1.5%. Measures of underlying inflation, which exclude the most volatile components, remained subdued and have yet to show convincing signs of a sustained upward trend. Also, new headwinds have arisen from the recent volatility in the exchange rate, whose implications for the medium-term outlook for price stability require close monitoring. On the back of improved economic conditions, the financial stability situation in the euro area has also continued to evolve positively. As I will explain in more detail, for the time being we have little indication that generalised imbalances are emerging. Overall, while we can be more confident about the path of inflation, patience and persistence with regard to monetary policy are still warranted for underlying inflation pressures to build up and inflation to converge durably towards our objective. That is why – at our last meeting – we reaffirmed the decisions taken at our October monetary policy meeting last year. Accordingly, our net asset purchase programme, running at a monthly pace of EUR 30 billion, will continue until September 2018, or beyond, if necessary, and in any case until the Governing Council sees a sustained adjustment in the path of inflation consistent with its inflation aim.  In parallel, we will reinvest the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the asset purchase programme for an extended period of time after the end of those purchases, and in any case for as long as necessary. We expect our key interest rates to remain at their present levels for an extended period of time, and well past the horizon of our net asset purchases. Looking forward, we remain fully committed to our price stability objective and – in line with our monetary policy strategy – we aim to stabilise inflation around levels that are below, but close to, 2% within a meaningful medium-term horizon.  As always, our monetary policy will continue to be guided by our assessment of the progress made towards our objective. Our forward guidance continues to provide a stable framework for our monetary policy stance and its outlook. In line with that guidance, monetary policy will evolve in a fully data-dependent and time-consistent manner. Let me also say a few words about the financial sector. Your draft resolution also considers several aspects related to the euro financial sector and I would like to follow up on some of them. Let me first of all emphasise that our monetary policy and a healthier financial sector are mutually reinforcing. By supporting the economic recovery, our monetary policy measures have had a positive impact on the credit quality of banks’ loans to businesses and households, and have helped banks further to reduce their provisioning costs. Moreover, a stronger economy generates greater volumes of sustainable bank lending. Both factors have therefore strengthened the solidity of the European banking sector. A better integrated and sounder financial sector has also been able to transmit our policy impulses more evenly across the euro area. The improved health of the banking sector, coupled with our credit easing measures, has brought about a marked improvement in the transmission process, as shown by the reduced heterogeneity of bank lending rates across countries, and by the improved borrowing conditions for SMEs. A more robust financial sector has also allowed us to pursue an accommodative policy for as long as necessary, without any build-up of significant financial stability risks. The draft resolution points in particular to the risks stemming from possible asset bubbles. We are closely monitoring developments in some market segments, such as prime commercial real estate and housing markets in some countries, and corporate bond markets for lower-rated issuers. As we explain in our Financial Stability Review, asset price increases in euro area markets have so far not been accompanied by excessive credit growth. Although credit flows have been recovering, growth rates are still far below anything we saw before the crisis, and on the low side of the range of growth rates historically seen during recoveries. So there is no evidence of systemic credit-fuelled bubbles. The efforts we have made in recent years to strengthen prudential regulation and supervision, above all with the establishment of the banking union, have certainly played a role in protecting financial stability. In particular, ECB banking supervision plays a key role in ensuring the safety and soundness of banks. It enhances the banks’ resilience through strengthened prudential regulation. It also fosters cross-border financial integration and provides a level playing field by harmonising supervision across the euro area. Also, on the macro-prudential side, we see national authorities in close cooperation with the ECB being very active in further mitigating the emergence of possible systemic risks, especially in respect of residential real-estate developments. Despite the improved cyclical environment, improved market sentiment and the substantial strengthening of its shock absorption capacity, the European banking sector continues to face structural challenges, as you also state in your resolution. Indeed, overcapacity and cost inefficiencies continue to weigh on bank profitability in certain banking markets. Moreover, the high stock of non-performing loans (NPLs) needs to be further reduced and any future build-up needs to be avoided. Non-performing loan levels have been declining for more than three years and good progress has been made on the EU Council Action Plan, although there is still a considerable way to go. Additional efforts by banks, supervisors, regulators and legislators are needed to create an environment in which non-performing loans can be effectively managed and efficiently disposed of. Strengthening the resilience of the euro area financial sector also means adapting to a changing operating environment. The resolution mentions, for instance, the growing role of fintech companies. This means more competition for banks, including in the field of lending and payment services. At the same time, new technology presents an opportunity for banks to increase the value added and the cost-efficiency of their services. Another factor shaping the euro area financial sector is the United Kingdom’s decision to leave the European Union. At this stage, we do not have clarity regarding the shape of the UK’s future relationship with the EU. Well-managed preparations are thus essential for dealing with frictions in the transition from the current situation to the new eventual equilibrium, especially in the event that no transitional agreement is reached between the EU and the United Kingdom. Banks and financial institutions are not the only ones that have to prepare for an operating environment in a state of flux. Policymakers too, at national and European level, have to make sure that the regulatory framework is fit and ready to safeguard the resilience of the financial sector in the face of new challenges. Let me mention two examples. First, finalising the banking reform package is crucial. The package will strengthen the regulatory architecture, reduce risks in the banking sector and increase financial stability. It will introduce into Union law new internationally agreed standards, such as the leverage ratio requirement, which will restrict the build-up of excessive leverage in the banking system, and the standard on total loss-absorbing capacity, otherwise known as TLAC, which will strengthen the resolution framework. As co-legislators, you play a vital role in this process, and I would encourage you to aim for consistent implementation of the internationally agreed standards, so as to ensure a level playing field worldwide and to reduce options and national discretion as much as possible. Second, it is important to complete the architecture of the banking union by putting in place the agreed common backstop to the Single Resolution Fund and by establishing a European deposit insurance scheme (EDIS). These are two fundamental pieces of the banking union project and their implementation should not be postponed. The backstop should ensure that sufficient funding is available at all times to guarantee orderly resolutions. A fully-fledged EDIS is an indispensable counterpart to the single currency as everyone in the euro area should be able to have confidence that the money in their bank account enjoys the same level of protection, regardless of where the account is held within the euro area. Let me conclude. We pay close attention to Parliament’s resolution on our annual report, and we will respond in detail to the issues you raise there when we publish our ECB Annual Report for 2017. The strong relationship between Parliament and the ECB not only demonstrates the importance of accountability, but also bears possible lessons for reflection on the future of Economic and Monetary Union, the strengthening of which should remain a priority. A well-designed and effective policy framework requires clear institutional architecture, measurable objectives and the tools to achieve them – and it needs to be accompanied by strong accountability. This is not only essential to ensure that policies are effective. It is also crucial if the public is to understand those policies and play an active role, in particular via their representatives in Parliament. Thank you for your attention. I am now at your disposal for questions. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr President. I also want to thank you for your personal cooperation with the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and with Parliament.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Jonás Fernández, and the members of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) for their report on the ECB’s annual report. It is a pleasure to be here today to discuss this with you and President Draghi. An ex-post debate on the ECB’s activities by the European Parliament is an expression of democratic accountability. So let me start by saying that the Commission largely shares the general thrust of the report prepared by the ECON committee. The Commission shares the report’s views that the ECB’s independence in the conduct of its monetary policy, as enshrined in the Treaty, is crucial to the objective of safeguarding price stability. Accountability and independence are intertwined, and in this report the Commission shares the views that the ECB’s responsibilities and tasks require transparency towards the public at large. The Commission also shares the views of the ECON report that the ECB’s unconventional monetary policy actions, such as forward guidance and quantitative easing, improved the transmission of monetary policy. They also had a positive impact on the overall financing conditions in the euro area and certainly contributed to the start of the ongoing economic upswing. The implementation of the above-mentioned ECB policy measures is expected to keep on gradually improving the financial conditions and contribute to bringing inflation closer to the ECB’s objective of close to but below 2%. We also share the ECON report’s views that a prolonged period of low or even negative interest rates could represent a challenge to the profitability of various actors in the European financial sector. That said, the low interest rates were necessary to support the recovery and had some positive impact in the short term on financing costs and capital gains for banks. These introductory remarks sum up our main points on the report. I am looking forward to a fruitful debate today and I trust that you will confirm the constructive engagement that has developed between the Parliament and the ECB over the years. Finally, I also would like to thank President Draghi for highlighting the importance of the work of completing Economic and Monetary Union and the Banking Union, and we fully share this priority.

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I welcome this debate as part of the European Central Bank’s accountability towards the European Parliament. As you have said, President Draghi, the euro area recovery continues at a steady pace; unemployment has continued to decline and has reached the lowest level since January 2009; domestic demand has strengthened, and we have seen 18 quarters of consecutive growth. However, the positive economic outlook still has to translate into higher public and private investments and we still have to progress on reaching our inflation objective. We are still concerned about the risks of the persisting low interest rates for the insurance and pension sectors as well as for private savings. This is an important element of the European Parliament’s report with regard to the ECB’s activity for 2016. This is why the ongoing tapering is necessary for the economy to get back on track and to be self-sustaining. Unconventional monetary policy tools have reached their limits. Monetary policy cannot and shall not be the tool to resolve all of the EU’s economic and financial shortcomings. I agree with President Draghi when he says that Member States have to increase their efforts in implementing growth-enhancing structural reforms, while at the same time maintaining sound and responsible budgets to support the economic recovery. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Jonás Fernández, for his work on this report, and we are sending – with the debate today and with its adoption tomorrow, hopefully with a large majority – a clear signal to the ECB on the Parliament’s position on your activity in the year 2016.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, Mr President of the Central Bank, Mr Vice-President, dear rapporteur, this is an important moment for monetary policy, but also for economic policy that this meeting around the annual report of the Central Bank is an important moment. As you said, Mr President, this time, basically, the economic environment for the European economy is improving, yet monetary policy has yet to help sustain economic activity. From this point of view, our report invites you to contribute to a reflection that we feel is emerging among experts on the reality of inflation, while a new air is blowing. Indeed, your mandate defined around 2% corresponds to a mode of production, a state of globalization which we can see that it may be questioned. It seems to me that the Central Bank has a score to play in this area. Beyond what monetary policy can do independently, it seems to us that the messages you send should be supported when it comes to encouraging the Member States to review their wage policy, to review their structures in the banking sector, and also this issue which has finally been mentioned so much in Davos, which is that of the fight against inequality. Among the new challenges, we see more and more states and banks concerned with the issue of cybersecurity and virtual currencies. Here, too, we expect prospects from the institution you preside over. Finally, as an institution, as you know, we will attach great importance to the conditions for appointing your future vice-president. We are waiting for a shortlist, a balanced list that allows you to meet all the criteria set out in the Treaty to serve as vice-president of your institution.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr Draghi, nice to see you here. You know, I'm not a big fan of your lax monetary policy. On the contrary, I'm quite critical. I am therefore delighted that the report we are discussing today is also critical on several points. Here we are now, three years later, EUR 2 000 billion later, because of your monetary experiment, Mr Draghi, your quantitative easing, an experiment we have never seen on that scale in the European Union before. And finally, for the first time, there are votes to stop that experiment. Its legitimacy is being questioned and the experiment is therefore being put to an end in September. This is very necessary and very important, because if we have too low interest rates for too long, debts are piling up. Public debts and private debts are swinging out, and that cannot continue. These debts are breaking records and the consequences we have seen before in 2008, with the beginning of the financial economic crisis. Those who look closely today will see that there are also fewer rosy figures and elements that we can quote. Your free money policy has ensured that the richest have lived for seven fat years and that the less rich, the middle class, have had to bite the poorer people on their teeth. They have to conclude that their savings are no longer yielding. I ask you, Mr Draghi, stop it, not in September but today.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, we all know that the ECB plays a crucial role, and sometimes more crucial than we actually understand at a given moment. Everybody still remembers the phrase ‘whatever it takes’. If that phrase hadn’t been pronounced I think we would have been much worse off than we are today.  So we do have a lot of respect for the independent nature of the bank, but at the same time we of course need some democratic scrutiny, and I therefore appreciate that Mr Draghi is here with us today.  In the report we have here in front of us, I think we have been able to strike a fairly good balance, with a balanced tone. Mr Draghi and the ECB have done a fairly good job and they have been playing a very important role in addressing the crisis.  But it is also important to point out that actions taken by the ECB sometimes fall short of what Member States need. At the same time this is probably also a good point to say that the Member States don’t always do what they should to increase the resilience of the system. I think we are heading towards more normal interest rates. That would be a great improvement. I therefore think that the next report by the European Central Bank will be much more interesting than the one we have been reading now, because you are going to be placed in a situation where you have to make some very tricky decisions on how to stop helicopter money. I wish you the best.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (EL) Mr President, Mr Draghi, we will not criticise you for the quantitative easing programme, but because you are not doing enough to prepare the euro area and the European Union for the next crisis and the next recession. We criticise you because we need to move faster and more strongly from dogmatic unilateralism to austerity to policies of sustainable development; because accountability and strengthening must be ensured not only in words but also in practice. We call for the European Central Bank to accept the European Ombudsman's recommendations on strengthening both transparency and democratic accountability. Retire from the Group of 30. We all know that the economy of the European Union and the euro area is currently doing a little better, but this cannot hide the deficits and construction problems of the euro area: incomplete economic union, incomplete banking union, lack of transparency and democratic accountability, unilateral in austerity. The European deposit guarantee scheme and harmonisation policies must be launched immediately, which will close the black holes through which the extensive tax evasion of the large multinationals and the VAT fraud and theft systems, through which the European Union is losing so much as well as the Member States huge sums at the expense of honest taxpayers. That's what we expect from you.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it is ten years now since the irresponsible activities of bankers and the structural problems of the global banking system led to the bailing out of the financial sector at great public cost. While the activities of central banks have patched up the system, many of the fundamental design flaws have not been addressed. There is still an urgent need for deep structural reform of the euro area banking system, as institutions remain too big or too interconnected to fail.  My group remains concerned that this point is not being adequately addressed in the report. In our view, the ECB remains a provider of implicit public subsidies to these institutions that represent a fundamental threat to the stability and efficient allocation of capital in the EU and internationally.  As Greens, we are also determined to ensure that the ECB’s activities are consistent with our Paris climate commitments and that the asset purchase programme does not undermine our rapid transition away from fossil fuels.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would suggest to Signor Draghi that he and all of Europe should be concerned with the way Messrs Barnier and Verhofstadt are treating the City of London in these so-called Brexit ‘negotiations’, which are nothing of the sort. Whether Barnier or Verhofstadt like it or not, the City of London is the banker of Europe, if not the world, and it will remain so after Brexit. By not organising a proper deal, Verhofstadt and Barnier are threatening the stability of the eurozone. As euro fanatics, Barnier and Verhofstadt would rather damage the economic future of the people of Europe than in any way upset the European project, which is their sole objective and fanaticism. Barnier’s job is not to negotiate a deal but to nobble, destroy, damage Britain’s ability to embarrass the European Union by running an effective market—driven economy rather than the European command economy envisioned by the European project which has failed so miserably in eastern Europe over the last 50 years.  Mr Draghi, more than anyone, as an Italian banker, should know the precarious situation many Italian banks are in, and that creating problems in the City of London and making it harder for Italian banks and people round Europe to obtain credit may well damage Italian banks and push them over the edge into bankruptcy, followed by the eurozone. This will hardly help small businesses all over Europe.  Why should Britain care? Well, quite frankly, we don’t want an economic basket case on our frontier. We want to trade with you. We want to do business with you. We want to be friends with you, but we want to retain our own bank accounts and our own economy as we are quite entitled to do. I would ask you, Mr Draghi, are you not concerned about what’s going on with Barnier and Verhofstadt?  Thank you for your indulgence, Mr President.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, Mr President Draghi, the current globalist doxa would suggest that the economy is better, and in particular that the recovery of growth in the countries of the European Union would be due to the ECB's accommodative policy, but this idealised vision does not take into account the very high level of economic growth. systemic risks. For the National Front, there are six zones of danger to the world economy, over which the ECB has an influence. First, the volume of private debt in OECD countries is Himalayan. The rise in long-term interest rates will have a catastrophic effect, with chain bankruptcies. Secondly, the risk of financial market collapse, even greater than in 2000 and 2008, will materialize when central banks cease their injections of overliquidity. Thirdly, the out-of-control expansion of shadow banking: the political and financial elite is trying to trick public opinion on the pretext that the banking system would now be safer thanks to the Basel rules, but paradoxically shadow banking, this shadow finance, is at high risk. Managers of assets, hedge funds and insurance companies, in particular, have never been so extreme in their implications. Fourth, CCPs: these clearing chambers of global financial markets are real time bombs. More than ever, they concentrate all market risks and interoperability, i.e. the interconnection of CCPs, multiplies the risk of a domino effect until the collapse of the entire global financial system. Will the ECB stop such contagion by the bankruptcy of a CCP? Fifth danger, the parallel world of block chain, and finally cybersecurity, with terrorist cyber attacks of the system. Far from your fantasy resilience, Mr Draghi, the ultraliberal and globalist economic model leads us to the worst crash of all time. I hope the ECB is aware of this and is preparing for it.

name: Presidente. –
text: As for the “blue card” questions, I grant them after the representatives have spoken on behalf of the groups, because then everyone has the opportunity to replicate. Mr Coburn has spoken now. Mr Henkel will be able to ask for the floor later. Now the floor is with Mr Balz.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: Mr President, President Draghi. I am pleased that we have met here today for this extremely important debate. In recent years, the ECB has had to take some landmark decisions that have contributed significantly to the stability of the euro and to the recovery in the real economy. It seems that we are now now, thanks to the courageous intervention of your Central Bank and its policies over many crises. Europe and the Eurozone are growing as rapidly. And yet the challenges do not fade. Technological developments in the financial markets are currently taking place at a breathtaking pace. In recent weeks, the significant price fluctuations of cryptocurrencies and the accompanying large losses of many investors have reminded us once again that virtual currencies have long ceased to be play money for a few technology enthusiasts. Many financial institutions — including major European banks — are now asking us to act to curb the relatively new virtual currency market with its drastic price fluctuations. First of all, however, it is important to identify the need for regulation without too much limiting the scope for innovation and development in the digital marketplace. Mr Draghi, virtual currencies will also be one of the major challenges of the ECB of the future. How do you assess the regulatory needs in this area and what means and instruments do you intend to use as a central bank to address this issue? (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure for the 'blue card'. — Mr Balz, we heard Mr Draghi earlier, who spoke of the need for responsibility. The Commission has just said that it is in favour of the banking union being completed now. I ask you: what do you actually think of having joint liability now — that's exactly what the Commission wants — and then the German saver is liable for the gambling of French, Italian and Greek banks?

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the procedure of “blue card”. Well, now today I chose a different topic, which is the one of the technological challenges. For good reason, because, of course, I did not want to bring a German election campaign here to Parliament, which we hope we have concluded. But you know my opinion: over the years I have been — I believe — one of those here in Parliament who never, really never, wanted these very issues, and this applies to Mr Balz to this day.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur Fernández and all the political groups for their contribution to this balanced text, in which a positive judgment is clearly expressed on the ECB's monetary policy action and the importance of unconventional measures to ensure price stability, avoid deflation and improve access to credit for companies and families and, ultimately, for the revival of economic growth and employment. As you said, President Draghi, if the results however are undoubtedly positive, we cannot yet declare victory, and the decision to continue the securities purchase program until September, and besides if necessary, it is therefore fully shareable. Of course, monetary policy alone is not enough to ensure the shift from a cyclical recovery to a structural one. For this, on the one hand, we need a proper policy mix, with socially balanced structural reforms aimed at increasing growth potential and a budgetary policy which, at aggregate level, is needed. move hand in hand with monetary policy and not against it, and, on the other hand, we need to complete economic and monetary union and strengthen its governance and instruments. The reform package presented by the Commission represents, from this point of view, an important first step. Parliament is doing its part to make it more ambitious and also to help ensure the independence of the ECB, even in the delicate steps that await us in the renewal of some top positions of its Council.

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: - Mr President! When the ECB announced its European bond buying programme three years ago, we raised our reservations about the effectiveness of these actions. In retrospect, it turns out that we were right and that cheap funding goes mainly to the public sector, which most spending goes to consumption. So it's hard to talk about the spectacular inflationary effect, and I guess it would be ridiculous to talk about the development effect. These conclusions in Mr Fernández's report are sadly lacking. It also disappoints the fact that you are positively assessing the federal nature of the ECB and supporting the continued issuance of European safe assets, or Eurobonds. The Polish delegation cannot fully support this report and will abstain. Mr President of the ECB, you boasted of high GDP growth in the euro area. I want to remind you what you know: that there are countries in the European Union with more than twice the economic development. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question under the 'blue card' procedure. —I deduced that you are dissatisfied with the policy of the European Bank, given that there was no significant drop in inflation, but it is stated in paragraph 18 in the report. Do you believe that monetary policy is sufficient for economic recovery and growth, or do we also need fiscal policies, social policies, so that we can achieve a decline in unemployment, economic growth and, obviously, a drop in inflation?

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — Certainly monetary policy itself, fiscal policy itself or social policy itself will not solve the problem of economic development. A total of actions, a full package of functioning on the market, is necessary to stimulate its development. In the case of the ECB, I believe that it does not quite meet its scope of business.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I have two very specific questions for President Draghi. First of all, since 2014, the ECB’s annual reports have referred to monetary financing issues in Hungary. The ECB has repeatedly asked for assurances that central bank resources are not being used for financing the state as this is banned under Article 123 of the treaties. In 2016, in response to a question from my colleague Mr Bullmann, the ECB stated that it was monitoring the situation. In 2017, I put the same question and got the same reply, namely that you were monitoring the situation. Now it is 2018, do you consider that the situation in Hungary has been remedied or is there evidence of a violation of Article 123? My second question is as follows. In several Member States the pension systems show considerable weaknesses and shortcomings, and that is contrary to the aim of sustainable public finance. Do you consider that governments are doing enough to reform their pension systems?

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, Mr Draghi. The ECB's Annual Report 2016 identifies four key risks to financial stability in the euro area. These are the increase in global risk premia, the low profitability of banks, the sustainability of sovereign and corporate debt and the liquidity risks in the area of investment funds. Unfortunately, not much has changed in this initial situation for 2018. For example, the 10-year yield of Italian government bonds has risen by 0.7 percentage points to 2% since 2016. The ECB now holds significantly more Italian and French debt instruments than the national central banks' capital key provides. This usually indicates that the yields of these bonds are under high upward pressure. In addition, there are structural problems in the Member States of the euro area. Economic growth and unemployment are uneven, and the inflation rate remains below the targets. Against this background, the ECON Committee adopted an own-initiative report in November last year, which calls for greater transparency and greater accountability to Parliament, that is to say a better monetary policy dialogue. A transparent, improved monetary policy dialogue, for example involving national parliaments such as those we have in the European Semester, would be desirable. I look forward to hearing your specific proposals.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the report by my colleagues and thank them for that report, and welcome President Draghi to the European Parliament. When one looks back at the last 10 years, significant progress has been made in getting the eurozone economy to a much better place. We look at the job numbers, we look at GDP growth, especially in the last three years, and we look at the emerging investment which is taking place. Getting inflation close to 2% is not just important in terms of reflating the eurozone economy, but it is also important in helping to reduce debt piles, which are very significant in countries that went through a bailout programme such as my own, so I recognise that progress. I also recognise the very significant impact that you have made, President Draghi, in terms of the bond-buying exercise that you directed with the Governing Council, and that sends out a strong message of trying to reflate the economy at a time when we needed funding. We recognise that it will come to an end at some point, it will be tapered, but I think there are issues still, and I have raised them before, surrounding how much each Member State is asked to give in terms of the national outstanding amount. My issue is to ask you once again to continue a dialogue with policymakers and Member States, and especially go to Member State parliaments. I hope you will have an opportunity to visit the Irish Oireachtas and possibly the Finance Committee between now and the end of your mandate in October 2019. I think that sends out the right signal to Member States, to national parliaments, to have an engagement with the President of the ECB so that those Member State policymakers are aware of the objectives for our currency. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Brian, for accepting this question. We are coming up to a Parliament vote on possible candidates for the Executive Board and I’m asking myself whether it is a good development that former finance ministers, who have basically participated for years in the Eurogroup, are now sent right away to sit on the ECB’s Board? Does this correspond to the value of independence of central banks for which your party family has also fought, and for which there is a great tradition, also in Germany? Do you think it’s a positive development that we have this sort of candidates?

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I want to thank my colleague for a very good question. I believe that the issue of the appointment of ECB Board members must obviously concern the question of technical competence and technical performance, but also the question of accountability. It is obviously open for all Member States to put forward various candidates, that are then to be considered by the Eurogroup and ultimately by the Council, and indeed by this Parliament in our deliberations. I am not going to preclude anyone, but I am simply saying that it is important that that question of objectivity, independence and technical competence are the key characteristics for us all to consider before a decision is made.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Mr President! This report on the European Central Bank is the best report I have read in this House so far. He makes many important, correct, critical remarks about the monetary policy of the European Central Bank in its impact on savers, pension insurance, banking stability and similar matters. He also makes a very important comment right at the beginning: monetary state financing is prohibited. And then, unfortunately, he gets involved in a great contradiction, because in the end he calls for Greek government bonds to be bought up by the European Central Bank. That would be precisely the monetary state financing that we do not want to have, especially given the risk that the issuer limit will suddenly be fully exhausted here and that the ECB will buy up Greek government bonds in large quantities. That must not be the case, and this is a major weakness of the report. Mr. Draghi! However, the ECB has another challenge, and I would like to put one question to you in this connection: the government bond buyout programme is grossly distorted in favour of certain countries, particularly southern European countries. Professor Heinemann once again pointed this out in the F.A.Z., who also refuted your so-called refutations. Can you please comment on the reason why the ECB is buying up such government bonds far too much?

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Mr President, Mr Draghi. A decade of financial crisis, and Europe was originally neither the starting point nor the centre of this crisis. One can also say that the crisis is no longer quite as acute in Europe. But we have managed to become a chronically ill man, because outside the euro area, the key figures have developed much better than in the euro area. Inflation figures, monetary growth, target balances, financial and banking market ratios, GDP, investment figures, unemployment figures — these are all metrics that will not be expected anything good in the future, at least not the big turn that we have all been expecting for years. And there is perhaps quite a good signal for you, Mr Draghi, but a bad one for all citizens of Europe from Germany, where it has been announced that the ESM crisis fund will now be institutionalised in Europe and will actually be handed over to you as a European institution. This may benefit your loose monetary policy, but it is a very bad signal for all German savers.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: Mr President! We are dealing with 2016: the ECB's report. Time has progressed and many things have changed: Britain's motion, the American presidential election with all its consequences. As a result, the framework conditions have changed not only from the financial crisis of ten years ago, but also within the global framework. Currency fluctuations have increased, and the President of the ECB says: we have done everything right so far, we are just going to continue it. That is why the question arises: firstly, when you say that we need reforms in the Member States, and I can agree with you 100%, you have always said that. But before we adopt deposit guarantees and resolution funds as part of the banking package, we really need these reforms. The second issue, in my opinion, is that if we create a European Monetary Fund — I am in favour — then it must be clear how it is controlled and how it is financed and who bears the last responsibility for it. In this respect, many questions in the reform package are open. And it will be important now, President Draghi, that you take a moderate turnaround in interest rate policy.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what are the consequences of the policy outlined and also praised in the report? That sovereign debt securities, first bought by private banks, today lie deposited in the assets of national central banks. Who earns it? Only one: Germany. The seller and lender, who, moreover, had chosen, mistakenly, his debtor — Greece and Spain — and sees himself saved by us poor taxpayers of the poor states of Southern Europe. To save it, we got into debt to the ECB right. Today we are in a situation where it is easy to predict that financial rates will rise to the detriment of those in debt, that is, our, in general, with a clear risk, namely destabilisation of financial markets. Another issue is the MUV, which is solely responsible for European supervision, taken from central banks, which has not protected depositors. Despite the stress tests, there has been a scare series of bank crack, a situation that today is the focus and attention of Italian voters, with very serious responsibilities in government. What has been, I wonder and hope that you respond, the monitoring and monitoring activity of the SSM? Can you give us concrete data? Can you give us guarantees for the future? And then, and I conclude President Draghi, do you finally want to have the courage to say what you know very well, namely that derivatives are a cancer cell of the financial system?

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Mr President! The 2016 report is the second report I've read — after 2015 — and I have to say that I am satisfied from the report itself. Both of these information relating to the redemption process of eurobonds, the conclusion of the stability package, as well as other elements. What bothers me today, by contrast, is the lack of information policy precise enough to keep such serious spans on future policies involving eurobonds in this room. On the one hand there is information, opinions that it is good that the Bank is backtracking in this policy, and on the other side of the room there are allegations that this policy pursued or continued will be a source of serious trouble and perturbation in European finance. I point out the necessity of better information policy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree to support the need at European level for healthy and growth-friendly national budgetary policies, while respecting the Stability Pact, and reforms socially balanced but also ambitious. The forecast of an inflation rate in the eurozone below 2% until 2020 confirms that monetary policy, alone, is not enough to sustain economic recovery. It must be accompanied by concrete policies at national and Community level. Improvement of credit access conditions for SMEs is essential. The persistence of differentiated credit conditions in the Member States will not encourage healthy and harmonised economic development. I also believe that concerns are well founded about the uncertain consequences of the quantitative easing instrument, as a result of the resumption of consumption. I thank President Draghi for the courage of the choices taken in these difficult years. However, I think that the ECB's tasks require greater transparency towards the general public and a greater reporting obligation to Parliament.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, Mr Draghi, the responsibilities of the European Central Bank, as a member of the troika, to turn Greece into a vast social cemetery are enormous. This has been agreed even by Mr Dijsselbloem, who stated that the memoranda rescued foreign banks rather than Greece. However, the ECB continues its “business as usual” in relation to red loans, demanding the activation of electronic auctions in order for the “crows” to seize the homes of the Greeks. Moreover, the ECB illegally continues to refuse the inclusion of Greek corporate bonds as well as Greek government bonds in quantitative relaxation, all at a time when the Bank of Greece spent 42.5 billion euros for its participation in the quantitative relaxation. Finally, Mr Draghi, once again we point out that the ECB must finally leave the troika in order to put an end to the conflict of interest that exists, given that the ECB 'wears four hats': it is a member of the troika, it is a lender to the Member States, it controls systemic banks and supposedly be an independent monetary authority.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, my group has tabled two amendments to this report and I invite you to vote in favour of them. With the first amendment, we call for a condemnation of the speculative behaviour of the European Central Bank in the case of Greek bonds exempted from the 2012 haircut process, which yielded a profit of almost EUR 6.2 billion to the Eurosystem, Mr. Draghi to a relevant question. This process caused additional budgetary pressures and suffering for the Greek people. We want to call on the Eurosystem to unconditionally return these profits to Greece and, otherwise, the Greek government does not pay these bonds, so that the austerity measures agreed by the Greek government for the next 36 years can be cancelled, among the which is the reduction of duty-free and the cut of pensions. With the second amendment, we would like to express our disapproval of the fact that the efforts to reduce red loans promoted by the European Central Bank and the Member States in many cases have the effect of infringing the fundamental right to housing, resulting in thousands of low-income households losing or living in fear of losing their homes due to bank debts.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, the first article in the report we are debating today is the most important one. Parliament is showing great urgency to ensure that in no way the independence of the European Central Bank is called into question. At the same time, however, this agency not only affects but to a large extent determines the lives of European citizens. When were the citizens asked? When did they consent to cede such great power to an independent organization? When was that power taken from the States and what democratic legitimacy does this agency have? The supposedly scrutiny of the European Parliament makes no sense because it takes place after the feast and, moreover, it is superficial and meaningless. Why has the President of the European Central Bank not been deposed after his characteristic failure to manage the crisis? Which private company would the CEO have remained in his position if he had not been able to deal with a crisis for ten years? We call for the return of these powers to the national central banks and their control by the Member States as a first step towards regaining national sovereignty and independence.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Draghi, the European Union has been through one of the key moments in its history. We have seen a situation of lack of credit, particularly for SMEs, which hindered economic recovery, and low inflation which prevented the Member States of the Union from alleviating their debt levels. The European Central Bank has played a very important role in economic recovery, but it has become clear that monetary policy alone is not enough to achieve a sustainable and more balanced and inclusive economic recovery. You said that, structural reforms are needed. And Spain is a good example of that. It has now done and is growing by over 3 per cent and has created over the last three years more than half a million jobs annually. We can take a positive account of the European Central Bank's performance, with a recent improvement in expectations for both 2018 and 2019. We are now entering a scenario of gradual withdrawal of stimuli in time and quantity, ensuring that economic recovery is never put at risk. In conclusion, I would like to congratulate the author of the report. And I would like to call, in line with the opinion of the European Central Bank, for the continuation of negotiations for the establishment of the European Deposit Guarantee System as the third pillar of a genuine banking union, which will contribute to strengthening and safeguarding the European Union's financial stability.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — Mr President, I have read this 13-page report carefully and I must say that I am disappointed to see that only one and a half row, in Article 24, we are talking about SMEs. I believe that all of us here know that there is still no lending to SMEs in the Member States, although the share in our economy, in the internal market, is SMEs. I want to address Mr Draghi, if he can tell us at the final word whether he proposes something to the ECB about the practical, not theoretical possibility of lending to SMEs. The report certainly envisages the productivity deficit in the euro area and, above all, somehow I am concerned that this deficit is expected to go up to 2020. Can the ECB do something to keep this from coming true, that is, not to go with a deficit until 2020? Of course, I would be concerned to know and to say to those who chose me whether the impact study on monetary policies can be passed on transparently, to be able to know and inform citizens, because here we are talking about countries in the euro area and countries that are not yet in the euro area. I look forward to the answer.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: Mr President! President Draghi, you presented us today with an ad hoc theory. One ad hoc theory is: I am doing a certain policy and looking for the rationale for it. In reality, since your famous word 'whatever it takes', you have been pursuing an interest-rate levelling policy to prevent the non-performing debtor states from bankruptcy. That is the goal of your policy. And the consequence of this policy is that reforms are being called for time and again. Yes, if interest rates are close to zero, or even negative in many areas, if you recalculate the inflation rate, there will be no reforms. Instead, you produce bubbles. In the period 2002-2005, real interest rates were also negative in critical countries, and the consequence were real estate bubbles, other bubbles. And that's exactly what we produce. I tell you: you are now trying to fight problems and are creating bigger problems in the future.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: — Thank you, Mr. Draghi for a report that is encouraging. He talks about economic growth, lower unemployment, more employment in the European Union. My questions are three: first, what will the European Central Bank do to keep state finances, especially bank finances, healthy in the future, so that there will be no repayment of bad credit by country taxpayers? Second, what can the European Central Bank do to make the difference between poor and rich countries smaller, so that we will not have this problem again and again in a few years we will have to vouch for the finances of individual countries? And the third question, what does the European Central Bank intend to do in the field of cryptocurrencies? There is increasing this capital value, balloons are big and if we want to have these cryptocurrencies regulated, the European Central Bank also needs to take decisive steps towards regulating this area.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: — Mr. President, I certainly welcome the activities of the European Central Bank, which has enabled its measures to facilitate periods of favourable financing and to reduce the difference in interest rates between Member States, which is very much felt in practice. This has significantly contributed to the creation of conditions of stability, predictability, security and trust, and these are the main prerequisites for the development of investments and new business ventures. I have one question for President Draghi, which is how to make favorable financing conditions as accessible as possible to all entrepreneurs and riskier projects because for stronger growth and reduction of inequality in development between Member States we need innovation, we need new knowledge and skills which underlie new technological solutions, which are the basis for productivity growth, all for better growth and more stable wage growth. However, funding is missing precisely for those riskier projects that lead us into development.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank honourable Members and President Draghi for the fruitful discussion. Let me conclude by mentioning a point which directly concerns the Commission. The report encourages the Commission to study schemes such as a Central Bank digital currency and Digital Base Money with a view to improving public access to payment systems. We agree that further study of the potential challenges associated with these schemes to access payment systems is needed. To this end, we will liaise closely with the ECB, as the report invites us to do. We count on your continued support in building the foundations for sustainable growth and job creation in Europe.

name: Mario Draghi
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Mr President, let me first thank Mr Fernández and his colleagues for the report. It is very encouraging for our work that you stress how our measures have contributed to the recovery and to financial stability. You noted in the report that the institutional framework enshrined in the Treaties allowed us to take decisive action in line with our price stability mandate, and this has been the objective of our monetary policy throughout. It still is the objective of our monetary policy. In the course of exchanges we are often told that our monetary policy affects one category or another, but our objective is price stability, defined as an inflation rate which is close to, but below, 2% for the whole of the euro area, not necessarily for one specific country. That is how our monetary policy should be judged: whether in the medium term we reach this objective. I would like to thank Commission Vice—President Dombrovskis, and all of you, for this very relevant and useful debate. The debate shows that, while we are now seeing the positive results of our policies, we should not be complacent, but should rather strive for continued improvement. I apologise in advance that, given the short time I have, I cannot comment on each and every statement, but let me touch on some of the issues that you raised. One issue raised by several honourable Members concerns the effects that our monetary policy has on the distribution of income and wealth. So let me say a few words about the effects of quantitative easing (QE). It is quite clear that QE raises asset prices. The holders of assets are generally wealthy institutions or wealthy people, so in the short run you have a worsening of distribution. At the same time, to the extent that QE is successful, it increases employment – as I have said, and I am going to say it again – and it is by far the most powerful measure for decreasing inequality in any economic system. From this viewpoint, even though in the short run one has some negative consequences, in the medium and long term the positive consequences outweigh, very consistently and significantly, any short-term negative concerns. This has been shown, by the way, in several studies. The best way to decrease inequality is to increase employment, and that is what we have done, contributing to increasing employment by 7.5 million jobs over three-and-a-half years. When we look at wage growth – and that is very important for us because it is, in a sense, what tells us whether inflation is moving towards our objective in the medium term – annual growth in terms of compensation per employee increased has gradually from 1.1% in the second quarter of 2016 to 1.7% now. It is still below its historical average, which is 2.1%, so we have to be more patient, but looking at what happens in other jurisdictions – for example the United States which is, by the way, far advanced in the business cycle – we see that wage growth picks up in the end. The recent data in the USA show exactly this. We have to be aware that we have weak productivity growth, ongoing impacts of labour market reforms implemented in some countries during the crisis and certainly a much bigger labour supply coming from stronger migration flows and higher participation rates. Participation rates of women and older people especially have increased considerably. Also, the low-inflation environment that has prevailed for a long time is now influencing current negotiations. And, by the way, one thing that is quite important in explaining this light response by wages is that even though we had a significant increase in employment, when we go and look at the quality of this increase in employment we see a lot of part-time and temporary arrangements. I am listing all these factors, because they are explanations of why the nominal wage-growth response is going to be lower than we had expected. But we know by looking at other jurisdictions which had, by and large, the same problems that, in the end, nominal wages are going to go up, and they are going up, albeit at a subdued rate. As regards the effects of our monetary policy, some speakers questioned the effectiveness of this policy. We have estimated that our measures have made a substantial impact on the economic performance of the euro area. Considering all the measures taken between 2014 (and even before, in 2013) and October 2017, the overall impact on EU area real GDP growth is 1.9%: 1.9 percentage points over three years. One Member pointed out that investment is still low. We are coming from very, very low levels of private investment but, if anything, over the past three or four quarters, private investment has picked up and it is actually increasing at a much more satisfactory rate than in the past. Since the end of May 2014, lending rates for households and non-financial firms have declined significantly. There is one thing I said in the introductory statement which is very important: during the crisis we observed widely differing lending rates by banks in different parts of the euro area, but this difference has now shrunk and rates are very close nowadays, as are growth rates, by the way.
