One measure we often look at to determine the strength of the growth process and expansion is how different the growth rates are in different parts of the euro area. Well, the degree of difference now is something like we had in 1995—1996. In other words, it is a historical low. All countries nowadays are growing. By the way, some Members questioned the effectiveness of our monetary policy for SMEs but, in fact, the lending conditions for SMEs have improved significantly across all sectors and countries. The gradual recovery in loan growth is continuing. The recovery started about four years ago and then really picked up, and it is continuing, though we are not seeing anything like we had before the crisis. So growth rates in lending are good, but nothing euphoric like we saw before the crisis. One point that was made was that we are focused on buying southern countries’ bonds. That is not true. We do not favour certain countries over others in the implementation of our programme. Our purchases are guided by the ECB’s capital key, which takes into account GDP and population. But if one focuses on purchases at specific points in time, for example on 2017 only, this is bound to yield wrong interpretations. The overall stock of euro system holdings is the relevant metric for any assessment of the programme, and not the recent purchase flows. So, in fact, if you look at the stock, you will see that, as far as German bonds are concerned, we are above the capital key for that country. By and large, one should consider the design of the programme: it is flexible and the distribution of actual purchases on any given day often deviates from the ECB capital key. But just consider: this was in the original design of the programme when we had countries like Greece, whose bonds we did not purchase. Of course, then, we had to deviate from the capital key. Some other observations concerned the side effects of our monetary policy. I just wish to reiterate that our measures are proving effective but, at the same time, we are aware of potential side effects and we have to differentiate between the various ways in which they affect economic actors. For example, for individual savers, an accommodative monetary policy means that they accrue fewer nominal returns on their savings. However, such a policy also supports economic expansion and this bolsters employment, income, returns on investment and tax revenues. It therefore benefits households in their capacity as workers, entrepreneurs, investors, borrowers and taxpayers. There is no one specific country that has benefited most from our monetary policy. Everybody has benefited. Public sectors in all countries saved billions on interest rate payments; private sectors across countries and sectors saved billions on interest rate payments to banks; and purchasers of houses could have access to mortgages with much lower interest rates than at any time in the past. This has not only boosted the construction industry but has also boosted investment for the purchase of houses. So we see benefits accruing right across society and not specifically located in one country. When the monetary policy is successful, both creditors and borrowers benefit from it. Similarly, let me continue now on savers. There are several channels through which our policies affect pension and insurance schemes. Beyond the effect on the liability side, it is important to see what happens on the asset side. Our monetary policy has had a beneficial impact on this side of the equation, as the value of the investment portfolio has increased. But, having said that, I completely agree there is a need to put pension systems on a stable path because the survival of any single country’s pension system cannot be dependent only on the proper configuration of interest rates. It must be actuarially sensible. I have already addressed, in my introductory remarks, the issue of possible asset bubbles currently being formed in the euro area. For the time being, we have little indication that generalised financial imbalances are emerging. There are no signs of general asset-price misalignments in the euro area but some segments do need close monitoring and one of them is the prime commercial real-estate market, where we actually see stretched valuations. Also, in some large cities and in some countries real-estate prices have increased at a faster pace than household incomes. This certainly requires monitoring.  Finally, yields in the euro area corporate bond markets, especially for some of the lower-rated issues, have started to look exceptionally low by historical standards, but what are we going to do? Are we going to change monetary policy because of these side effects which are not, by the way, systemic? No, the answer is to enact macro-prudential policies which are the best tool for tackling these challenges – also given their country-specific and sector-specific remits. In late 2016, the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) issued a set of country-specific warnings on medium-term vulnerability in the EU residential real-estate sector.  Now a word about Brexit. We are not party to these negotiations but we are certainly monitoring their evolution and, clearly, I agree that much depends on these negotiations and possible arrangements. Of course we always prepare for any eventuality and, at the same time, we are assessing the direction, the probability and the potential impact of risk, but the bottom line is that either this transition is well managed and there will not be substantial risks, or it is not, and the risks will be there. We are certainly looking at that and we have to be prepared for that. Let me also add that, as far as our role as supervisors is concerned, our good cooperation with the Bank of England is important in coping with the potential risks, and especially the risks of any cliff-edge effects. Certainly, transitional arrangements along the lines of the December European Council guidelines could be useful to smooth out the Brexit process but, as we all know, the materialisation of the transition period is still exposed to political uncertainty, and that will remain for some time to come. On financial supervision, I welcome the review of the European system of financial supervision, including changes to the European supervisory authorities. Some of your comments touched upon the issue of transparency. Here, let me reiterate that we are in complete agreement about the importance of ECB transparency vis-à-vis the European public. We have continuously assessed where we need to further strengthen our transparency framework, and we have demonstrated our commitment, improving our framework as necessary. Just briefly, let me list a few of the actions we have taken. The accounts of Governing Council discussions are now published four weeks after each monetary policymaking meeting. There was none of that a few years ago. Since 2015, the Executive Board members, as well as the Chair of the Supervisory Board, publish their diaries covering professional meetings with external parties. None of that was in place until a few years ago. And in 2016 we decided to disclose the agreement on net financial assets (ANFA). Last year we also published the text of the emergency liquidity assistance agreement. We have announced transparency in relation to our purchase programme, especially transparency on the corporate sector purchase programme. Some of you made reference to the European Ombudsman’s recommendations on the interaction of members of the ECB decision-making bodies, including myself, with the Group of 30 (G30). We have certainly taken note of the Ombudsman’s letter and we will respond in time, but let us remember that the European Ombudsman has already concluded that the ECB must conduct dialogue with market participants and that there is no evidence that the G30 meeting could have directly influenced, or have had an adverse impact on, the ECB’s supervisory tasks. The Ombudsman has also confirmed that the ECB has a robust system of safeguards in place to manage its contacts with the financial sector. Again on transparency, we publish on our website extensive documentation on all these interactions with markets. We disclose agendas and summaries of the discussions, so I can assure you that the ECB is, and remains, committed to reviewing, adjusting and updating our transparency framework. One or two speakers touched on Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. Let me first say that we are not observing a systemically relevant holding of digital currencies by supervised institutions – by banks, in other words. Actually, the credit institutions established in the European Union are showing a limited appetite for digital currencies like Bitcoin, notwithstanding the high level of public interest. However, recent developments, such as the listing of Bitcoin futures contracts by US exchanges, could lead European banks too to hold positions in Bitcoin, and therefore we will certainly look at that. However, we should understand that Bitcoin and other digital currencies are in the unregulated space and should be regarded as very risky assets. Virtual currencies are subject to high volatility and their prices are entirely speculative. Banks should measure the risk of any holdings of digital currencies in their portfolio accordingly. Right now, digital currencies are not subject to a specific supervisory approach. Work is under way in the Single Supervisory Mechanism to identify potential prudential risks that these digital assets could pose to supervised institutions. There were some other specific points. We are going to consider the possibility of having a Charlemagne commemorative coin. On monetary financing in Hungary, we will assess the existence of monetary financing in our report. As you know, the ECB is accountable to the European Parliament, but members of its Executive Board, myself included, have accepted invitations to discuss our monetary policy generally and broadly in national parliaments, so I would be glad to accept an invitation from the Irish Parliament if I were to receive it. I think I have gone through most of your questions. Thank you.

name: Jonás Fernández
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, I would particularly like to thank President Draghi and Vice-President Dombrovskis for having accompanied us in this debate and, of course, all the colleagues who participated, especially the shadow rapporteurs — Mureşan, Loones, Torvalds, Papadimoulis and Scott Cato — with whom we have been discussing this report. But I wanted to take this last minute to address the Eurogroup. Europe is demanding more democracy every day. European citizens, in each of the elections, demand more transparency, more accountability, more public debate, a greater ability to know and discuss European policies. In the coming weeks, in the coming months, we have the discussion ahead to fill several vacancies in the ECB. And that is why I dare to address, representing the majority of this House, to the Eurogroup to demand that it send us a list of candidates that Parliament can discuss; a list that also incorporates gender balance and which allows citizens, through parliamentary debate, a thorough knowledge of the various candidates, the various profiles; a list allowing all Europeans to become the owner of the ECB's developments. So, although on a personal level I would have some additional requirements, I am staying at that: we need to bring Europe closer to citizenship, we need to democratize more Europe and we need to dignify this Parliament.

name: El presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: in writing. — In light of growth figures in the euro area, the euro has been saved. The bailout still relies heavily on monetary and investment demand stimulus. The bailout could be a short-term gain at the expense of the long-term unemployed and prove a heavy burden as wealth bubbles burst and the onset of a new crisis. In the long term, rescuing the euro requires a functioning eurozone where markets are efficient and a price mechanism controls resource allocation. Only on the basis of a functioning market can sustainable competitiveness be built without sustained ECB massive monetary stimulus. In practice, rescuing the euro requires, among others, a single labour market in the euro area. Different languages, cultures and practices create obstacles that, like other obstacles in the internal market, should also be addressed in the context of this report and not only focus on politically appropriate problems.

name: El presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate from the Commission Declaration on the manipulation of scientific studies by multinationals following emissions tests in monkeys and humans carried out by the German automotive industry (2018/2565 (RSP))

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I want to state very clearly and strongly that the Commission, and I personally, are shocked by the news that emissions tests have been conducted on animals and humans, because no EU laws justify such behaviour. These were private tests commissioned by the German car industry, and the Commission condemns them in the strongest possible way. The EU has always been highly committed to animal welfare. The EU legal framework in this regard provides for very strict requirements and barriers and, of course, there is no provision for animal testing in the legal framework for cars. The legal follow-up to this unacceptable case is in the hands of national authorities. We are happy to see that the German Government will urgently investigate the matter. This testing of animals and humans adds a new and, I have to say, a much sadder dimension to what we saw during the ‘dieselgate’ scandal. It was just two-and-a-half years ago that we found out that car manufacturers had cheated in emissions tests. Then we read in the press just last year that private emissions tests had been conducted on animals in the USA and on humans in Germany. When I first heard it, I frankly couldn’t believe it. I thought it was just a very unfunny joke. But I have to say, again very personally, that this is the second time the car sector has shown that it is completely untrustworthy. One has to question the ethical behaviour of the German car industry. Is this really, yet again, just an incidence of misbehaviour by a few individuals in a company? I have to say, frankly, I doubt that. There is a systemic problem in this industry. The industry promised us – during our investigation into the emissions scandal – a cultural change: that it would be transparent and would investigate. Yet, once again, we find out about this situation via the media. We should again, and say very strongly, that we must not accept breaking the law, and equally we must not accept the breach of ethical standards. I have repeatedly asked for full transparency in the wake of ‘dieselgate’. Unfortunately I have had to hear, at very regular intervals, that yet another car manufacturer is being investigated for cheating, or that another car recall is being commissioned. At the moment the tools available to us to remedy this situation are still limited. The Commission has launched infringement procedures against some EU Member States. I have also repeatedly asked – and I am repeatedly asking in writing and via Ministers in the Council – for Member States to cooperate fully and inform us fully about the state of play in the investigations and about the remedial action they are taking. I am afraid to say that their willingness to do so has been at best very limited. In the Commission we work very hard, hand in hand, on air quality and our citizens’ health, so I want to say first that I fully support Commissioner Vella in his most recent efforts to accelerate compliance with long-overdue emissions limits. From my side, and with the strong support of the European Parliament – for which I thank you very much – we have put a legal framework in place that would largely prevent future emissions cheating. This should assure consumers and should make the car industry more competitive, as I have repeated many times. However, more ethical behaviour by the car industry now has to follow. This is a must because, as the unacceptable behaviour reported last week shows, changing the legislation alone will not be sufficient: the car industry needs to assume full responsibility for its behaviour. European industry must mean quality – on different levels, including quality in terms of ethics. In this context I will ask Member States to verify the information about testing on humans and animals, to establish whether this situation was occurring in Europe. We know about the testing on humans, but we don’t know whether animal testing has been occurring. And we owe it to our citizens to investigate. I will, of course, come back to you with the response I receive from the Member States.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I, too, consider the experiments to be completely unacceptable, and I would like to add one more argument: the limit values for particulate matter, nitrogen oxides and other pollutants are calculated in such a way that people who are susceptible to health — the elderly, children suffering from asthma, and so on — do not suffer any damage over a longer period of time if they have the health of the elderly, children suffering from asthma and so on. are subjected to stress. How can you test on monkeys or even healthy volunteers — just a few hours — and you can draw from this knowledge that the values may not be right, I do not know. In particular, there are rules as to when animal testing can be done at all. I do not think that animal testing has been done here at all acceptable, as well as the healthy volunteers — I do not know what the point should be. That is why I agree with the view that this was completely unacceptable and that we need to criticise this clearly. This is about long-term exposure, and that is why we must not take short-term measures, which may even be counterproductive, even when it comes to the question of how to get the pollutants under control. If you lock a road and then people take a detour that may be much longer, then that's not the point. We need to get to the root of the problem with cars, but also, for example, buses. I have asked the Commission to do something before — the answer was not very convincing. And, for example, in the case of marine engines: it's incredible that ships still burn the last dirt, in most cases without significant emission control. We must finally do something to better protect people's health and the environment.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, exposing human beings to toxic diesel fumes in a laboratory, and also the monkeys in the United States, already brings us very low. But add to that the fact that the cars in these tests were manipulated, and so the results were manipulated too, and that reminds us, for instance, of the tobacco industry. Remember when they in the past paid for so-called independent research to say that there are no hazardous substances in cigarettes? The aim is to undermine the work of legislators such as us, and at the same time mislead consumers. This week, we will establish a special committee on glyphosates – the same story! Big multinationals paying for so-called independent research with the sole aim of saying to the public that their products are safe; undermining our work in Parliament and making sure that consumers are misled. As long as public authorities, the Commission and national Member States do not punish that misbehaviour, the car industries, and other industries too, will go on doing this. It is time for the Commission – I heard you very clearly, Commissioner, and I like the way you speak and I like the words that you use – but we need action, not just condemnation but also action! In our national market surveillance authorities too, we also need to show our teeth. This is leaving millions of fraudulent cars on our roads, more than two years after the ‘dieselgate’ scandal and our committee work in this Parliament! In our economy, Commissioner, and in our society, no private company, no sector – they may be the largest, they may have a lot of people working there – but none of them should be allowed to act as they do today, as the car industry does today, because then they think they are untouchable and that is absolutely unacceptable!

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I agree with everything critical has been raised here. I must remember that I myself was responsible for German industry for six years, and one must be ashamed. But Mr Liese was right to say that we also have to think about the causes. I can think of a company that keeps getting out: Volkswagen. We'll have to talk about this for a moment today. I remember very well that a few years ago, the Volkswagen Board of Management hired an employee of General Motors to get to the secrets of General Motors. He was severely punished for this. As Chairman of the Supervisory Board of Volkswagen, Gerhard Schröder has appointed an IG-Metall member and appointed Board of Management. This IG Metal member then systematically fixed works councils, paid them the prostitutes and eventually even hired the mistress of one of these works councils. A few weeks ago it emerged that Volkswagen's works council received an extremely high salary, which nurtured the suspicion that this could be fraud. In the meantime, his salary has been cut back. Then came Diesel Gate — it was pointed out — and finally now this monkey theatre. You have to be ashamed. What is one of the reasons for Volkswagen? Whenever politics and business are together, they bounk, something like this comes out. It begins again and again with bailling, then there is corruption and finally the neglect of morals. It's time for Volkswagen to clean up. The first thing that needs to happen is that the company must be privatised for once again. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, I very much appreciate your activity here in Parliament. Concerning this important issue, and especially the testing of emissions on animals and human beings, do you not think that it is now time that we should promote, within the European Union, legislation on research ethics for such conditions?

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – If, indeed, we come to the conclusion that this was possible because there is a law missing, then we should come up with another law. But I tend to believe that we don’t need new laws, I think they violated regulations and laws.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, let me begin by thanking the Commissioner warmly for her firm words, because we all share this indignation at last week's news of the tests on monkeys and humans. That indignation is also fully justified. Because this has nothing to do with scientific research. In fact, this is the undermining of scientific research — as Mr Van Brempt said — similar to the tobacco industry. It shows once again that the moral compass of the European automotive industry is completely upset. More than two years ago, the dieselgate scandal arose and, despite the many promises made by the car industry, millions of shumel diesel are still driving across Europe's streets. That's one of the biggest scandals. But the biggest scandal is, of course, that our Member States — as the Commissioner stressed — allow the car industry to be above the law. Because they didn't test well. They have not maintained. There are no mandatory recalls. And no fines are imposed. Where are the German fines for Volkswagen? Where are the British fines for Skoda? And where are the Italian fines for Fiat? They're not there! My question to the Commission, even in the absence of the Council, is: what can the European Commissioner himself do about this? That is, of course, one of the main questions. We wanted to raise this in the debate in the Committee on the Environment last week. Unfortunately, we did not yet have written answers to our written questions. I would be very grateful if we could still have that answer before we can discuss the debate with you again in the Committee on the Environment. But thank you for your firm today.

name: Stefan Eck
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Politics were once again shocked: VW, BMW, Daimler-Benz had exhaust tests carried out on ten monkeys. Even Chancellor Merkel, who had no interest in animal welfare throughout her term of office, spoke out: the tests on monkeys and even humans could not be justified ethically. Reactions among the population ranged from unethical to repulsive once the tests were known. I can tell you that I do not approve of these exhaust tests in any way, and I can only describe the fraud of the companies involved as scandalous. But what is this farce that is going on here in this house now! Every day, tens of thousands of animals die on animal testing in the EU; in Germany alone, some 2 500 to 3 000 monkeys are tortured and killed in animal experiments every year. New medicines have been and will be tested in clinical trials with the acquisition of major health risks in patients. Animal testing is still done in the tobacco industry. Where is the political outrage here? I didn't interrogate them. Explain to me why an abstract, senseless animal trial — and there are enough of them — can be ethically justifiable, but the diesel exhaust tests are not. We should take this opportunity now to make it clear that all animal testing is generally unethical and unrepresentable. Otherwise, we are ridiculous because the European Parliament is obviously too... (The President withdraws the speaker from the speaker)

name: Karima Delli
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, I have a message for Volkswagen and its competitors in the automotive industry. Twice, in the diesel scandal and during animal testing, you lied to the citizens. Your public apology and the dismissals of your leaders do not deceive anyone. We are waiting for repairs. I am terrified that ethics have so far left the methods of the world's leading manufacturer. 600,000 employees depend on you, 400,000 Europeans are victims of air pollution every year. Respect them! Instead, the automotive industry uses methods worthy of the tobacco industry by enclosing monkeys in cages, to inhale your diesel vapors. But I have a scoop for the automotive industry: diesel is carcinogenic. It is the WTO that has been saying so since 2012. So diesel is over. The rest of the world has already taken the turn of autonomous shared clean vehicles. So, compensate European consumers as in the United States, clear the slate, so that we can finally look to the future.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, the Volkswagen Group is being criticed for conducting a study in 2013 and 2014 on 25 healthy humans for which they had to inhale nitrogen dioxide, a highly toxic gas and a major pollutant in the Earth's atmosphere. In 2014, monkeys were locked up and forced to breathe smoke emitted by a vehicle. In addition to the fact that this blatantly undermines respect for animal welfare and that of the human person, these tests are a second scandal. Indeed, they aimed to study the effects of pollution of Volkswagen diesel engines rigged at the time to appear less polluting, which is all the more condemnable. It will also be interesting to see the follow-up that the European Commission will give to these revelations, given how much it is committed to respect the rules of fair competition and the rules in force.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: — I would much rather listen to the fact that the European Union produces the best electric car than the news of the new scandal. The previous principles were consumer confidence and ge. I am grateful to the Commissioner for emphasizing two key words — trust and ethics. The first thing is consumer confidence and not enough technique, we need a technique with ethics. And I think the European Union needs to develop surveillance, sanctions and preventive measures to make us resilient against these kinds of lies and manipulation. And a few more would be asked - the address that conducted the research is called the European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector. Who grants the right to use the word “European”? Because the word “European” means as if we are almost next because we are a European institution.

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am surprised, but I am not surprised to find myself, once again, standing in this Chamber to talk about the misdeeds of the diesel industry. I am surprised, because the facts we are talking about today — experiments on monkeys and humans subjected to the inhalation of toxic gases, in defiance of all consideration for their dignity and health — are extremely serious. They're even staggering. Conmay. It's unimaginable! But I am not surprised, because the unbridled race for profitability, without concern for human, social and societal costs, has long demonstrated its harmfulness, regardless of the economic field. Some automotive manufacturers did not hesitate to set up a business model based on cheating, a sign of a flawed ethical sense, which is therefore also found in the experiments revealed by the German press. The investigation into emissions fraud had shown how some of them twist European emissions rules to their advantage. It is now seen that the same applies to clinical trial rules and animal protection standards. In these areas, it is up to the European authorities to shed light but also to act. It would also be welcome if the Commission would inform the European Parliament on the status of the five infringement proceedings opened in July 2017 against five Member States that do not adequately sanction emissions fraud. Both subjects are not disconnected, they are well connected. (She agreed to answer a question “blue card” (rule 162, paragraph 8, of the rules of procedure))

name: Peter Liese (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — I said my opinion on the tests. I think they're irresponsible too. But the German translation said, colleague: people and monkeys were forced to inhale these gases. According to my information, this was the case with the people at RWTH Aachen with volunteer volunteers. I think you should argue cleanly. I hope this was a translation error, or do you have any knowledge that people were forced?

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: answer “blue card”. — I have the same information as you. But you realize that these volunteers had to inhale very toxic gases. DoESN'T THAT SHOCK YOU? It is time we could protect consumers and European citizens in the same way as they are in other states. This is what we adopted in the report of the EMIS Committee of Inquiry, and that must be taken into account.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! The scandal we're talking about, of course, has a much wider scope than just these experiments. It's also a political scandal. The mystery of polyshinel is the links between political elites and those managing leading car industry concerns in Germany. The fact that Angela Merkel's once trusted associate straight out of the chancellor's office went on to work in high office at the Daimler concern is just one example of this. So it's not just about Volkswagen, as colleague Henkel convinces us. We all remember the European Commission's dispute with Volkswagen, ultimately lost by the Commission in the wake of an astonishing judgment by the Court of Justice of the European Union. Unfortunately, the Commission has not demonstrated persistence in this case. Lower Saxony still owns 20% of the shares in Volkswagen, and on the supervisory board it is represented by the prime minister of the Land and the economy minister of the Land. So it is possible to doubt whether indeed the national government and the federal government did not know about emissions manipulations and about animal and human experiments being conducted. And they have responsibility for that too.

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President! The fact is that German companies used animals and humans to lie their cars clean. However, as justified as the debate on animal testing and human experimentation is repeated, the greater attempt that takes place is the one with a great many people on our streets every day. Nor can I take our Commissioner's outrage seriously if the indignation at attempts at humans and monkeys does not also result in the outrage of this great attempt that takes place on the streets every day. The car industry, Mrs Bieńkowska, must be persued by you, together with the governments of the Member States, to finally comply with limit values, because otherwise the car industry — and you and your colleagues in the national governments — will be responsible for the fact that people get sick and die prematurely. The technique for this is there, it must finally be applied. And if proper retrofits do not happen, then it is finally necessary to talk about driving bans. That is the real consequence of the scandal. I agree with Mrs Van Brempt, we should no longer trust the lobby of the car industry. It should be given the status of lobby non grata, as is the case with the tobacco industry today. We've had enough of these lies!

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Mr President! As we can hear here tonight, confidence in the European car industry is at a very, very low level — and quite justified. Dieselgate with cheating, monkey testing with exhaust gas and tampering test results. It simply does not pigeon! We need to do something! And yes, there is new legislation on the way that allows Member States better to control, but it will be more than two years before that legislation is in place. Mrs Bienkowska, it is very good to hear that you want the same as us, which is that action must be taken, but then scrutinise EU law and see if there are no tools we can use to punish the car industry in Europe. It doesn't pigeon this! We need to have looked at whether it complies with competition rules and we need to have set up some new ethical playing field for our car industry. So the losers in this are consumers and our environment, and it won't work out! We need to have confidence rebuilt and we can only if we show the car industry that we don't put up with this.

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. This automotive industry, which is simply unsurpassed. So unscrupulous, so unethical. So these monkey tests and human tests are actually just further evidence of the unethics of this lobby. This results in three questions to the European Commission. The first is, do we not have to close existing holes in legislation in animal testing? With cosmetics, it is clear, why not in other areas too? Second question: Professor Dr. Greim, the head of these monkey tests, is on your board of diesel, glyphosate and a third substance, in the endocrine disruptors. If he doesn't fly out of there next week, I think you have a problem. Thirdly, Mrs Harms said: the real scandal is that hundreds of millions of EU citizens are exposed to diesel and non-compliant diesel cars. Where is your list of hardware updates? I've been promised for weeks, months. When will the Commission come up with a list of which cars can be technically upgraded to put an end to this real scandal of people dying in Europe?

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. What happened with the tests, of course, can not be justified by anything and can be condemned in the strongest possible terms. Nevertheless, I would like to focus today on the future, which is to raise the question: how can you avoid such a thing in the future? Commissioner, I believe that we can avoid this by taking the step into the next generation, which will be electrically powered. Although the technologies are already available today, we are not significantly moving forward. We are not making significant progress because we do not have the infrastructure we need today — whether it is the electric charging stations, hydrogen refuelling stations, or even gas filling stations. That is why, Commissioner, in particular, we need 680 000 electrical charging stations across Europe, we need 10 600 hydrogen refuelling stations, and all this will cost us around EUR 24.2 billion. That is why we are proposing a European Clean Mobility Fund, which can be 85% financed by industry, 10% from EU funds and 5% by CO2 fines. We are presenting this proposal to you, Commissioner Bieńkowska. Now it's up to you whether you make something of it or not.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this scandal, all ethical and moral limits have been exceeded. Nitrogen dioxide harms human health and this is sufficiently documented. The German car industry should therefore have simply adapted and not tried to prove a supposed harmlessness of it. It is beyond puzzling the apparent availability of parts of the scientific world that consciously carried out unacceptable experiments that put the health of humans and animals at risk. These tests represent a violation of the fundamental rights recognised by the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, but also of Regulation (EU) No 536/2014 on clinical trials of medicinal products for human use and the Directive on the Protection of Animals used for scientific purposes. This of emissions tests is a sad affair that requires urgent and unequivocal answers. The Commission must undertake a thorough investigation into these practices and their compliance with European legislation and hopefully initiate infringement proceedings.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, it is proved once again that the German automobile industry is a state in a state. We saw it in the case of 'Dieselgate' and we see it in this case, as we have emissions tests on humans; 25 of our fellow people have been exposed to nitrogen dioxide. These are illegal acts. This is a violation of human rights. It's about immoral behavior. From that point on, we have similar tests on animals, especially monkeys. It turns out, therefore, that the unaccountability of the German car industry must be put to an end. There must finally be controls. There must be severe punishment and, of course, provision for compensation for our fellow human beings who participated in these experiments.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, is our society so sick to get toxic gases to human guinea pigs and monkeys breathe for several hours, which I consider to be acts of torture against animals which cannot say no? In this dieselgate case, the scandal is added to the scandal, shame to shame and disgust for the practices of industrialists willing to cheat and out of appetite for gain. That is why we are asking for an investigation; we also ask that they be sanctioned because they contravene the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, they offend our values and, ultimately, they shame us.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Bieńkowska, this is who feeds false science, the ready-to-wear pseudoscience of lobbies. When, in 2012, the IARC declared that the exhaust gases from diesel engines are carcinogenic certain to humans, the car lobbies ran to fund these shameful and unacceptable experiments on guinea pigs animals and humans, in an attempt to disprove science. And it's clear why they did it, because in those same years the car industry was building rigged cars, sold as greener, deceiving consumers and causing one of the most serious health problems of the Our century: air pollution. It is a silent killer who causes more than 400 000 deaths a year and 37 million dirty diesel cars continue to circulate in our streets, with the total indifference and inaction of the Member States, and this is what you do recalled. Commissioner, the citizens of Europe have had enough. The time for discounts to carmakers is over. I thank and appreciate your words, but I expect the Commission to take concrete action and no step back on mobility packages because we are winking again at the sector of car manufacturers and this is no longer acceptable.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: — Mr. President, I am also appalled by all these disclosures that in this particular car concern used such unethical and inhumane methods, such as testing on humans and monkeys. And I wonder, so how far can we go in this profit-making, where are those limits? Obviously these most basic civilizational boundaries are falling and so how far can we go even in being insensitive, unresponsive to these kinds of scandals? I think it is of course also the European Commission's turn to react harshly, not only by warning and possibly changing the rules, but also with appropriate sanctions, because when it comes to such fundamental violations, fundamental rights and also those rights that are linked in international documents, which arise from respect for human dignity, then of course there should be no exceptions here, here there should be no apologies for any conduct that is contrary to this. So once again call to the Commission for harsh sanction so that scandals are not repeated one by one.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, crimes in the name of science are a sad memory of the past. But when these crimes are committed for economic gain, they become heinous and must be punished severely and exemplary. We have learned from the media that a German automobile industry has been experimenting on humans and an American on apes to see the effects of inhalation of automotive fuel on human health. This is an unacceptable and immoral act which violates human rights and makes no sense, because we know very well what levels of carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides are that harm human health. The States must therefore cooperate with the European Union in order to put in place appropriate legislation and to provide for sanctions for these industries. But I ask myself: is this possible when the car manufacturers have close cooperation with European politicians?

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner. I join in condemning these deceptive and degrading fraudulent attempts. However, I might also like to focus today on another problem. If we have the great outrage today about how people and animals are exposed to harmful substances here, and if we have already talked about the tobacco and car industry, I would ask you to examine in the Commission whether we could not adopt a general ban on smoking in cars, because there are hundreds of thousands of children every day, Minors, involuntarilants who sit in the car and are exposed to harmful substances in high concentration. Some Member States have already introduced legislation here that takes this into account. I would ask you to take action here in order to protect children, minors, but also to protect society from the dangers of smoking, namely inattention to road transport. The indignation of industry today is justified, but I believe it would also be worth trying to bring about improvements here in our daily lives.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Bieńkowska, it is not enough for the Commission to state shocked. The question is, how long will the Commission face scandals, immorality and deception on the part of the automotive industry so lukewarm? Why have European mechanisms not found what journalists have discovered? Where are the severe sanctions, both economic and legal, against those who violate every concept of morality and legitimacy? Some have confused the free market with deception, immorality and the transformation of humans into guinea pigs. Where is the implementation of those strong European policies that will put rules and obstacles to these scandals? In the “Dieselgate I” scandal and in the “Dieselgate II” scandal that we are living now? And why do you confine yourself to the German government's investigations? Shouldn't the Commission also investigate? Should we not have common European rules? We want to do things at last; not just for you to regret it.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, the contribution of cars to total air pollution amounts to 60% for carbon monoxide, 30% for nitrogen oxides, 50% for hydrocarbons and 3.5% for sulphur dioxide. Taking into account that exhaust gases are emitted at the height of human breathing, cars are classified as one of the largest pollutants in urban air, with a share of 80 to 99%. In order to meet the Commission's requirements for pollutants standards new vehicles must meet, the car manufacturers do not hesitate to present misleading evidence, as was the case with the software tampered with in the Volkswagen scandal in September of 2015. But they don't stop there. According to the new scandal that erupted in the German automotive industry, Volkswagen, Daimler and BMW groups, in order to prove that engines are not dangerous, were using not only monkeys but also humans in their experiments, in order to find out whether the diesel engines are harmful to primates. It is not enough to apologize to Volkswagen and the Institute for Respiratory Studies after this incredible revelation. We call for the exemplary punishment of all those involved in this scandal.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, yes, I understand the outrage and I agree completely with colleagues who have expressed it, especially when this is coming from what we deemed very reputable companies – like Volkswagen, with a worldwide reputation – and the practices have been rather shocking and there is certainly a need to bring them to order and ensure it does not happen again.  I think it is probably too easy to say the Commission is to blame – it can only do so much – but I think what we have to do now is ensure that we learn lessons from what has happened and collectively come up with a solution. Because with more emphasis being put now on decarbonising transport, more research will be required but it has to be done in a very moralistic way, whether that involves animals, humans or anything else.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, the scandal that resulted from the knowledge of the fraud of handling automobiles has shed some light on the standards under which these multinationals are governed. The drive of profits overrides the environment, health, ultimately, even human life, an eloquent portrait of capitalism. The European Commission has not come out unharmed. The complacency or even complicity of those who knew that the tests carried out and the reference values had no way of being proven was evident in this process. The promiscuity between economic power and political power is thus evident, a promiscuity which the pious calls for ethics and the responsibility of industry only confirm. In practice, the rule is “business as usual”. The revelations that several manufacturers have used human guinea pigs and other primates to test the health effects of diesel engine emissions confirm that we are not dealing with isolated episodes, but a systemic problem, and only systemic solutions to systemic problems.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I want to reiterate what I said before. Without the car industry taking responsibility and admitting that what they are doing is immoral, we will not achieve everything that we can because of course legislation and changing the legislation is not sufficient. I want to state once again very clearly that once we have the legislation – because for now we do not have tools as the Commission to interact and to react in such a situation, but agreement on the type approval was reached in December so I am happy that we will have it – the situation will of course be different. But, as far as animal and human testing are concerned, this is another situation again. So now the national authorities must check what the situation looked like in Europe, whether testing on animals took place and whether we have evidence of this. We probably have the evidence of testing on humans, but again the only link we have is the European Charter of Fundamental Rights. On animal testing we have the legislation for the cosmetic industry and I will discuss with my colleagues in the Commission whether to perhaps extend this testing to cars and the car industry. But as far as extending the emission tests on cars to the health issue, of course politically I support the idea, but technically we should look at all emissions, not only from cars. This requires a much more holistic approach, including specific car tests on health. We can of course discuss it, but again I will come back to this. Without morality in the industry, I do not think we will cover the whole range of problems that may appear one day or another. I will do my best because I will soon have – or my successor will soon have – tools for emissions and for the things that are under the type approval regulation, but animal testing is much wider than we thought during the emissions scandal. As you probably know, I am very dedicated to enforcement. We are currently – I think for three or four months now – analysing information after the first packet of infringement procedures that we opened against five Member States for failing to fine Volkswagen. So, regarding the second package, we are currently analysing the information and data provided by the Member States and I can again reassure you that, if Member States do not cooperate – and they are not so very open on this – I will go ahead with the next step of the procedure. We are not ready for this yet. On the hardware update and the list of equipment, we do not have the technical data in the Commission to provide such a list. If you ask me to do so, I can ask the Member States to provide this information for us, but I can assure you it will take a few more months or even years. For the list of equipment and hardware, I am very open to this. I have only recently heard about this list of equipment and hardware updates, so I can ask the Joint Research Centre whether they are ready to prepare this for us. On recalls, maybe you know that under current regulation the Commission has no power to issue EU—wide mandatory recalls. This will change with the new type approval framework. It is still currently the joint responsibility of Volkswagen and the Member States. I have written a few letters over the last few months calling on Member States to issue mandatory recalls. After this letter the number of Member States with mandatory recalls increased from four to seven, but of course the results of the recalls are not the same everywhere in Europe. In those Member States where the recalls are mandatory they are much higher and much better. If the situation does not change in the next couple of weeks, I am prepared to take further steps on our side and of course again it is legal action against Member States where recall rates are very low and definitely for those where the recalls are voluntary the rates are very low. On the comparison with glyphosate and with the other tests or studies that were submitted, I want to underline that these tests on animals that we are discussing now are not required by our EU type approval legislation. So in the context of EU legislation in other areas and other domains, industry has to submit the studies. This is mandatory. It has to submit the studies when applying for approval of the substances and this was what happened with the glyphosate. Here with private testing such an obligation under our EU type approval legislation does not exist so I think this comparison with some other cases is not relevant. Regarding the response to the written questions to the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), I was told that the current horizontal rules did not foresee such a submission of the written answer ahead of the regular exchange of views, but I can assure you that I will provide you with this response this evening or tomorrow morning. I have been told that we can only provide written answers ahead of the inquiry committee. That is why I am very open to having this exchange with the ENVI Committee, but I was told that horizontally the situation is not appropriate, but we will provide you with the answers to the written questions at the latest tomorrow morning. I want to finish by reiterating what I said at the beginning. We cannot fix mistrust only with a regulatory framework and with legislation. This must come from the industry itself, but it is not happening for now. This is not happening for now and I think this is the biggest shame and the saddest thing in all of this because, after the diesel scandal and after the whole discussion we had with them, I thought that this transparency would be everywhere. Unfortunately, even if I compare the dates, I see that the moment the diesel scandal occurred, it finished. This was about the moment when they were testing on animals and humans – it was 15 and 14, I checked it – so it was at more or less the same time. We will do our best on type approval and emissions. I will discuss testing on animals with my colleagues in the Commission because this is joint work with the Commissioner responsible for health and consumer protection. We will of course discuss it together, but I will still repeat that, without proper discussion with the industry and without a proper admission by the industry that they were doing the wrong things, we will not achieve 100% success because life is much broader than we can imagine. Could you imagine a month or two ago that something like this would be discussed today? No. I was not surprised because I have been living with this for the last two years so I know how things are going, but still I was shocked. Can you imagine what will happen in the next six to ten months? Again we will try then to prepare legislation and to change the legislation. The legislation is extremely important but it is not the only thing. We have the legislation in place. Member States have the legislation in place. But it does not work if there is no will for it to work.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you so much for those replies. Commissioner, indeed life is difficult and sometimes it surprises us, but sometimes we feel like the Commission is not always surprised. I think the issue is going to be important and we're going to be meeting that. Thank you for participating in this afternoon's debate. Thank you colleagues and colleagues for your statements. I'm closing the debate. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Carolina Punset (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The automotive industry has not been able to fall lower, after it was known that Volkswagen, BMW and Daimler used monkeys and people in experiments, the results of which they concealed as being harmful to health. Like tobacco in its day, this sector lies. Brands manipulate eleven million vehicles, and they take us for fools. The automotive industry does not care about the more than 70,000 premature deaths that have caused emissions from fuels, mainly diesel, with extreme pollutant levels in more than 130 cities across 23 states since 2103. The oil lobby is your great ally. 78% of the oil consumed in Europe goes to road transport, the only industrial sector that does not reduce its GHG emissions and continues to increase them. But the most bleeding is the high degree of subsidies that fuel receive. According to the IMF more than $5.3 trillion, or 6.5 per cent of world GDP. With these peers, the automotive sector is campaeming with impunity, undermining our health and destroying the planet. A non-emission propulsion change will occur when the flawed relationship with the oil lobby, maintained by overwhelming State subsidies, is broken.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item of the order of the day is the report drawn up by Rose Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on geographical blocking and other forms of discrimination based on customer nationality, their place residence or place of business on the internal market and amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Directive 2009/22/EC (COM (2016) 0289 - C8-0192/2016 - 2016/0152 (COD)) (A8-0172/2017)

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein
text: rapporteur. — Mr President! There are days when you should enjoy, when you should feel satisfaction. Today, we have a day like this, because today crowns the work of many people, many institutions, many organizations. Today we can say that we achieve something measurable for the citizens of the European Union together, something that will really affect the lives of each of us. Almost two years ago here, the current commissioner Andrus Ansip proposed a ban on refusing online sales on the grounds of nationality or because of the location of the customer. Because, after all, it is not normal that in a united 21st century Europe, where we move freely between states, there are still such meaningless restrictions in the world of e-commerce. Today we can say that we are going for success, success still incomplete, because there is very much to do, but thanks to the new law, each of us will feel concrete changes for the better. Tomorrow, please, we vote. No more refusing to sell when buying goods or services online because of the customer's residence or nationality. End technical barriers to access websites and applications. No more auto-redirecting to a seller's website in another country without customer consent. No more use in the same store of different conditions of sale of goods and services, including prices, depending on the nationality or place of residence of the customer. No more refusing to sell because of the country of credit card issuance. We have also taken care of the dealings of the If the entrepreneur does not direct his offer, if he does not direct his business to the country, then the consumer is not still geoblocked, but arranges himself to collect the goods, and thanks to this solution small sellers do not need to know the regulations of each of the 28 countries The European Union separately, because we have not yet harmonised these rules. I'm not hiding, we wanted more. We have taken the Commission together for inclusion to this regulation at least non-audiovisual content, those protected by copyright: iBooks, music, software, games. Unfortunately we failed to fight the resistance of the Council. I am grateful to my colleagues and colleagues for their cooperation and for their willingness to compromise, because by doing so, geoblocking — for now only physical products — passes to the past. I direct my words of appreciation to the representatives of the Estonian Presidency — such a small country and its excellent representatives have shown how efficiently complex negotiations can be carried out, even more than more challenges faced by the Council partners than during negotiations with Parliament and the Commission . So thank you all again: the members of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, including particularly other rapporteurs, and my brave and competent colleagues.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank Parliament for this important achievement, and particularly the rapporteur, Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein. You have demonstrated your belief in this proposal and how it will benefit Europeans. Thank you for helping it become reality. The Geo-Blocking Regulation lies at the heart of the e-commerce package that we designed to remove barriers for consumers and companies trading online. It will end artificial segmentation and unjustified discrimination based on nationality or residence. Using either of these as a reason to deny access to websites, goods or services will finally no longer have a place in Europe’s single market, either online or offline. Today, only 37% of websites allow consumers to buy from another EU country, because people get blocked and rerouted elsewhere. This situation cannot exist in a digital single market, and we have to end it. Our aim is that, by Christmas, all Europeans will be able to enjoy online shopping without being blocked, rerouted or discriminated against. That is why we need to adopt this regulation without any further delay. I would also like to ask for your support and commitment to make the entire digital single market a reality on the ground. Again, the clock is ticking. We have to move quickly, and adopt and implement initiatives where the co-legislators have already reached agreement. We are making good progress on e-commerce, and European consumers should soon feel the benefits of recent political agreements, which need to be implemented quickly. From 1 April this year, new rules on the cross-border portability of online content services will allow Europeans to access their music and e-books when they travel to other EU countries. To make sure this happens, companies should comply with the rules as from their dates of application. We recently agreed on new rules to make prices for cross-border parcel delivery services more transparent and affordable. Consumers and companies, in particular SMEs, will be able to send and receive products across the EU with greater ease and confidence. It is also essential for the success of the Geo-Blocking Regulation that we work as hard as we can for this regulation to be quickly and formally approved. In December, new rules on VAT for electronic commerce were adopted. They will facilitate VAT collection when consumers buy goods and services online and make it easier for online businesses to comply with their VAT obligations. Member States should now work quickly and efficiently to transpose this directive. In addition, it is vital that we make progress on other proposals that are still being negotiated and are necessary for the digital single market. I am talking about the proposals on digital contracts, which concern contract rules on the supply of digital content and the online sale of goods. Thank you for your attention, I am looking forward to the discussion.

name: Εύα Καϊλή
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. — (EL) Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for the outcome of the trialogue negotiations, because it has been an extremely successful step towards the completion of the single digital European market. I am particularly pleased that, as rapporteur on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I see that our priorities in committee have been guaranteed and, indeed, more than that. All EU citizens will now have geographically inclusive access to online offers of products and services from other countries, without being redirected to other websites and paying different prices for the same product. Congratulations to you too, Mr Vice-President, for having remained ambitious that we now have practical access to better prices and an end to discrimination between European citizens themselves, which was not easy. Sometimes it was easier to export to China than to overcome the obstacles that existed in the European Union market. Indeed, the now mandatory acceptance of credit cards will facilitate online transactions, without excluding countries with restrictions on capital movements. The removal of these barriers is a decisive step for the benefit of citizens and we are also creating new opportunities for businesses, so that they can develop their activities and promote their quality products within Europe. At the same time, in two years, during the revision of the regulation, it will be extended to other sectors for other products and services at low prices and at the best possible quality. This creates a stronger Union in many areas.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. A fully functioning digital single market is important for the European cultural and creative sectors. We welcome the Commission's approach of letting electronically supplied services providing access to copyrighted content outside the scope of the proposed regulation. E-books or music services have different funding and licensing models that require careful analysis. The Committee on Culture therefore supports the review clause on the condition that particular attention must be paid to the specificities of cultural goods and services. However, it must also be recalled that there is particular complexity in the area of audiovisual services and territorial copyright rules. For this reason, audiovisual services are treated in a specific legal framework, the AVMS Directive and the SATCAB Directive. As the Commissioner also said, the trilogues on the two dossiers are running. The geo-blocking proposal should not include audiovisual services. The Committee on Culture is opposed to changing the regulation of audiovisual services through the back door and outside the sectoral legal framework.

name: Antanas Guoga
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the future regulation on geo-blocking is a big step towards strengthening the e-commerce sector in Europe. It will give EU citizens access to a wider choice of goods and services. Today only 15% of Europeans buy products from online shops based in another EU country. One of the main reasons is precisely the geo-blocking practice, and we need to get rid of this. EU citizens have a right to be able to shop online in another EU country just like the locals do. That is the core idea behind the digital single market that we have been working on in the European Parliament. I would like to thank the EPP rapporteur, Ms Róża Thun, for her commitment and a great job during the negotiation process with the Commission and the Council during the Estonian Presidency. The agreement between the Council and the Parliament will remove barriers to e-commerce by avoiding discrimination based on a consumer’s nationality, place of residence or place of establishment. It will prevent discrimination for consumers and companies based on access to prices, sales or payment conditions when buying products and services in another EU country. EU consumers will benefit now from better prices when buying online, and traders will be protected with a clearer set of rules laid down in this draft regulation. It is unfortunate that the inclusion of non-audiovisual copyrighted content in the scope of the regulation was rejected by the Council. I, as shadow rapporteur on this file in the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI), together with Ms Thun, will work towards a review in two years’ time. All in all I believe it is a balanced approach.

name: Virginie Rozière
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, first of all I would like to thank my colleagues and especially the rapporteur for the excellent work and collaboration on this issue. I believe that the text we are about to adopt is a good compromise, which will make it possible to take another step towards a deeper and more efficient digital market for the benefit of consumers. Because I would like to point out that the internal market is one of the pillars of European integration and that, if the internet changes consumption patterns, it should not be a way to return to the foundations of our Union. In particular, discrimination between consumers in the internal market is unacceptable. When I go to a bakery in Belgium or when our colleagues here go to a business in Strasbourg, they should not be denied a refusal to sell them what they want to buy, on the pretext that they are Italian or Belgian or because they reside in another Member State. On the Internet, this is exactly the same thing and I am glad that this regulation will put an end to situations of discrimination. This regulation will therefore result in a wider choice for consumers and an additional benefit for them. But just as discrimination is unacceptable, it would have been equally unacceptable to unfairly lessen consumer protection on the pretext that it is an online purchase. Fortunately, this regulation, as our group has requested, will maintain a high level of protection for consumers engaged in cross-border transactions. I also wanted to stress here that it was important to be careful about the impact of this regulation on specific sectors, with a specific economic model. I therefore welcome the possibility that the cultural sector can be assessed at a later stage as part of a possible upcoming revision. But what this text shows above all, beyond the progress we have been able to make, is that it is within the framework of ever more demanding harmonisation in consumer protection that we can build an ever more efficient internal market. I think that is the same sense that the European Union must move forward.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, I am delighted that, from the end of this year, Europeans will be able to go on bargain hunting throughout Europe without hurting all sorts of obstacles because of their location. Because of the new rules on which we will vote, the shopping experience will become much more enjoyable. The online market will be much broader, with in many cases a cheaper supply of goods and services. Companies will also not have to be aware of the legislation of all European Member States. In this way, they will also be encouraged to sell in other Member States. Our companies will therefore be able to enjoy a broader customer base, a win-win situation. The audiovisual sector is not affected by these rules, and fortunately it is. This sector plays an important role in the formation of our language and our culture. Unconditional universal access to series or other productions could jeopardise their financing, and this would have negative effects on cultural diversity.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I had the honour to chair the negotiations on this file on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and I can truly thank Ms Thun for all her work and all her efforts. This regulation is a good first step.  No longer can Disneyland say that the French can get cheaper tickets than Czechs. This regulation fixes this. No longer can a company redirect customers without their consent. If I ask for the German website, I want a German website, not a Czech one. This regulation fixes this. No longer can a company refuse because a credit card was issued in another country. If I go shopping in Austria, my Visa card is just as good as an Austrian Visa card. This regulation fixes this. This said, we must address the elephant in the room: copyrighted content. Let’s be honest, this regulation will not fix the problem of blocked access to movies, TV, software or even e—books. It will not fix the first item that people think of when they hear the word geo—blocking and we must continue to move towards the end of this type of geo—blocking. We must end this artificial barrier in the digital single market.

name: Julia Reda
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, at the outset of the Commission’s efforts to tackle geo—blocking, research showed that digital borders were widespread in the EU, that they cost businesses millions in sales and that people supported decisive action against them. A very important and popular topic indeed.  This week we are voting on the second of three legislative actions on the issue, but all three have turned out to be no more than baby steps, merely carving out exceptions for certain groups of people in certain situations. After they are implemented, geo—blocking will remain widespread. That is a missed opportunity.  I applaud all the steps forward that have been taken in this legislation, and I thank the rapporteur Róża Thun for her efforts to make it even more ambitious, but I deeply regret that these efforts were shot down by the governments in Council and that, as a result, digital media, like video games, e—books or music, will be unaffected by this regulation, and that fear prevailed over the commitment to building a true digital single market, which cannot develop until we abolish digital borders and not just reduce them.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the ultimate aim of this legislation and other such proposals, is the furthering of the single market and harmonisation of legislation across Europe. Such reports exist in order to fulfil one political objective, a United States of Europe. Recent events in the UK prove that there is no appetite for this. Differences in prices are because of supply and demand, ultimately a common sense approach adopted by businesses. The European Union is made up of 28 Member States, all of whom carry different cultures and identities, a one-size-fits-all approach to such diversity just does not work. It is of course a positive to be giving citizens better access to goods and services, however businesses should be free to conduct sales as they see fit, without the EU telling them what to do. If it worked for businesses to implement the aims of this legislation they would have already done so themselves. The Commission should recognise this and leave Member States and businesses to determine what is in their own best interests and act as they see fit.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, according to the rapporteur, 15% of consumers, I would say 'only' 15% of consumers and 8% of professionals bought or sold online in another Member State. That is the rationale and justification of the regulation we are debating today. Here is the illustration of the sense of priorities in the digital single market. European legislators are convinced to find here, with this regulation, a remedy for the existential crisis facing the European Union. So what does this text say? That the reasons for these low rates of cross-border consumption are the unjustified barriers imposed by Member States through geo-locking technology, removing European consumers from nirvana from consumption. “Geoblocking” is a concept that actually refers to digital boundaries. This concept is widely disregarded by the European legislature, who defines it as — and I quote — discrimination on the basis of nationality or place of residence. The regulation simply wants to prohibit the use of it to professionals. Despite the temporary exclusion of audiovisual services from the scope of the regulation — which I welcome — I want to denounce this new brutal unilateral intervention in economic equilibria, a measure which will have serious consequences for many operators, who will see their consumers go to consume where it is cheaper .

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President! The European Parliament regulation on geo-blocking ensures that there is a legal basis for the fact that commercial transactions between customers and suppliers can be concluded without undue discrimination. That sounds so far, so good. But if there is unjustified discrimination, then there is also justified discrimination. I miss them here, and I suspect that is the political discrimination. After all, we just allowed geo-blocking vis-à-vis Russia at the last part-session of Parliament for political reasons and even installed a separate force for this. What about the hypocrisy towards my country, Germany, where the Merkel regime has just created a network enforcement law that allows an entire censorship army to be put on its feet in a private company like Facebook and suddenly people can be shut down here — without legal hearing , without the possibility of getting a free procedure?

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: Mr President, I am glad that I am speaking after Mr Voigt, because he confuses everything. What is at stake is a binding decision within the EU. This has nothing to do with Russia or beyond. This is about the internal market and the way in which we have organised the matter. And our citizens deserve it. Get rid of price discrimination online. It doesn't matter where you make your purchase in the EU. It hits everyone. Why would a rental car at my national airport Schiphol in the Netherlands cost me more than a resident from another Member State who comes to the counter? And why would a ticket for Eurodisney in Paris cost me more than the French when I book online? Get rid of the arbitrariness, also in the conditions and in the discounts that are offered. I am also pleased that Rosa Thun has worked so hard and, with the support of the Estonian Presidency, has achieved a clear result that is also enforceable by regulators. This opens the page to the digital internal market for which we are now making so many proposals. Only 15% of consumers make purchases across the Union and the number of businesses entering the digital market is still low. So a good step. The next stage concerns digital audiovisual services. You can do that in two years. I'm very happy. I don't understand where you get your example. (The speaker answered a blue card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Question about the procedure for the 'blue card'. I would have just a very short question: do you know that goods, namely advertising, can also be bought via Facebook and that this is often turned off in Germany without a legal procedure, without the legal possibility of doing anything about this?

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE)
text: 'Blue Card' answer. — (NL) What matters is that here in the European Union we must treat businesses and citizens alike. I don't know exactly what the deal is with advertising, if you can stop it. In this respect too, we must deal in the same way. Advertising is sometimes part of the messages provided. But the essence is that, wherever they make a purchase, citizens are treated in the same way.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the end of the unjustified geoblock is a further step in the process of building the digital single market. After the abolition of roaming and after we have allowed online content portability, European citizens will finally see the end of those barriers and unjustified discrimination, which up to To date they have constituted an impediment to the possibility of having a European e-commerce. In fact, the Commission found that more than 63% of online sales sites still apply blocking forms which often end with the practical impossibility to conclude a purchase or choose the offer more convenient.
