Online shopping will be easier from today. For example, the ability to rent a car without paying any surcharge depending on the nationality or location of the consumer is certainly a conquest. However, in conclusion, important challenges remain ahead, which cannot be won until a harmonised framework of tax rules, product safety assurance and product safety assurance is defined. full consumer protection.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, who has done a good job here. E—commerce is one of our fastest growing industries. Consumers no longer recognise borders and boundaries when shopping. The internet gives them the choice to look for anything, anywhere. That is a revolution in choice. But sadly, the law and many companies have yet to catch up with shoppers. That is why this regulation is important: breaking down artificial barriers and ending unfair price discrimination. Now I am sad that I cannot yet pay to watch cricket coverage and other audiovisual stuff here in Belgium, but that will come in the future. Because with more competition, we get lower prices and better service: everyone wins. We have come a long way from the Commission’s original proposal, which needed some work, but no company now has to sell where it cannot deliver. But everything will see more transparency and cheaper pricing. This is a digital revolution in action. So I commend this report as an action of good policy – but a warning: do not cut the EU off from the rest of the world. This should be a template for global e—commerce. We should see customs de minimis thresholds brought in line with offline thresholds. E—commerce and consumers should not be punished just for shopping online. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. — Suppose the French government subsidizes something, say Disneyland. Isn't Disneyland allowed to introduce relief prices for the French at this point?

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, as I understand it, we’re in a single market and in a single market there’s a principle that consumers cannot be discriminated against on nationality. That’s the principle of the single market in general and it should be a principle that applies in the digital single market. We can’t have two different rules for online and offline commerce.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President! If we adopt the geo-blocking regulation tomorrow, we will have taken a major step closer to the digital single market. Geoblocking is diametrically contradicting the objective of a common internal market. It is absurd that artificial boundaries are being established for intangible goods. Tomorrow's decision is an important stage win because it strengthens consumer rights, promotes competition and helps to consolidate a common market. We have achieved a great deal, and I am happy to join in thanking the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs. But we shouldn't rest on it. We still have a lot of work to do. Our goal must be a truly limitless Internet that applies to all offers and platforms. That is why our current work on copyright legislation is so important. We must carry them out responsibly and not lose the pan-European aspect.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Mr President, the prohibition on discrimination based on nationality is already established by the directive on services in the internal market. Internal market rules we need to adapt to today's digital reality and blocking say a clear no. Thanks to this regulation, citizens on the internal market will be able to purchase goods electronically on fair terms, book accommodation, use services throughout the EU and finally without distinction of origin customers. The proposal is reasonably balanced, in my opinion. Customers should have access to goods and services under the same conditions, but it will not entail unreasonable costs for entrepreneurs and nor will it automatically incur an obligation to comply with the rule of law the state of the consumer, nor the obligation to deliver goods throughout the EU. I find it right that the regulation will not apply to electronically supplied services and works that are copyrighted, such as books, music and others, and should be the case until we solve fair funding of authors.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: — Mr President, discrimination against consumers on the basis of their nationality or country of residence is unfortunately a daily reality of the internal market of the European Union, not only in the online environment. Limited choice, different payment terms, unwarranted price differences, but also different quality at first glance of the same goods are an unpleasant experience for many consumers. The Geographical Blocking Regulation will restrict and make it easier for consumers to access a range of goods and services. This is a step in the right direction, and I would like to thank the rapporteur, Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein, in particular. Work to bring about a fair internal market where consumers have equal access to goods and services, but also where consumers are not knowingly and deliberately misled, certainly does not end with acceptance. I believe that this will also be taken into account by the Commission in preparing a package of measures of new policy for consumers, which we are already waiting impatiently for.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the single market is an important achievement of the European Union itself and, of course, the single market does not allow discrimination of any type. It is therefore logical that the digital single market should operate in the same way. The fact that the Internet is now being used to purchase services or products does not mean that discrimination against consumers is legitimized. There may be no discrimination on the basis of the nationality of the consumer or on the basis of the place of residence or place of residence. Therefore, the decisions we take and the regulation, which now eliminates all these discrimination, are an important step at European Union level. However, discrimination concerning music content and books must also be stopped. These things are wrong to stay out of the rules.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, trade, even in its so-called electronic form, starts from concrete production and distribution processes and from concrete, real and non-virtual, non-dematerialisable social relations of production. The sale of goods and services in the Single Market, even by electronic means, expresses a link that is established via that market between the various producers, between workers from different countries, put into direct competition, taking advantage of the differences in wages and duties to force a devaluation of your workforce. In capitalist integration, this is the meaning of the much-propaled freedom of movement of goods and services: levelling down, increasing exploitation, winning markets and increasing profits online or off-line. Of course, the full potential of e-commerce is yet to be unleashing, as in general the enormous potential of acquisitions of science and technology for the benefit of workers and consumers. It is true that there are obstacles in the online environment that frustrate natural expectations from consumers, but working to overcome them must not make us lose sight of this more general picture.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: — Mr. President, every day artificial digital borders block millions of Europeans from ordering goods, watching movies, listening to music online, watching sports downloads, and all because of so-called geoblocking, because of this so-called unfair and inadmissible discrimination. What we have now on the table, this regulation, in some ways we can not be quite really happy, because it also means disappointment, because many good elements have been removed, and above all, the regulation completely excluded videos, music, e-books, online computer games, that is, that is, the area that most used in ordering, just because someone is from an incorrectly state and this geographical blockade because of the countries of origin is, of course, inadmissible and the real geoblocking can be eliminated completely or not.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Mr President! Geographic blocking is a problem many citizens face every day. Research indicates that about 30% of consumers shopping online at least once encountered problems buying merchandise on an overseas website. Practices such as forced and automatic redirection to a local site are obviously at odds with the principle of equal access to services and discriminate against customers. The provisions of the Service Directive have unfortunately proved insufficient to avoid such situations. I therefore support the Commission's initiative, which aims to introduce greater legal clarity and enforceability. However, the case is extremely complex, so I am all the more pleased that after a year and a half of intensive work, an agreement has been reached which seems to be a very sensible compromise. A ban on redirecting to other sites without explicit user consent means consumers will gain access to a broader, non-discriminatory no-one offer.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the collective effort to combat discrimination against consumers by removing unnecessary barriers for accessing the same level and quality of online services for the benefit of citizens across the EU. Nevertheless, for some online services it is important to keep a balanced perspective and ensure the viability of content creation, in particular for creative and media content. The principle of territoriality is at the core of the economic models of many European content producers, media services providers and channels. It is also in many cases how the production of high-quality European works of all types is ensured, nourishing a vibrant cultural diversity. I am particularly concerned about small independent creators and artists. It is very difficult for smaller enterprises to earn a living today and I want to make sure that their interests are defended along with increased accessibility of content and cultural diversity for users.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate was just music to my ears. Let’s remember from where we had to start. We organised a so-called ‘mystery-shopping survey’ and according to those results 2% of those people who tried to buy some goods and services from another EU Member State just could not get access to those websites.  Then 27% of those lucky people who got access to those websites were not able to register because their IP addresses were wrong addresses: they were from France, from Germany, from Austria, from Poland – from some EU Member State that was wrong in some way. Then 32% of those lucky people who were able to register were faced with delivery problems and to find solutions for those problems we launched our parcel delivery proposal, and I am happy that we were able to find consensus on that proposal. But even 26% of those people who did not have issues of any kind with delivery problems, could not pay because their credit cards were issued in wrong the countries: in Sweden, in Finland, in Latvia, in Lithuania, in the United Kingdom – in some EU Member State that was wrong in some way.  All in all, just 36.6% of all those people who tried to buy some goods and services from another EU Member State were able to conclude those purchases successfully. This is not the single market we would like to have in the European Union when only every third person is able to conclude those purchases successfully. We have to hurry up. We have to have some votes here in Parliament, in the Council, then publishing, then a signing ceremony and then nine months, and then it will already be Christmas time. But our people deserve to enjoy their Christmas shopping next year without being afraid of being blocked or re-routed. So I would like to ask you to hurry up.  Then I would like to state very clearly that the Commission is fully committed to carrying out a comprehensive assessment of this regulation’s scope to identify if other sectors should also be included. We will pay particular attention to the non-audiovisual copyright protected services like software, games, e—books and music that the regulation only covers only partially now. We will keep our promise to the co-legislators. Once again I would like to cordially thank the rapporteur Ms Róża Thun and all the Members of the European Parliament.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission Vice-President for his words and for the excellent cooperation, and thanks also to your wonderful team, Mr Vice-President. Colleagues, thank you for this constructive debate, which has been music to my ears. This compromise was long, this compromise was difficult but we have managed to achieve it. This compromise, thanks to the determination and hard work of many of us, will bear good fruits. I am asking for your broad support in the vote tomorrow. We proved today that the European Union can deliver concrete results for citizens all over Europe, bringing positive changes in our daily lives, but for the full completion of the digital single market we still need many reforms and a lot of work. We need to do our best to break down national silos. There is no place for protectionism in our common European market. The next step we should take is harmonisation of the VAT rules. We also need to unify copyright protection rules and open up the services market in the audio-visual sector. We need to improve the functioning of parcel delivery within the EU, and this is not all. I am counting on the Commission to continue the role of a leader in this extremely important process. I hope that the Council will help us in these efforts. As for us, in Parliament, I hope to see this project at the forefront of our agenda. Already now, I am looking forward to the review in two years, which you have just mentioned Mr Vice-President. Citizens want improvement, they want changes, for a more united digital single market, and we will keep working on delivering that improvement.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: It was a real pleasure to preside over this debate. There has long since been such far-fetched unanimity in this room. Thank you very much to Vice-President Ansip and wish you a pleasant evening in Strasbourg. I'm closing the debate. Voting will take place on Tuesday 6 February 2018 Declarações escritas (artigo 162.º)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Geoblocking represents a discriminatory business practice used to artificially segregate markets so as to maximize profits. In other words, what happens in practice is that online sellers: either prevent consumers from accessing a website because their IP address indicates a specific geographical location, or they they rdirect to a local online sales site that practices different pricing. In the light of this and in view of the implementation of the single digital market, geoblocking practices should be prohibited, especially in those areas such as audiovisual where such a practice It is evident and unjustifiable in the eyes of the ordinary citizen. The regulation in question therefore represents a relevant regulatory act, but because of the exclusion from the scope of audiovisual content, streaming music, video games and of e-books, its effectiveness has been drastically deenhanced. Which prodest? Certainly not to European citizens who will continue to undergo the practice of geographical blocks, with a negative impact both on the circulation of content and for promoting and safeguarding diversity cultural. The economic interests of a few have, once again, had the better of the interests of the community.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — Prevent geographical blocks and other forms of customer discrimination based on nationality, place of residence or place of establishment.

name: Валентин Радев
text: , in writing. — Fellow Members, the ban on geo-blocking is an important element of the Digital Single Market strategy. The abolition of this principle will extend the freedom of e-commerce and European citizens will get better access to e-sales websites. Traders will no longer be allowed to block or restrict access to their online interface by customers for reasons related to their citizenship or place of residence. Given that today only 15% of Europeans shop online from shops established in other countries, ending geographical blocking will contribute to the development of the single market and remove important barriers to trade. This will also benefit European businesses, which will be able to benefit from the strong development of cross-border online commerce. For the moment, services relating to copyrighted content or works in intangible form are excluded from the scope of the Regulation. But I hope in two years, when a review of its implementation is carried out, these services will be included as well. Thus, we will be able to contribute to removing the remaining obstacles to the free movement of goods and services and the maximum development of the internal market.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Written. — Has it ever happened to you that a website that sold a particular service, after it detected that you were from another country, redirected you to another page where, possibly, these services were more expensive? I am pleased that we are removing this by regulation, as from now on, blocking or redirecting due to the consumer's nationality, place of residence or his temporary location to another site will be prohibited. According to a survey by Voice of European Consumers in Standardisation (ANEC), nearly a quarter of respondents have already experienced their online order being rejected because they are home from another, “wrong” EU country. The Regulation allows traders to allow cross-border customers to access country-specific websites. I hope that this Regulation will eliminate the disadvantage and give better access to goods and services to customers.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – We aspire to support the realisation of the full potential of the internal market as an area without internal barriers. Ensuring the free movement of goods and services is one of our greatest values and achievements. Nowadays, the internal market includes also e-Commerce, which is one of the main key drivers for the growth. According to statistics only 15% of consumers buy online from other EU countries and 8% of traders sell cross-border (as compared to 24% of domestic sales), which is absolutely not enough. Therefore, we should try to reduce trade barriers as fast as possible. It is unacceptable for the consumers to be prevented from accessing certain websites, not be able to buy certain goods in other Member States or have to pay a different price - only based on their place of residence or even temporary location. I appreciate hard work and effort of the Rapporteur Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein. The adopted report covers many important issues that required difficult inter-institutional negotiations. The final agreement opposes discrimination in the e-Commerce which is an important step forward for the EU.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – The debate on the Regulation addressing geo-blocking and other forms of discrimination based on nationality is timely and vital for our citizens. By seeking to effectively implement the Single Market, not only for goods, but also for services, digital commerce, capital and energy, we would create 4 million new jobs for our citizens, while adding approximately 1.5 billion to the EU economy. Even though this is a step in the right direction, the proposal at hand is yet imperfect, given that it does not address all forms of discrimination, particularly copyrighted content. This includes transmissions of films, television, music or e-books. I see a link here to the truly worrying situation of almost 50 million people, those citizens belonging to ethnic and linguistic minorities across Europe, who continue to be affected by such discriminatory practices. It is exactly these citizens who have come together and signed the Minority SafePack Initiative, aiming to address such key deficiencies and tackle discrimination based on ethnicity. The geo-blocking of copyrighted content is an important factor here, and it is the obligation of the EP to also hear the voice of citizens belonging to minorities and address this shortcoming in the revision of this Regulation.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item of order of the day is the Commission's statement on the decision taken on the Fair Taxation Package (II and III) (2017/2857 (RSP)).

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for organising a debate on the EU VAT reform, a key initiative included in the 2017 Commission work programme and a topic of utmost importance for Member States and businesses. Member States reply heavily on value added tax (VAT) revenues to finance their public spending. However the VAT gap between expected revenue and revenue actually collected is estimated at more than EUR 150 billion per year. It has also been estimated that cross—border fraud alone represents an annual loss of revenue of around EUR 50 billion, money that could be spent on public services. The current VAT system is not only prone to fraud, but also too fragmented for a growing number of businesses operating cross—border. Therefore the Commission decided to renew the VAT system as part of its agenda for a fair and efficient tax system in the European Union. In particular, the Commission is proposing to create a single European VAT area that caters for the challenges of the 21st century. I recall that the weaknesses of the current system were acknowledged also by this Parliament in its resolution ‘towards a definitive VAT system and fighting VAT fraud’ of November 2016. In the same resolution Parliament shared the Commission’s view that the definitive VAT system should be based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination, which addresses tax competition between Member States. I am proud to say that the Commission has delivered on all its commitments made in the Action Plan on VAT of April 2016. The first proposal of the Action Plan, which will modernise and simplify VAT for cross—border e—commerce, was adopted by the Council in December last year. This is very good news for businesses. Furthermore, between October last year and 18 January this year, the Commission adopted the last five proposals announced in its Action Plan. I will present these five proposals to you today by focusing on their three main objectives. Firstly, to create a single VAT area that establishes a level playing field for EU businesses and in particular for SMEs. Secondly, to create a single VAT area that is fraud—proof, with tax administrations working closely together. And thirdly, to create a single VAT area that treats Member States equally and grants them more freedom in setting VAT rates. So to start with the first objective, a level playing field for businesses, I would remind you that our current VAT system is fragmented, complex for a growing number of businesses operating cross—border. The latter have VAT compliance costs 11% higher than companies having only domestic activities. We have to open the borders of VAT and create a real single VAT area for EU companies. The proposals adopted in October 2017 represent the cornerstone for a new system, based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination, which will result in taxing cross—border sales the same way as domestic sales. The main simplification is that companies selling cross—border will deal with their VAT obligations via a one—stop—shop. That means that traders will make declarations and payments using a single online portal.  The Commission also adopted in January 2018 measures to simplify VAT procedures for SMEs, which represent over 98% of all EU businesses. Currently the cost of compliance under the present VAT system hits SMEs much harder than it does big business. The proposal we made will extend the benefits of the VAT SME exemption to all small businesses, irrespective of whether they are established in the Member State in which the VAT is due or not. The new rules will also simplify compliance for a larger group of SMEs – exempt and non-exempt from VAT. All businesses with a turnover of less than EUR 2 million per year will be able to benefit from simplified registration, invoicing, reporting and book—keeping obligations. We estimate that this proposal will result in a compliance cost reduction of up to 18% for SMEs. The second main objective of our VAT reform is to address the unacceptable problem of VAT cross—border fraud which, as already mentioned, represents around EUR 50 billion per year. Criminal networks exploit the weaknesses of the current VAT systems. Journalists have also established links between cross—border fraud and the financing of terrorism. This is no longer acceptable and we should put an end to this phenomenon. By eliminating borders for VAT procedures, the new definitive VAT system should eliminate much of the large—scale cross—border VAT fraud. As implementing a new regime will take time, we need to take urgent measures to contain cross—border VAT fraud. This is why the Commission proposed in November 2017 a proposal to enhance the cooperation between national administrations and close loopholes in information sharing. This proposal, which is now being discussed in the Council, aims to build trust between Member States by allowing them to exchange more information, in a more efficient manner, so as to better detect and identify fraudsters. This proposal will also boost the cooperation between national tax authorities and law enforcement authorities such as customs, OLAF, Europol and the newly created European Public Prosecutor’s Office. Eventually our intention is to reduce complexity around the issue of reduced VAT rates. Although there are general rules, over 200 reduced and zero rates still exist in all Member States, that were initially intended as temporary derogations from the general rules. In the frame of the definitive system based on the principle of destination, which will address tax competition, Member States would have more freedom to set their VAT rates under harmonised rules that will treat all Member States equally. One of the major changes proposed by the Commission is to replace the list of goods and services to which reduced rates can be applied with a negative list to which reduced rates cannot be applied. The main advantage of this negative list is that it is to be structured according to the statistical classification. The same statistical classification will also be used to collect and publish structured information about reduced rates applied in all Member States via a web portal. On these grounds the web portal will allow all businesses to easily retrieve information on VAT rates.  Further harmonisation concerns the use of reduced rates. They must clearly be for the benefit of citizens, who are the final consumers paying VAT. To prevent revenue erosion the Commission will protect VAT as an important source of income for Member States. Indeed Member States will have to ensure that they apply an effective average weighted VAT rate of at least 12%, which is the lowest applied today in some EU Member States, and the requirement of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15% will become a permanent requirement. Finally the proposed amendments to the VAT Directive as regards reduced rates will enter into force only when the definitive regime is effectively in place. To conclude, let me say that these proposals represent a win for both Member States’ revenues and European businesses. So it is our responsibility to act and therefore I call on Parliament to take the lead and show ambition for real reform of the VAT system.

name: Luděk Niedermayer
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, losses in tax collected have very serious consequences for our economy as well as for society. It is not just a shortage of government revenues; it distorts competition, sometimes it helps to finance illegal activities and, if losses are too high, it can push up the tax rates in other categories. That is why I am very happy that this area is one of the priority of EU and in last years, we made significant achievements. After focusing on income tax of large corporations and later on addressing the issue of anti-money laundering and transparency of ownership, now the Commission is coming with the action plan and the proposals included in the VAT package. It is very important because of VAT is one of the largest sources of government revenues and, as it was said, we are losing a lot of money. I am glad that an important part of the proposal is the simplification of tax compliance, especially for small and medium sized businesses. We need to collect taxes better just not more expensively. I call on the Finance Ministers to reach agreement on the package and to go forward really quickly. I believe that better collection of taxes should not be used for increasing the government revenues. I believe we do not need to spend more, we just need to spend better. In my view, money gained should be invested mainly in the reduction of public debt and the reduction of the most devastating taxes for the economic growth. This is the way how we will benefit the future of our citizens and the growth of the EU economy.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Madam President, Mr Vice-President, thank you for this package, as we say in European language. Of course, it will get attention when you help SMEs in the maze of taxation that sometimes overflows them. However, I would like to focus on the issue of reduced rates, because it is a politically extremely sensitive subject on which this European Parliament has often asked you. You make a proposal that puts us at the heart of our contradictions. Rather than debating and negotiating around an annex, you propose to give Member States more flexibility, with the risk of having a completely variable geometry depending on the Member States and thus an impact on a logic of the internal market which, in turn, will be called into question. This, however, addresses a number of concerns, including the issue of zero rates on a number of products or the alignment of paper book taxation with the digital book, which, from a cultural point of view, is a critical issue. I want, however, to draw your attention to two points. First of all, I would like to ask you how you identified this minimum rate of 12% VAT collection from the Member States. What is the current rate per Member State? Finally, I think that, from the point of view of the cross-border impact on a number of products, this flexibility left to the Member States will call us to put in place mechanisms to counter the effects of this competition that could take place in border areas.

name: Lieve Wierinck
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, I welcome the work of the Commission. As shadow rapporteur on CCTB and DAC6, fair taxes have been an important part of my work in recent months. It can no longer be that honest, hard-working entrepreneurs pay the price for a system that does not function properly. As the Commission has shown, we only lose EUR 50 billion in revenue every year in VAT. This is money that needs to be taken out of the illegal circuit and go to crucial infrastructure, health care and research. Goods, services and capital have long stopped at the borders of our Member States. A solution must therefore be cross-border and based on cooperation through the exchange of information, with the help of the relevant agencies, but also with the agencies. This is also an opportunity to simplify current systems and procedures and thus reduce the administrative burden on our companies. Such simplification would be a relief for our SMEs in particular. Finally, whether direct or indirect taxes, it is time for everyone to make their fair contribution. For me, the Commission's efforts are a step in the right direction.

name: Marisa Matias
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Madam President, Commissioner, it is true that tax revenues are very important for the Member States and it is true that there is a tax loss of millions of euros every year on VAT and that it could be spent on public services. All that is true, but with regard to this reform there are a number of problems: the first is what we are currently seeing from this trend of the European Commission acting mainly in a transfer of the collection of direct taxes to indirect taxes. It should be the exact opposite, because only direct taxes guarantee that there is real redistribution. The second problem has to do with this definition of minima. The definition of minimums does not eliminate the profound inequality that exists in taxation at European Union level, and therefore the taxation of capital income has not stopped falling in recent decades while it is so much on those who work. And then there is the fundamental problem, Commissioner, and with this I finish. Because it makes no sense to talk about minimums as long as there are privileged tax jurisdictions within the European Union, because that has a name: it is called tax theft.

name: Sven Giegold
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Vice-President, colleagues, thanks first of all to the Commission for this bold approach to VAT. This is very much needed. We know about the problems of fraud. We welcome in particular that you took the concerns of small and medium-sized businesses seriously. My colleague Molly Scott Cato has lobbied very hard for this and the Parliament did this, so this is really the right direction you are taking. But I have to say that we have concerns concerning the increasing number of exemptions which are possible under the new regime. You have now an umbrella for the exemptions but Member States can even add more products which are treated differently from one state to the other, and even if you have put limits to that, this is not the vision of a common market. In a common market, we should have common tax rates when it comes to indirect taxation.  So therefore, we call on colleagues, the Member States and the Commission not to forget about the dream of a common market where common rules determine our common sales and business area.

name: Jörg Meuthen
text: on behalf of the EFD Group. — Madam President. We are talking here today about Commission decisions on fair taxation. We shouldn't do that. The subject does not belong here at all. The EU is not responsible for this issue. She can't be. Member States should cooperate to combat VAT fraud. But we do not need the new competences for Eurofisc that the Commission has proposed. This is where a European tax office is being created at the Commission. Respise the principle of subsidiarity. Taxing fairly also means not letigging for tax competences. We do not need lower tax rates — not VAT or corporation tax limits. It is fair for each country to adopt its own tax laws. All alone. Without the intervention of the Commission. Here in Parliament and also in the Council, we will look closely at which colleague and which Finance Minister is easily prepared to abandon national sovereignty in tax terms.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President. The subject belongs here. If we remember that we have a VAT gap of EUR 170 billion alone, if we remember that cross-border tax fraud alone will cause European taxpayers to lose EUR 50 billion, and if we remember that we are a single internal market, and if we are going to work with TAXE-I, TAXE-II - and the PANA Committee think: yes, the subject belongs here. Of course, we also need a European VAT area. It is therefore right that we are stepping up cooperation between Member States and public authorities when tax fraudsters increasingly operate across borders. It is right that we are creating a uniform system of VAT rates. But we need to reduce the 250 exemptions in order to eliminate further inequalities. It is true that we are introducing a simplified regulation, especially for SMEs, if the complexity of the system slows down growth and employment. It is right that we are to create a new, better system if VAT is to be a growing source of public revenue for the European Union too, because we need to focus more on own resources for the future financing of the European Union. We are looking forward to working together. There are things to sharpen, but the approach is chosen correctly.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, as you said VAT fraud costs EU Member States more than EUR 50 billion in lost revenue each year and now, I think, finally we are taking this seriously. We have popped the hood of Europe's ailing VAT system and, let's be honest, it's a mess as must now be painfully obvious to anyone who has worked seriously with the issue of tax, VAT fraud and avoidance and evasion. National laws, schemes and regulations are not a deterrent to these abusers. On the contrary, they are enablers of them. The more rules and the more exemptions, the easier it becomes to find loopholes. In the EU we still maintain no less than 28 different national VAT regimes, all with different rates and exemptions.  I'm happy to say that we the fair tax package proposed by the Commission we are finally taking action to plug the gaps of Europe's leaking coin coffers, to deny those who would cheat and swindle their way out of their fair contribution to society and, at the same time, making life just a little bit easier for the vast majority of companies who pay their fair taxes and their fair VAT.  Finally, we will set up a system that returns control over individual VAT rates to Member States’ own discretion by doing so in a way that will not distort competition and that will not allow for a race to the bottom. I look forward to our continuing work on these important files and to ensure a VAT system that is fit for the 21st century.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, we welcome the proposal to strengthen the unified VAT regime so that VAT is paid in the country where the goods or services are consumed and at the rate applicable in that country. This is essential to tackle the high current levels of VAT fraud. We welcome any simplification of rules related to cross—border transactions that will aid businesses, especially SMEs, to operate in the internal market. Personally, I am also delighted that the Commission is inviting all EU Member States to follow the UK practice of exempting the smallest businesses from VAT altogether, something I have been campaigning for for some time.  My worry is that the Council will try to block these reforms. It would represent a defeat for businesses and for tax cooperation in the EU if Member States are not able to trust each other and accept that one country can collect and send VAT revenues on behalf of another. The temporary VAT regime has been in place for 25 years now, and it is time we worked together to replace it with something that works better for citizens as well as businesses.

name: Arndt Kohn (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner. I would like to mention two aspects of the reform package for fairer VAT in the EU. Point 1: The fight against fraud and cooperation between national and international authorities must provide effective and rapid opportunities for the exchange of information — both technical and legal. Now, however, point 2: With regard to VAT rates, the confusing list of goods to be taxed should be removed. Instead, Member States should be able to choose from a colourful range of VAT rates: flexibility. A tax rate of 0%, a tax rate of between 0 and 5%, two rates between 5 and the standard tax rate of at least 15%, all at a weighted average of at least 12%. Do you know what that sounds like? That sounds like a mess. If this remains the case, it will entail considerable expenditure for accounting, tax advice and financial management. This involves an increased risk of error and fraud. That's exactly what we wanted to avoid.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, it is obvious that measures must be taken to combat fraud around the system of operation of value added tax. At the same time, the main problem in the European Union is the tax dumping applied in practice, as there are countries with very low and others with too high VAT. In Greece, Mr. Dombrovskis, increased VAT is applied because that is what the troika has imposed. A final example is the imposition of increased VAT on the Aegean islands, where there is competition on the part of Turkey with very low VAT. The inhabitants of the Aegean islands are protesting, small and medium-sized enterprises are protesting, and you should see this. It is not possible to have the increase in VAT on the Aegean islands: this process really leads to economic disaster. At the same time, we must have zero or too low VAT on basic necessities, foodstuffs and public utilities.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: — Madam President, harmonising the minimum corporate tax rate and VAT, more strenching and combating tax havens and implementing the OECD protocol to avoid relocation of tax profits — known as BEPS— are the prescriptions experts advocate for improving EU taxation. Competing to attract taxpayers nobody wins. We all lose capacity to finance public policies, and those cuts affect our social model too often. The European federalists also want a European Ministry of Finance and a European Treasury. There are models that quite reasonably regulate the relationship between central haciendas and the associated autonomous farms, such as the one we use in the Basque Country and Navarra with the concert and convention systems. These systems, in addition to determining contributions based on the powers each exercised, promote responsibility, are an anti-deficit tool, prevent corruption and are a stimulus to create policies to promote the real economy, as this House has repeatedly acknowledged.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank you for this debate, which shows the high interest and need for a deep reform of our VAT system. As I mentioned in my introduction, since the first package of reforms in 2016 the Commission has gradually adopted proposals that would allow a fundamental reform of the VAT system in the EU. But there is no time to rest on our laurels; we still have a long way to go.  First of all on the Commission’s side. Before this summer the Commission will come forward with two legislative proposals: one introducing changes in the VAT Directive, which will contain detailed arrangements putting into practice the cornerstone of the definitive regime adopted in October 2017, while the second one will address the issue of VAT fraud in online sales. Secondly on Parliament’s and Member States’ side. The debate is now in your hands. At the highest political level we need an ambition to deliver the real reform of our VAT system, to create a level playing field for EU companies, to support SMEs so that they can grow and benefit from the opportunities of the single market, and to put an end to cross—border fraud which steals public revenues and finances criminal organisations or possibly even terrorist activities. On VAT reduced rates; we are proposing to give more freedom to Member States in a framed manner, so I will come back to some of the concerns which were raised in this regard. Indeed it is very important that this does not lead to revenue erosion or distortion of competition. That is why we have put safeguards in place in terms of the minimum effective VAT rate, in terms of negative lists which mainly concern high value, easily portable goods, which are the ones probably most prone to being moved across borders, and this proposal would only come into force once a definitive VAT system will be in place. We are, of course, are ready to discuss with co—legislators whether those safeguards are sufficient and what is the best way to address potential risks of revenue erosion. Now as regards the broader issue, I think we share the need to reform the current VAT system in the interest of Member States, of EU businesses – mainly SMEs – and of European citizens. So with your support we are confident that progress can be achieved in the coming months.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate has ended. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the fact that the European Commission has finally put on the legislator's table a package that would completely reform EU VAT rules in a coherent system. It is high time we put an end to the possibility of VAT fraud. Currently, there are 28 types of tax systems in Europe, with different rules and loopholes. The payment of VAT resulting from the free movement of goods and services in the common market and the lack of transparency of the rules is a huge problem, in particular due to the lack of cooperation between Member States. In EU Member States, unpaid VAT amounts to around €150 billion a year, i.e. more than the EU's total annual budget is missing from the budget of the Member States. Moreover, EUR 50 billion of this is linked to VAT fraud, such as the cross-border circular VAT fraud known in Hungary. The system proposed by the Commission reverses the rules on VAT payment and refunding. If the EU accepts the proposal, cross-border VAT payment and recovery will also have to be treated as if they were within borders. The difference would be accounted for by the Member States, thus simplifying the administration. This requires much greater cooperation between Member States. There is no doubt that the system will gain Parliament's support. We are also calling on the Council to adopt the draft as soon as possible, saving serious billions of budgets.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Commission is proposing an EU-wide reform of VAT rates and VAT collection. Due to inefficient tax collection, uncoordinated cooperation between Member States and fragmented VAT rules, the VAT gap between expected revenues and VAT revenues in the EU is estimated to be €150 billion per year. Cross-border fraud costs Member States €50 billion per year. The Commission therefore intends to reform the current VAT system to create a fairer and more efficient tax system in the European Union. An important element of the VAT package is an EU system for simplified VAT compliance. Tax compliance costs for cross-border European SMEs are 11% higher than for SMEs exclusively engaged in domestic activities. The Commission's proposals would reduce compliance costs by 18% through simplified registration, invoicing and accounting rules for SMEs with a turnover of less than €2 million per year. We need to ensure that the EU continues to work towards better cooperation between European tax authorities and reduces compliance costs for European companies without opening the door to European VAT. Greater flexibility for Member States in reducing VAT rates for certain goods and services is linked to further harmonisation.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report by Julie Girling, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2003/87/EC to cost-effective emissions reductions and to promote low-carbon investment (COM (2015) 0337 - C8-0190/2015 - 2015/0148 (COD)) (A8-0003/2017).

name: Julie Girling
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and all of his team, some of whom are with us here today. I would like to thank the Council and their hardworking team and, of course, all my wonderful hardworking colleagues here in Parliament. Nothing is ever perfect, and the emission trading system (ETS) is certainly no exception to that, but it remains the cornerstone of our EU policy to combat climate change and we have done our best to agree an ambitious update. The ETS has had a chequered history. There have been many detractors over the years. We tackled many problems – from a carbon price that was clearly too low to make the market function to the extremely difficult issue of striking the balance between our environmental ambition and the protection of energy-intensive European industry. This is always open, and we are always discussing it, but it remains a system operating in 31 countries. The rest of the world has sometimes been disappointingly slow to catch up, but now we have some momentum going. We have the recent agreement with Switzerland, we have President Trump to thank for the call to action in the United States, which has meant some ambitious plans in California and their tie—up with Ontario, and indeed even movement in China, where I know the Commission has been very active in terms of helping with their own putative system. So we are making this agreement in the context of a world that is moving forward. It would be nice, actually, to be criticised at some point for not being the best system in the world, so we look forward to that in the near future hopefully. However, the background to this update is challenging. We must have a system that can deliver the EU’s Paris commitments, but sometimes reality is at odds with this. We were working against the background of the 2014 Council conclusions, which was not always helpful. There are challenging internal politics around the relationship between the EU 15 and more recent accession states, with a lively discussion on the absolute amounts and on the conditions that would be appropriate to impose in providing the flow of funds to assist these Member States. We also had the difficult issue of indirect cost compensation, warmly embraced by some Member States and not by others, leading to a fundamental question as to whether, if some Member State governments are prepared to support their industry financially and others are not, EU funds should be used to iron out the differences. We await further developments on state aid rules to illuminate this question. I welcome the compromise that we reached on this, but we did not settle the matter. The discussions will continue. I do not intend to list all the final conclusions of the deal, just a couple that are highlights for me. The 2023 review – in line with the global stock-take of the Paris Agreement – will include a possible increase in the 2.2% linear reduction factor. This is a major achievement. Secondly, there is the substantial withdrawal of excess allowances from the system. And, thirdly, what is called the ‘Duncan mechanism’ in tribute to the rapporteur who preceded me – I think we should now call it the ‘Lord Duncan mechanism’ – comes in if the cross-sector correction factor is applied. If it is not needed, then additional funds go to the Innovation Fund and the Modernisation Fund. We have changes to benchmarks and carbon leakage lists, offering a fine balance between carbon leakage protection and ambition. These are just a few points. There is a clear stamp of the European Parliament on this agreement – new thinking and new mechanisms which have been taken on board – and I thank my colleagues for this. But sometimes what defines the role of rapporteur is the most frequently asked question: what did you want that you didn’t achieve? Well, for me, there are two clear things here: the important issue of environment performance standards – we did our best, we made advances but we didn’t get the specific, clear numerical limit we wanted – and the issue of shipping. We got our recital on the International Maritime Organisation (IMO), but we wanted more. I think Parliament has made a very clear statement that this is not good enough. We pass this baton on to others in other pieces of legislation, but I hope they will recognise the job that we did.

name: Fredrick Federley
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. — Madam President, We've got to the end of the way and we're now really just going to club through the decision which in some parts was very complicated but in other parts been considerably easier. I think we have done as much as we have been able in the various institutions, but also here in the various committees of the European Parliament. I think for the next round that we will soon start charging for will take with us partly the mid-term review, but also that in 10 years we should have a new regulatory framework in place. So I think we have to take a note in the European Parliament about how much we are going to continue to water down this system, which we have done in several ways. What the money and values this market creates is actually supposed to be used for, I think is a base question. The second is how many more funds can we look to create to do things that perhaps not at all the ETS system is really meant for. I think we need to ask ourselves a question that will be hard, difficult and painful in here: how long are we going to continue to make exceptions for certain Member States, and how long should some Member States be considered new? After how many decades are all Member States equal and treated equally before our laws?

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am glad we are meeting tonight to finalise the adoption of the revised European Union Emission Trading System (ETS) Directive, creating a solid framework for the European carbon market for the next decade. The European Union ETS remains the most important instrument to realise our ambition of a reduction of at least 40% in greenhouse gas emissions within the European Union by 2030. With the political agreement reached in early November last year, we can proudly show to our citizens and to the world that the European Union is delivering and turning political words into legal commitments. The trilogue agreement on this proposal is the result of a long, complex and thorough negotiation process that necessarily involved compromises from all sides. The support and active engagement of the rapporteur, Ms Girling, and also of the shadow rapporteurs, Mr Belet, Ms Guteland, Mr Gerbrandy, Ms Konečná, Mr Eickhout, Ms Evi and Ms D’Ornano, was crucial in this regard. I would like wholeheartedly to thank Ms Girling for her skillful work on this challenging file and congratulate her on the result. Only the constructive spirit of the negotiators of both institutions made it possible to reach a solid compromise and I am happy that the Commission could facilitate this trilogue agreement as an ‘honest broker’. As I said, the agreement required compromise from all parties involved. It strikes a proper balance between strengthening the European Union carbon market and incentivising industry to decarbonise with innovative solutions and renewable energy, while being mindful of the specific challenges of lower-income Member States, in particular regarding the modernisation of their energy systems. The European Union ETS is a great example of a forward-looking regulation where European legislation enables innovation and modernisation of our energy system. The European Parliament has greatly contributed to the final shape of the trilogue outcome. Each side of the triangle of issues at the core of the discussion clearly carries the European Parliament’s signature. The political impetus for strengthening the European Union ETS originated in the European Parliament. The temporary doubling of the feeding rate for the Market Stability Reserve and the limitation set for the validity of allowances in the reserve will ensure that market balance will be restored swiftly and that the carbon price creates incentives for long-term low-carbon investments. Regarding the free allocation to avoid carbon leakage, a free allocation buffer of around 450 million allowances was created, at Parliament’s request, to avoid a cross-sectoral correction factor. This provides European industry with certainty in terms of free allocation and a reliable planning horizon. And finally, because of the European Parliament’s insistence, the modernisation provisions will also enable activities fostering a just transition of labour on the way towards a low-carbon economy; and, as an additional safeguard for investments, no support from the Modernisation Fund will be granted to coal-related energy generation, with the exception of district heating in Bulgaria and Romania. I could continue this list, referring to other issues such as a larger Innovation Fund, but I think that, together, we can be proud of the result of our joint effort to agree on an improved and robust architecture for the renewed European Union ETS. I invite you to lend your support to the political agreement in tomorrow’s vote to ensure that the legislation enters swiftly into force and the necessary changes are in place by January 2021. There is no time to lose in the European transition to a low-carbon economy. This is what we have promised to our citizens. This is what they expect from all of us.

name: Florent Marcellesi
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. — Madam President, energy transition is also a matter of justice and distribution between the countries of the North and the countries of the South. And it is a shame that this rather weak report did not take it much into account. In line with the Paris Agreement, the European Union could have turned its emissions trading regime into a powerful instrument for climate and solidarity. Some ideas for the future: that half of the auction revenue be allocated to climate control in vulnerable countries; that the aviation sector contributes to the 2030 climate target at the same level as other sectors and that those revenues go to climate control in vulnerable countries; that maritime transport will contribute based on emissions generated in, to or from European ports; limit the zero emission factor of biomass to waste and waste in order to avoid land grabbing and deforestation in the South. The energy transition in Europe cannot be done at the expense of others, but in solidarity with others.

name: Ivo Belet
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (NL) Mr President, one and a half years of hard work and negotiation, and then one and a half minutes of speaking time: it remains a challenge of course. The reformed ETS is undoubtedly one of the absolute pillars of European climate policy. Contrary to what the previous speaker said, we can say that the interventions are ambitious, but that they are also realistic and feasible. The aim of the ETS is to provide incentives for companies and also the energy sector to produce and consume energy in a sustainable way while avoiding carbon leakage. We all know what carbon leakage is. Mr Eickhout, there is no point in taking measures to allow companies to move to other regions where there are no measures, as we do. That's totally pointless. Thirdly, we are counting on the innovation fund to be rapidly deployed in the current period to support the transition. Indeed, as the Commissioner said, we are very pleased that financial support for the innovation fund has been increased under the impetus of Parliament. In conclusion, let me warmly thank and congratulate my colleague Julie Girling and her team for the excellent job they have done in a sometimes challenging context. Let me also thank you, Commissioner, and your team, the cabinet and administration, for the tremendous work that you have done.

name: Jytte Guteland
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President! Where thing has its time and I am one of those who has been fawned and really been tough in the negotiations to make this be a sharper climate legislation, but today I thought to be happy. I think it is important for new faiths ahead in climate legislation that we also celebrate when we have tightened legislation and put a better one in line with the Paris Agreement. These have been long and tough negotiations, and it is clear that the views on climate are thudged, both in the European Parliament and in EU member countries. On one side are the progressives who see the possibilities and who want to do more to solve the climate threat. On the other side, we have the Conservatives who want to continue to tuck their heads in the sand and are happy to hug old fossil fuels and maintain emissions reform. We Social Democrats and the S&D Group have been driving in the negotiations. By scrapping up to 2 billion allowances, we are running out of current inflation in the system and we make it more expensive to emit; that's a good thing. For us, it has also been important to make the transition into a climate-smarter society in a more equitable and socially sustainable way. Everyone should follow along, and especially in regions where the conversion is difficult because of major challenges to leave the fossil, it is important that there is support for workers so that you can join the conversion. I am also pleased that the rules clearly signal that all sectors must contribute. No one should go stingy on other people's improvements. Climate work concerns all of us. And sure — I would have liked to see an even tighter better regulatory framework, but we have tightened the system, we make sure that Europe takes responsibility in this legislation, and that gives us strength to be enshrined even more in future legislation.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Protecting climate and jobs was the high stakes in the reform of the emissions trading system. The functioning of the European carbon market must be better and more efficient in order to further stimulate climate-friendly investment. At the same time, we must avoid companies leaving Europe to third countries where climate rules are less strict, because then we lose twice: we lose jobs and we do nothing for the climate. The European Union is leading the world in the fight against climate change. We're not allowed to turn winners into losers. The agreement is certainly a step forward in this respect compared to the original Commission proposal, but for us protection against carbon leakage could have gone even further. Finally, the strong focus on innovation is particularly welcome. A low-carbon Europe can be achieved not only through a workable system of emission allowances, but also by clearly deploying innovative solutions to the climate problem both inside and outside Europe.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking Julie Girling for the excellent job she has done as our rapporteur, especially jumping in late when Ian Duncan had to step down. She might not yet deserve the title of Baroness but the mechanism should certainly be named after Julie Girling instead of Ian Duncan. Today’s result: what shall we make of it? Well, only the future will tell us whether what we have been doing has been sufficient. We do know that the price of carbon credits has gone up by about 20% so far, so it might be successful. Surplus of allowances, we tackled that. I think the coal phase-out in Germany, the Netherlands and Italy is easier to achieve now. The Innovation Fund has been increased, which is important; and I think one of the major improvements that Parliament has made is that the Modernisation Fund is not applicable to coal-fired investments. That is very successful. But there are two elements I would like to stress. First of all, carbon leakage. We are still handing out 95% of all allowances for free to industry, even for sectors that have no real trade or carbon intensity. That is still something that is not too good. And lastly, we continue referring to conclusions from the European Council from 2014. That is like in the Renaissance looking back to the Middle Ages! Let us please stop referring to those pre, pre, pre-Paris conclusions from Council – and that applies to both the Commission and the Council. Let’s move forward! Paris is beyond 2014.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, let me also join the crowd of all who want to thank Julia Girling, who took up this document de facto in the middle , as already said, and led him to a successful end, in my opinion, because after years of hard work, we are presenting to you today a reform of the emission allowance trading system. Despite the very difficult negotiations, I believe that the text presented balances satisfactorily both the issue of climate protection and the implementation of the Paris Agreement, as well as the protection of European industry and by guaranteed jobs. The document received probably won't fully satisfy any camp. On the one hand, we have a number of great measures that will lead to an increase in the price of the allowance. On the other hand, a measure protecting any increase in industrial production in the EU or exemptions for the protection of our steel sector. Yes, I can still see a number of non-add-ons that we couldn't remove for various reasons. Such as the outstanding issue of protecting European industry from imports of raw materials and products from states that do not share our position on combating climate change, such as carbon adjustment mechanism. It would be good for the next few years the European Commission to finally resolve this issue once and for all, having failed to do so here. Especially taking into account the threat of our strong industry with cheap imports from China. I've talked about it on this soil many times. Before the completion of this work, a so-called winter energy package flew into the whole process, but some institutes and tools from the previous only completed package greatly disrupts. I cannot forgive myself for the Commission's appeal: Please do these things in such a way that they come together.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all I too would like to thank Julie Girling, who stepped in later in the process and did a great job in delivering this result. I know you probably are not happy back home, Ms Girling, but the Greens too are thanking you. That doesn’t help you at home, but still the thanks are there, and we as Greens can also support the reform because it’s an improvement on what we have. Though let’s be honest: it is not very difficult to get an improvement on what we have, right? And that is really still the problem. Finally we are doing something on the surplus of allowances, and getting rid of that surplus to a certain extent, but we’re not there yet. This system is still not functioning right. The prices are now around EUR 10, whereas we know that, for Paris implementation, prices need to be around EUR 40 or 50, and we know that the emission trading system alone will not deliver that. So this is a good basis we have developed, we can support the improvement, but now it’s time for Member States to take national action and implement additional, national, policies because this alone will not deliver Paris, and you all know that.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we for our part have always often expressed various doubts about a market-based system for addressing climate policies and the climate issue. We fail to see ETS as the mainstay of EU climate policies. We cannot see it because it has not been in the past and unfortunately I fear it will not be in the future either, despite all the many attempts to strengthen this instrument. Obviously I strongly hope that I am wrong. I personally have wondered several times whether we are trying to protect the climate or are trying to build a very complicated mechanism of financial engineering and speculation, if we are trying to reduce real-world emissions or we are only doing calculations based on virtual numbers and projections, if we are seriously applying the polluter pays principle, or we want to flip it — In order to continue polluting, it is enough to pay for an obolo — and finally, if we are really trying to push towards the industrial energy transformation of Europe, so that it is really sustainable and competitive, or we are attempting to keep the fossil-related model up.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Tomorrow will hopefully be a very good day for climate protection in Europe and worldwide. I believe that we will adopt a reform which will lead to the ETS finally fulfilling its purpose. Anyone investing in climate-friendly technologies will be rewarded. Anyone who wants to keep old slingers will be punished. According to experts, the price will rise to well over 30 euros in just a few years' time — for example in four or five years — and will be well above 20 euros on average for the next period. We will then see investments that we have unfortunately not seen before. But in order to ensure that these investments actually happen in Europe and that we do not distribute the energy-intensive industry that is in international competition from Europe, it was important for us as the EPP to supply free certificates for those who are at the cutting edge of technology. So only those who are already on the cutting edge of technology or invested accordingly will be supplied free of charge — the others will have to pay. We are also helping industry through the Innovation Fund, and we are helping Central and Eastern Europe through the modernisation fund. I think that's a very good thing overall. We protect jobs, we create innovation and we help the climate. That is why I would also like to thank Julie Girling, the shadow rapporteurs, especially Ivo Belet for the European People's Party, and the Commissioner and his team. I believe that this is a good piece of legislation, and I would ask everyone to agree tomorrow.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, I am afraid that once again we will be reacting to history, because the text proposed to us is a bland text. It is bland because, throughout the discussions, one for national interests, the other for sectoral interests or others for both at the same time, arrive at these results. You know that I am defending the carbon adjustment at the borders, but you yourself have always opposed it because you said — you always say — that it is a protectionist measure. Protectionist, yes: protectionist of climate, environment, jobs. I therefore plead for carbon adjustment at borders. Moreover, many third countries, including China, have understood this very well and are investing heavily to decarbonize their industry and economy. Imagine the ridicule of the thing if tomorrow, in five years, in ten years, imported products are less carbon than ours. We will look silly, don't you think, Commissioner? That is why we lack ambition and here we have missed the history. And you know, me, bland soups, I don't like eating them.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Madam President! In European energy policy, a balanced and realistic treatment of environmental ambitions and the associated costs arising from technical constraints is essential. Unfortunately, the compromise on the EU ECJ does not take these assumptions into account. While it guarantees Poland the opportunity to use unused allowances from the period 2013-2020 and increases the number of allowances in the framework of the compensation mechanism, and, importantly and for which I thank you, takes into account the specifics of heat production for municipal needs by continuing free allocation of allowances for this sector on a favourable basis. At the same time, unfortunately, it reduces the possibility of financing under compensatory mechanisms for fossil fuel-based investments, even those that are economically efficient and have extremely low emissivity. For this reason, I will not be able to support this report entirely.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Madam President! On television and in this era, one remembers only what was two weeks ago, not before, but I was raised without television. I went to college when there wasn't TV yet, which is why I remember a great time when hundreds of thousands of young people were going to save the Earth, when professors were charting, proving that the Earth was in danger of catastrophe, that threatened the Earth with a monstrous global cold. All of this was proven exactly the same as it is now being proven by other nutjobs to threaten the Earth with total overheating. Well, thankfully, there was no European Union, that is, a bunch of people who are willing to waste trillions, just to show that something is being done just that. That's why no one went to sit, while you guys are going to sit for wasting people's money on meaningless actions. And besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, Dear Mrs Girling, thank you, because we have been waiting for this reform of the carbon market for a long time. I would also like to thank my colleagues in the PPE Group, because we have worked hard with Ivo Belet and Esther de Lange to finalise our position on such a complex subject. Because when we introduced the OTS system, it was thought that the price would be 30 euros per ton. We are far from this since this price ranges between 6 and 9 euros due to a surplus of quotas on the market. This, of course, prevents the acceleration of low-carbon investments and the change in the annual allowance reduction from 1.7% to 2.2%, which can be revised in 2024, will help to halt this surplus. Thanks to this reform, quotas will be distributed more fairly, to be in line with real emissions from industrial sites and this will allow the creation of the Fund for the Modernization of our Electricity Sectors and to mobilise in an innovation fund the equivalent of more than 400 million quotas for innovation in Europe. It's fundamental. Thus, we respect our commitments following the Paris Agreement, but at the same time we are defending our industrial sectors that are facing difficult international competition. Our industry is efficient, it must implement very high standards. We must accompany it to keep it competitive because, what is essential is to reconcile a real industrial strategy with active climate diplomacy.

name: Puhemies. –
text: I still need to address the previous speech. Representative Korwin-Mikke, You said that everyone who is in the process of making this decision will go to jail, and this is perhaps something that you in this chamber would not be able to say.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with the adoption of the reform of the ETS, the European Union reaffirms its commitment signed with the Paris Agreement and I would also like to thank the rapporteur Girling for her job done. This is an important directive, where we managed to combine the climate policy target of reducing CO2 emissions by 40% by 2030 with the competitiveness of the manufacturing sector and the push for its further innovation with the ad hoc fund. Important, from this point of view, to have updated the rules to define which industrial sectors are most exposed to the phenomenon of so-called carbon leakage, in order to grasp the real level of exposure to commercial competition from countries that do not apply our levels of environmental protection. Progress was then made on the issue of indirect cost compensation. I would have hoped for the creation of a clearing mechanism at European level, as requested by Parliament, but I still believe the commitment made by the Commission to carry out an assessment of the carbon market, which also serves to understand how much the mechanism is working, and in 2024, if deemed appropriate, put forward legislative proposals that go towards a European mechanism.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: A great deal has already been said in this debate. On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would of course like to congratulate Julie Girling and Both in the Committee on the Environment and in the Committee on Industry and the Committee on Industry, we naturally wanted ambition on the one hand — because, yes, the system had to be adjusted — but also realism, so that our industry, our innovation and our jobs do not leave elsewhere. That does not help the climate — since we are often the cleanest producers in the world — nor employment. Of course, you must continue to encourage the industry to innovate. But you have to help them with that, instead of teasing them out of here. I am therefore very pleased with the strengthening of the innovation fund so that developments, such as carbon capture and storage, can hopefully take place in the port of Rotterdam. The same applies to carbon capture and re-use, the plan to transport CO2 from the chemical cluster in Geleen to the greenhouses in North Limburg, which can again be used as raw materials. I believe that these are the projects we need in Europe. The smart solutions that deliver innovation, but also keep European hands at work.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Thank you for preparing the EU ETS reform. In this room, we differ every bit in our assessment of this reform, but we are no different in one: we all thank your abuser. I would like to join all the shadow rapporteurs, as well as those who were on the ITRE committee, because this committee had a certain task to do, namely to defend our reindustrialisation, to defend the industry, steel producers, cement, paper, fertilizer producers. I think it worked out. It's very important. Please note that often in the fight for climate or environmental protection, energy poverty threatens us, and this is very much associated with the problem of heating in many regions that move away from coal gradually, step by step. Therefore, the preservation in the modernisation fund, and partly also innovative, of the ability to treat the heating sector in a special way, is that we have a chance to protect people who could suffer from a lack of energy supply. That's also the advantage of the system we're putting in place.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am not very happy. I must say that I would like to thank the Members of Parliament first and foremost, starting with rapporteur Girling to Ivo Belet, Esther de Lange and everyone else. We had done a good job for a year and a half, but to truly have that balance that serves between climate and environmental policy and protecting the competitiveness of our industries and the Preservation of jobs is missing one chapter, that of indirect cost compensation, which remained at the status quo. Parliament had put up something better and more.
