He was unbridled in the negotiation of the resistance of the Member States, incomprehensible, because it causes, even according to Italian antitrust, real decompensation and imbalance within the single market. The increase in electricity costs derived from ETS becomes, for some countries such as Italy, which already pays electricity 30% more than the European average, an unsustainable thing. So I ask, Commissioner, not to wait until 2024 to open this chapter and that it is a chapter of social justice and fairness. We talked about it, Europe cannot be mother and stepmother.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: - Madam President! We had very different assessments early on when the debate over this reform began. I would like to note that, firstly, we have achieved an important target that will allow European companies not to be exposed to runaway emissions and continue to be protected. Secondly, that instruments have been introduced that will allow the energy sector in countries that need transformation — such as Poland — to get funds from the system to cover some of the costs of the necessary transformation. Thirdly, the district heating sector received support and exceptional treatment, which in countries such as Poland is crucial for reducing not only CO2 emissions, but also emissions of pollutants such as sulfur oxides, nitrogen, dust and in general the whole phenomenon of smog, which is associated with low emission. I also want to emphasise that it is a shame that district heating has not been entirely on the list of priority projects of the modernisation fund. It seems to me that the assessment of this regulation will undoubtedly bring additional assessments, but what it has been done here is also the common merit of the rapporteurs as well as all those involved in the debate.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think it is wonderful to behold the amount of MEPs from across the political floor who are working so hard so that we can put policies in place to meet our commitments on the Paris Agreement. Last month we had the clean energy package, energy efficiency and renewable energy, and tonight the ETS. I think that wonderful work has been done here. It is a very difficult file and I would like to thank everybody involved in moving towards the Innovation Fund, carbon capture and storage, limiting especially carbon leakage.  One area where I would especially like to thank my colleague, Esther de Lange, is where I badgered her about Prodcom, which was very important for the agri—food sector in Ireland. As a result of the work by Esther, Ivo and others, it saves them about EUR 40 million because the original proposal was so impractical. So that shows you the hard work that goes on behind the scenes and I think everybody can take a bow.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030 is a fundamental goal for ensuring the sustainability of the planet, air quality, but also to give a new incentive to the modernisation of the European economy. I welcome the work that has been done and which has made an important contribution in terms of flexibility in the management of licences to improve market transparency and rationality. An effort has also been made, even if not fully successful, to reduce the distortions of competition caused by different national indirect cost policies. Simplification factors have been introduced and two major funds have been set up to support the transition of industries, fostering innovation and modernisation, protecting jobs and competitiveness. We are therefore not dealing with the best but a reasonable proposal. Effectiveness and monitoring are needed if the decarbonisation and innovation objectives are fully met.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the European Union is trying to meet the Paris commitments to protect the environment, and it has entrusted this above all to a carbon trading system, the ETS system, which is essentially based on the market itself. I would say that it is not an effective system and that it often leads to speculation while at the same time some unlikely situations are created. To explain what I mean, Bulgaria and Poland have been exempted from the gas emission rights market and there is no such exception for Greece, resulting in Greek PPC losing EUR 400 million a year. At the same time, in the region around Greece, the industries in Turkey, Bulgaria, Skopje, Albania operate as they are and are not bound by any restrictions. The system is therefore absurd and an exception should have been given to Greece in order for PPC to operate as its Bulgarian counterpart, with the exception. Thank you very much.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. We are really doing a lot at EU level at the moment when it comes to protecting the climate, saving energy, dealing with it more efficiently, so on the whole one could say: to maintain and contribute to our creation. This is a pretty strong challenge because we want to be ambitious on the one hand. Paris has been mentioned, COP21, 22 and 23 we have also had COP21, 22 and 23. We want to protect the climate. We do not want it alone, however, we want to do this worldwide as possible, and of course we also want to see that we apply the polluter pays principle and say that those who damage the climate must also compensate and pay for it accordingly. That's perfectly correct. However, we must also take into account that we do not want to jeopardise jobs, that we also want to remain competitive and that we want to have a balanced instrument as possible. ETS is a market economy instrument that works well. I believe that this compromise we found at the negotiation — Julie Girling, heartfelt thanks— is really good. Because if no one is 100% satisfied — I get the impression — it's always quite good. So I think we can live well with that, we can build on that well, we can be proud of that.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: — Madam President, there is a starting problem in the approach to the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, which is the option and the insistence on a market approach that has clearly revealed not only its ineffectiveness, but also its perversity. From the initial clamorous failure, some good souls thought that by putting some patches in the system, it would finally lead us to the proclaimed goals. - in vain. The creation of a license trade to pollute laid the foundations of yet another millionaire scheme of fictitious financial asset generation, who knows if another speculative bubble ready to be inflated. It has done nothing, nor does it, for the desired reduction in greenhouse gases, especially if we want it to be achieved within a framework of social justice and economic sustainability. What would be a mirrific incentive to adopt low-carbon technologies has become the biggest disincentive. Leaving environmental objectives in the hands of the market, which could and should be remembered in other ways, will be useful for some, undoubtedly, but harmful to the environment and to the people.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all of you for your constructive work throughout the intensive co—decision process and for your interventions in this debate. As I have said before, we can be proud of the result of our joint efforts and I count on your support in tomorrow’s vote. The European Union Emissions Trading System (ETS) is a key instrument of our climate policy and we all managed to agree on a solid and robust framework for the next decade to ensure that we meet our ambitious emissions reduction target, while preserving the competitiveness of our industry and fostering low-carbon innovation and modernisation.  Internationally, many are looking at us and our European Union ETS as a model to develop similar forward-looking climate policies, and by putting in place the necessary legislation to renew and strengthen the European Union ETS, the European Union confirms its determination to lead the way in the fight against climate change and honouring our commitments under the Paris Agreement.  Let me make a final comment because there have been some interventions relating to the need for a centralised fund for indirect cost compensation. I know that this was a particularly difficult chapter in the negotiations, with almost irreconcilable views on issues such as a fully harmonised system. Indirect cost compensation will be continued in the form of state—aid schemes. We will not, however, see a mere continuation of the past. The continued use of a state—aid scheme is accompanied by substantially enhanced and timely transparency in reporting requirements.  Every Member State providing state aid will, as soon as the legislation is in force, have to publish, within three months of the end of a calendar year, the actual amount of compensation paid out in total and the benefiting sector, and this is a substantial improvement. The enhanced reporting that has been agreed will already start this year, and as part of future reviews the ETS Directive clearly foresees that the Commission should also consider whether measures in relation to indirect cost compensation should be further harmonised. I hope that all of you will support this ETS new system because we have made a big effort to seek compromise. Our rapporteur did excellent work, as did all the shadow rapporteurs, and in this spirit of compromise we have improved the system that, as some of you said, has not worked perfectly in the past, but really this time I think we are going in the right direction and I hope it delivers as much as we expect from the work we have done.

name: Julie Girling
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank everybody who spoke. It is very kind of you all – well, most of you – to speak highly of the work that we have done, but let us remember that it was a joint effort. When you are listening to a debate like this, it is easy to get hung up on all the detail, all the things that we could have done, or should have done, a little bit better, or the bits we left out and the Member States for whom it does not quite fit. So we have to bring ourselves back to basics and remember that the cap-and-trade system gives us the opportunity for an increased carbon price, which creates the incentive for industry to invest. It also creates a huge amount of money for Member States to invest in their own industry around the whole issue of decarbonising technology. I think we need to call on all those Member States, as we conclude these negotiations and put this into law. We need to call on all of those Member States to remember that this does not constitute drawing a line which they do not have to pass. They can see this as just the start of the efforts they make towards achieving our Paris commitments. There is so much that they could do, and here we really need to hold their feet to the fire, to make sure they take advantage of the flexibilities that we have given them, and that we have built in, in order to achieve and invest wisely for the future. As all of you know, this will probably be the last thing for which I take responsibility as a rapporteur, but I can assure you that I will be going back to my Member State and trying, firstly, to sort out what we are going to do when we are not part of this ETS system. Whatever comes of that, I hope it will complement it well, that my own Member State will continue to be an exemplar in terms of carbon-reduction investment and that we will be able to continue to work together in the happy spirit that we have done.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate has ended. The vote will take place on Tuesday 6 February 2018.

name: Puhemies.
text: — The next item is the report by Mr Buzek, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on speeding up clean energy innovation (2017/2084 (INI)) (A8-0005/2018)

name: Jerzy Buzek
text: rapporteur. — Madam President! We continue to debate energy issues. Energy is known to be the most important issue for the economy. It's hard to function with an uncharged phone, a car without petrol, cold radiators or non-working apparatus in factories, offices or hospitals. We want to have security of supply — that is the basis of our operation. We want to burden the environment as little as possible — it's about climate, but it's also about eliminating phenomena like smog. And finally, we want prices for energy not to be too high — we want to keep the industry competitive. We have a clean energy package on occasion and the very name of this package tells you what energy, what energy future and what transformation in the European Union is about. If we take all this together, then we can basically cope in the long run just by the fact that we're going to invest in new energy technologies. This is a fundamental matter for our future and the future of energy transformation. For sure, we want to free up public investment, private resources, as well as citizen activity in assisting our efforts towards new energy solutions. It is also about the technological neutrality that was guaranteed in the Paris Agreement. Three points seem most important to me in terms of investing in new technologies in the European Union. First of all, simplification of EU programmes and funds. Let's talk about this for a long time, but if we really want to benefit in the long run from funding for new energy technologies, we must necessarily do so. And we need to increase funding for energy, new energy technologies. In the Framework Programme, we would like to see at least €120bn, but the idea is to increase energy funds by a percentage of 50%. Finally, more national expenditure is very much needed, but it is absolutely essential to coordinate national expenditure and European expenditure, because we often repeat the same studies and are not effective enough. Please note that we have our European clean technology institute, which deals with innovation and technology, and half of its activities serve to improve energy technologies. We should use this institute. We also have a Centre for Clean Coal Technologies, which has been funded by European money. We have digitisation, we have problems in transport, in construction, we have our environmental policies, our regional policies, we have infrastructure connections — we need all these programs to connect. Only such an action can really bring us change in the transformation of energy technologies, because we are transforming not only our energy market, but we are also transforming technologies. All these activities should support innovation in generation, transmission, storage and energy consumption.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all let me congratulate the honourable Member, Professor Jerzy Buzek, and the respective shadow rapporteurs for the constructive, thorough and positive report on the Communication on accelerating clean energy innovation. The suggestions proposed confirm and reinforce the Commission’s position and will be instrumental in the ongoing implementation. We have presented the progress made last year in the Communication on the State of the Energy Union, but the coming year will be crucial. To this end, the Commission will continue to focus on the four flagships that we decided on in the Communication: e—mobility, decarbonising buildings, renewables and – last but not least – storage. In doing so, as noted in your report, coherence of EU actions is absolutely necessary. We are focused on building and reinforcing synergies across funding instruments and stakeholders, and on aligning our policies to support innovation and not hamper it.  Your report is clear: public procurement can be a powerful tool to support the market uptake for clean energy innovation. Within the Commission we are looking at ways and mechanisms to incentivise EU public bodies to use demand as a tool to foster innovation. I am also pleased to see that we are aligned on the need to provide long—term financing certainty to better support and align incentives for innovators and investors. As you know, discussions on the design of FP9 are ongoing, and we take note of your suggestions with regard to the budget. Your assessment that funding for clean energy research and innovation will require a tremendous increase are the same as our conclusions. We agree with you, other international organisations agree with you, and we have to fight for that. On your point on the EU’s global clean energy leadership: we are the leaders. Europe is the leader and we should shout more about it. How many people are still surprised when we say that 40% of the patents in renewable technologies are European? Our leadership is also clear in the Mission Innovation initiative, gathering together 22 countries and the EU. At the time, I was introduced by the US Secretary of Energy as someone coming from the only country in the world that was able to run for four days straight on renewable energy alone. That is European leadership.  We are also working closely with other global initiatives, such as the Breakthrough Energy Coalition created by Bill Gates, which is now exploring a public—private collaboration with the Commission and four other Mission Innovation members.  Our views also coincide on the citizen’s central role in energy innovation that you referred to. There is a need for a transformation of mindset and the development of new skills. The role of the Commission is to facilitate, but also to take account of more interdisciplinarity and user innovation in future calls. The legislative package you are currently negotiating with the Council reflects the central role given to consumers in all aspects: innovative services, technology, products and integration methodologies. We cannot do it alone, so thank you very much and I hope to keep working together for the future.  (Applause)

name: Stefan Eck
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. — (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. While energy poverty affects around 54 million EU citizens, on the other hand, some of our policies and measures prevent us from being genuinely consistent with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. However, we all know that action is urgently needed in the areas of sustainable energy and climate change — apart from our colleague, Mr Korwin-Mikke. More than ever, we are faced with all the negative effects of our past decisions. However, despite international commitments and despite the advancing climate change, various Member States are still doing far too little for the energy transition. Against this background, I would like to encourage the Commission to send the following request to the governments of the Member States: subsidies for fossil fuels must be abolished as soon as possible. We urgently need clean energy projects at national and local level with strict timelines. In the transition to renewable energy, fossil workers must be provided with public guarantees to ensure a social transition of the energy transition.

name: Isabella De Monte
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has for years been committed to climate change through the development of energy renewable in industry, transport and building construction. In the coming years, in order to continue to be world leaders in these issues, it will be important to improve access to European funds for those new technologies that, in complete disruption with the past, focus on a low-use economy of coal and fossil fuels. In addition, Europe will have to cooperate with both Member States and small and medium-sized enterprises to deliver on the commitments that have been made with the Paris Climate Agreement. The European Union will have to concentrate its actions especially in the transport sector, which has for too long been exempted from making its contribution to reducing carbon emissions. Finally, I would like to point out that focusing on the efficiency of public transport and clean energy will enable sustainable tourism to be developed.

name: Monika Smolková
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. — Madam President, environmental quality is one of the most important factors for all citizens of the European Union. Therefore, investment in clean energy is also an investment in environmental quality. I am speaking on behalf of the REGI Committee, so I would like to remind you that the European Investment and Structural Funds offer significant opportunities for innovation in the field of energy and to bring them into the market. But at the same time they are not a panacea. We therefore welcome the Commission's intention to introduce targeted financial instruments in order to achieve an appropriate balance between grants and other financial instruments. Public-private partnerships and research, development and innovation joint ventures could spur private sector investment in clean energy. In doing so, we must not forget the key role of the regions, cities and municipalities, because they are the ones who are codecision and are responsible for switching to other energy sources. They are eligible applicants of financial resources from European funds and are a source of awareness of the objectives and possibilities of engaging in the transition to clean energy sources.

name: Puhemies. –
text: At this stage I regret to announce that the evening has progressed so far that I cannot concede catch-the-eye speeches.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I welcome this report by my very good colleague Jerzy Buzek. I think that it sends an important signal that we, as a Parliament, want to see more support for energy innovation and that we recognise the vital need for this to happen if we are to meet our 2030 targets.  We have traditionally been at the forefront, as Commissioner Moedas has pointed out, but we need to do more because other areas of the world are catching up. For instance, China spent USD 44 billion on investment in clean energy projects in 2017, up from USD 32 billion in 2016. So, while we can be happy with ourselves, the rest of the world is probably moving quicker. Therefore, I really agree with Mr Buzek when he calls for an increased budget for FP9. Horizon 2020 did not make enough funds available.  We also need to look at ensuring that those funds are easily available. As Jerzy Buzek pointed out, we have too many financial instruments and in some of the seminars, etc., that I have held in my own constituency, the point was made to me several times that applying for funds is too complicated. There are too many streams and they need to be coordinated and simplified. I think if we do that in terms of renewable energy, for which I was rapporteur for the EPP, we can reach, and maybe surpass, our 35% target.

name: Петър Курумбашев
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, the European Union budget will decrease over the next seven years and, in this sense, it is extremely important that the report on accelerating innovation is adopted at this very moment. I'd say — just in time. There is a temptation, when the budget is decreasing, to precisely reduce the funds for innovation for science, and I hope that this report will give a strong signal not to cut funds in this area. We need to pay particular attention to geographical differences, especially for the allocation of these funds in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. The financing of projects in the field of electric mobility and hydrogen mobility, both cars and buses, and industrial needs to continue. Let me also note that we must enable better management of these funds at regional and local level, and not just at European and national level. Finally, allow me to thank the rapporteur, Mr Buzek. It has been an honour to work with one of the representatives of heavy artillery in this Parliament, Mr Jerzy Buzek.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking our rapporteur, Jerzy Buzek, for the good cooperation on this report. That's a big report. It is very comprehensive because it is about the energy of the future and the innovations we need for this. Jerzy Buzek has made it clear that energy will be necessary for everything in the future. And I would like to say that the clean energy we want in connection with the Clean Energy for All Europeans package may not have matured in many respects, perhaps sometimes not so well known. That is why, Commissioner Moedas, research is so important to move forward here. For example, because I deal a lot with maritime things, I think of energy from the ocean. For example, we already know offshore wind energy plants. However, research is being done on wave energy, tide energy, and many say that the fuel of the future for an aircraft may have been produced from algae, and then also very environmentally friendly, even CO2 neutral. We can still accomplish a lot of things. We need technology neutrality, we need a lot of research. We also need to recognise that research is clear that even smaller companies and smaller research institutions know exactly where they can apply for something if they want to move forward, and that we are also using the resources in research as efficiently as possible. Then we can move on with it. In order to really drive innovation, we also need a competition of different energies. Pushing subsidies are good, but not permanent. This is not what we need to look to the future.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President. We know that the energy transition is much more than a change in technologies, and that it is also a change of model. Scientific and technological innovation certainly plays a very important role, but it must be accompanied by a profound change in the energy system and also social innovations, for example, that citizens are the main and central player of this energy transition. And it is that this report is born with an original sin, in our view, which is the concept of technological neutrality. I mean, the same thing we're investigating today in fossil fuels as in photovoltaics. What is being done is to color the coal green; paint a windmill to the gas; or put a smoke vacuum on a power plant and call it clean coal. It is not enough just to nurture the illusion of false solutions, nor is it enough just to rely on the market. To encourage this innovation in clean energy, it is essential to set ambitious objectives — which is not done by this House or the European Union itself as a whole, because there is an inconsistency between words and facts. Last month, in this House, large groups agreed to set energy efficiency and renewable energy targets of only 35%, which are not binding on States, that is, little more than market trends mark. Sectors such as renewable innovation or energy efficiency need clear signals of public commitment; that is why we advocate that these are strongly supported by the public sector.

name: Jakop Dalunde
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President! The EU has a vision that we should be a world leader in the climate field, and in May the Commission will present most of the next 7 years policy and will show what the budget and the future EU research and innovation policy will look like. Then it will be decided whether we will lead or whether we should hand over the baton to others. The cornerstone of the EU's forthcoming Framework Programme for Research and Innovation must be the climate, because if we fail to make innovation here, well, then it doesn't matter what comes after that. We need to see increased efforts in research in the EU, but also in Member States' budgets. In these collective ventures, an increasing proportion should be put into producing tomorrow's solutions for green realignment. We will make sure to have good, sustainable transport and renewable energy that actually delivers what we promised each other in Paris. The climate can't wait.

name: Dario Tamburrano
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, society derives from energy, the kind of reports, morals, laws and goods that can be produced. To accumulate resources and therefore energy, how many wars, treaties, annexations, laws and social classes have occurred throughout the history of man. Technological innovation, on the other hand, has always been the instrument of change, even social, since man began to use the plow to produce the first form of energy stored in an organized manner, the food. As policymakers we should be more committed to defending the future from the ballast of the past, and instead I often see that many of us, unfortunately, are committed to defending the past from the future. I would like to thank Mr Buzek for taking into account our suggestions in the report. Producing, consuming, storing and exchanging energy between peers, perhaps with blockchain, is fundamental for a firm turn towards a more horizontal, more equal production model. The widespread spread of small networked plants can give a great boost to the energy transition. Let us ensure that the Energy Union, with the citizens in the centre, does not remain locked in a drawer.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: on behalf of the EFF Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner Moedas. Research, development and innovation are particularly important in the field of clean energy, which is the only way to safeguard the industrial pioneering role and competitiveness of European companies, and to create sustainable growth and employment. Today, the European Union is the world leader in high-quality low-emission energy innovation, innovations in energy efficiency, renewable energy, smart grids, storage and the development of clean technologies. However, in order to remain competitive in the global market in the future, innovation in the field of clean energy needs to be accelerated. The optimisation spectrum is far-reaching — from simplifying access to research funding to PPP projects to the conversion of knowledge into economically viable products. And: we need a regulatory and financial framework that is in line with the Energy Roadmap 2050 and the Paris Agreement. The most important points to be taken into account — Mr Buzek has also done so in his report: the coherence of action at EU level, financial security, safeguarding global leadership and the participation of citizens. In order for Europe to remain top, we need more resources, faster and better R&D for clean energy.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: Madam President, clean energy innovation must be an engine for meeting our climate and energy objectives, and also to take advantage of the competitive opportunities offered by clean and affordable energy, thus ensuring European leadership in renewable energy. To that end, it is essential to phase out subsidies to fossil fuels by targeting those resources to the efficient decarbonization of the system. It is necessary to establish stable regulatory frameworks, as well as coordination of the various instruments that encourage energy and avoid duplication. We must not forget that this innovation must reach all citizens and especially those affected by energy poverty. Finally, this innovation in energy transition must be shared and exported to third countries, facilitating access to clean energy. This must also be part of European leadership in the world.

name: Jonathan Bullock (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Buzek for the work he has put into the drafting of this report. I understand his point of view that modern economies are undergoing a profound transition in the way they produce, transmit, store and use energy. However, my party and I cannot ignore the fact that the report agrees with the foolish concept of decarbonising Europe’s economy and achieving climate targets as stated in the Paris Agreement.  We cannot deny the importance of fossil fuel energy. First of all, human activity contributes only 3% to the global carbon cycle. Secondly, coal use is on the increase globally and nothing we in Europe can do will stop it. We hear a lot about China’s increase of, say, solar power but not so much about their increasing coal—fired generation. Furthermore, the emissions savings achieved by renewables have been exaggerated. Wind is intermittent and it requires conventional backup. That means that backup is run intermittently and inefficiently, which means more fuel and more emissions. Things need to be done differently.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: Madam President, in the global world in which we live today, an economic power such as the European Union must be on the technological frontier in all sectors, and in some sectors it has to take the lead consistently. Given its dependence on external supply on fossil fuels and the commitment to digitalization and decarbonization, the energy transition has to be one of the sectors in which this leadership has to be affirmed and for it resources, talents and political determination must be channelled, not least because it calls for the primordial knowledge such as mathematics, physics, chemistry, biology, social sciences, and promotes integration between digitalization and decarbonization. I therefore welcome this report, for its timeliness and the richness of its content. The European Union has gone ahead, but unfortunately it has been losing advantage in the energy transition. In clean mobility it has even been overtaken by other industrial powers. Let us therefore, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, make this report a mobilising impetus at the service of citizens and future generations.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission and this House are already working together very closely, but any achievements would require many other partners – the Member States, private investors, industry and the citizens. It is through the engagement of all that we can do it, because today we cannot do it alone.  Looking ahead to the next framework programme, we will continue to invest. We will continue to increase the investment in clean energy, but we have to do more than that. We have to do more in terms of the way we look at innovation. Firstly, we have to simplify; as Mr Buzek rightly said, we have to be simpler. We have to create our own brand of innovation that everybody knows.  That is why we are looking at the idea of the European Innovation Council, the idea that we have to grasp innovation that comes from different sides, from the intersection of disciplines, as Mr Zorrinho rightly said, from the intersection of the physical and the digital worlds, through this idea of creating innovation that comes and solves our problems in ways and in many different places that we cannot even imagine.  Secondly, we have to link with the citizens: link with the citizens with mission-driven science, with ideas that people understand, with ideas that people can link to Europe, and that is also part of our project. Clean energy is a mission and that mission is the mission of Europe; we have to put it in words that people want to understand.  The other day in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy one of the honourable Members, Claude Turmes, gave great examples of that. He said: ‘Let’s achieve a zero-carbon city. Let’s achieve a zero-carbon chemical industry. Let’s achieve a zero-carbon boat’. So let’s work on it.

name: Jerzy Buzek
text: rapporteur. — Madam President! Commissioner, I would like to thank you for preparing a Communication from the European Commission on such a very important issue as innovation in the field of energy. We talk about a clean energy package all the time, we're talking about energy poverty, we're talking about security of supply. We can't cope without the kind of innovation we're talking about here. First of all, we need to change the awareness of our citizens It will no longer be just a matter of changing the energy supplier or buying equipment with the right energy class. I am convinced that thanks to the mobile application we will soon buy the necessary electricity from a small cooperative, for example, in Lisbon, having solar panels on the roofs of the surrounding townhouses, or after shopping, our refrigerator will calculate the demand for electricity, connect to the energy portal and will auction off the needed power from the owner of the geothermal power plant in Slovak Poprad, or our electric car charged at the night tariff will resell some of the energy at daily rates while waiting in the parking lot at work. Windows in our house will keep warm, but also with the right installed appliances blended in the shafts will produce electricity, and so this is a completely new, attractive future. If we don't convince our citizens that this is worth fighting for, that it will also give us energy savings, savings in our portfolios, then we won't win. That's why we thank you for the action, Commissioner. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, we worked very much in line indeed. We started from slightly different points of view, but we were able to get the job done in such a way that the committee voted through the report with an overwhelming majority. Very much to all colleagues and colleagues thank you.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate has ended. The vote will take place on Tuesday 6 February 2018. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, in the field of clean energy, there is a very strong competition between European and other global economic powers, and further steps needed to achieve the Paris climate edge, and clean energy research and development is therefore of the utmost importance support. The largest percentage of innovations is developed by small and medium-sized enterprises, but research and development of new technologies requires very high financial investment and risks, so one of the EU's tasks is to reduce this level of risk. Nor should we forget the less developed regions. It is well known that most of the technological developments are concentrated in the top regions of the EU, and other regions are delayed to import new developments. Therefore, I consider it a second important task to ensure the fastest possible technological transit, thus contributing to territorial cohesion. Unfortunately, I cannot agree with the part of the report concerning the phasing-out of energy support for Hungary and the Hungarian EPP delegations, which is a priority national interest. Thank you for listening to me.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — (PT) The meaning of technological change — its assumptions and consequences — is not dissociable from the economic and social context in which this change is taking place. If we want, the current socio-economic training. In a liberalized (and therefore tendentially concentrated) energy sector, dominated from production to distribution and consumption by the interests of large groups, acting under oligopoly regime, the assumptions, volumes, options and results of investments in innovation will surely be different from which can be achieved within a framework, which we advocate, of public and democratic control over this strategic sector. It is in this context that the challenges of sustainability and innovation can be better addressed, ensuring the prevalence of the public interest and safeguarding the future of the planet and its resources. Dumping millions of any future Framework Programme for Research into multinationals in the sector, on the pretext of supporting research and development (as is already the case with Horizon 2020), will not bring us any closer to this, quite the contrary.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. — The fundamental movement axes of the EU's energy transition are merged into the Europe 202020" strategy as well as the 2030 climate and energy framework and the 2050 energy strategy that we set ourselves as a Union. In line with the latter, the competitiveness and sustainability of European energy policy will only be guaranteed by an incessant stimulus to innovation in the clean energy sector. The Commission Communication which we are discussing today reaffirms this essential passage, consistent with the three reports voted in January of the so-called Energy Package, initiated by the Commission European in November 2016: a revised directive on energy efficiency, a proposal to recast the directive on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources and a new regulation on governance of the Energy Union. It will therefore be essential to have a consistent view at EU and Member State level, while respecting the different national markets in the sector. In this sense, there should not be a lack of adequate investment in the medium and long term, both in funding and in human capital, represented in this sector not only by research capital but also the direct involvement of European citizens, prosumers of our energy market and innovators in this long transition to social appropriation of European energy.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: in writing. — Citizens are key to the successful introduction of low-carbon innovative solutions — from smart meters in their homes to large wind farms. It is decisive to find new and better ways of engaging European citizens in the transition to a low-carbon economy and to allow existing public support to speak. More engaged citizens have more responsibility for their own and EU energy security and help develop new and original business models. In order to help European citizens change their mindset and understand how they can innovate and use digital tools to produce, consume and preserve more sustainable and clean energy, systemic education programmes should be introduced. It is also necessary to lower the barrier to entry to the market so as to make it easier for citizens to participate in it, and to ensure openness, transparency and fair competition. The European Union must become a global leader in energy innovation. Moreover, it must simplify EU programmes and funds so that investors and academics can use them more effectively. Accelerating the transition to a competitive low-carbon economy is both an urgent necessity and a huge opportunity for Europe.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — Accelerating the transition to a competitive low-carbon economy is both an urgent need and an extraordinary opportunity for Europe, and innovation is key. The own-initiative report 'Accelerating innovation in clean energy' calls for an innovation policy on energy consistent with the Paris agreements and the EU's objectives on energy and climate change. As the objective of the Commission Communication is to establish a strategy for policy leverages that the EU can carry out to boost private investment in clean energy innovation, this report calls on the Commission to consider the energy dimension as a horizontal part of the EU industrial policy and introduce energy efficiency as a horizontal cross-cutting priority applied to all sectors of activity. Stimulating energy innovation is possible by centering the energy system on the user, taking into account social aspects relevant to energy innovation, cooperation of all parties involved in this process and a substantial increase in resources financial support for the development and adoption of innovative solutions in the field of clean energy.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the motion for a resolution amending Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1675 by the Commission on 13 December 2017 supplementing Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/849 of the European Parliament and of the Council by adding Sri Lanka, Trinidad and Tobago and Tunisia in the table of point I of the Annex, tabled by Marie-Christine Vergiat, Cornelia Ernst, Marisa Matias, Merja Kyllönen, Helmut Scholz, Barbara Spinelli and Lola Sánchez Caldentey, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group, pursuant to Article 105 (3) of the Rules of Procedure (C (2017) 8320 - 2017/3020 (DEA)) (B8-0074/2018).

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: AUTHOR. — (FR) Madam President, like others, it is with surprise and misunderstanding that on 5 December 2017, I saw Tunisia appear on the blacklist of tax havens, led by the Council, and on 13 December 2017 on the list of high-risk countries in the field of money laundering and terrorist financing, led by the Commission. For the first list, the Council revoked its decision on 23 January 2018 and removed Tunisia from that list together with seven other countries, including Panama. Of which act. But for the other, the Commission maintains its position, and I was not convinced by its arguments at the LIBE-ECON meeting on 29 January. That is why, on behalf of my group, I have tabled this objection so that the plenary could speak. The issue is not the fight against money laundering or the financing of terrorism — we all agree to move forward and even more — it is a question of posting and priorities in this area. At the beginning of December, the blacklist included only eleven countries, five of them from MENA, all at war. Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria, Yemen plus Iran, but not Libya and no Gulf country. What is Tunisia coming to do here? We are told, of course, that other countries will come, including European countries. Let me be skeptical. We are also told that listing on this list is not worth sanction, but increased monitoring. That's true, but what signal do we send to investors and creditors in Tunisia? What damage will have been done until the Commission returns to its delegated act? Will she do it? And if, yes, when? Tunisia remains economically fragile; it is moving step by step in its democratic transition. Should we recall that its new institutions did not really start their work until 2015 and that the amendment of the legislation on these subjects was among the first steps taken? This which initiated the FATF procedure! It's a big one! Is it really the best way to support Tunisia, as we continue to proclaim, than to put it on this list? The FATF assessment on which the Board's decision was based was in May 2016. However, a new assessment was published on 6 December 2017, prior to the publication of the delegated act. The FATF itself has just drawn the consequences by taking Tunisia out of high-risk countries and putting it on the list of countries under surveillance, which endorsed the Tunisian government's progress and commitments. More than 26 commitments honoured at the beginning of December and more since! So why does the Commission want to keep Tunisia on this list at all costs? Are there no other countries, more dangerous for the European Union, to register more urgently? Is it so complicated to redo the delegated act? How does the Commission work on FATF countries and on what priorities? Mrs Mogherini reiterated, even today, that the stability of Tunisia and the full realization of its democratic transition are priority issues for the European Union, which will always be alongside that country. We must act in this direction, Commissioner. I am personally concerned that the stakes are different and that we are trying to put pressure on Tunisia to implement more quickly other reforms, including some so-called “structural” reforms. To truly support Tunisia, I invite you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote in favour of this objection in order to finally bring speeches and actions into coherence.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing within the European Union and globally is a major political priority for all the EU institutions. This Parliament, in particular, has fought hard to ensure that our rules against money laundering set a gold standard for the world, most recently in December when we reached agreement on the latest upgrade of the Anti-Money-Laundering Directive. The list of high-risk third countries plays an important role in the EU’s framework and in protecting the EU financial system against the risk of money laundering and terrorist financing. As regards Tunisia, the situation is clear. Tunisia still shows strategic deficiencies in this field, which today justify its inclusion on the EU list of high-risk third countries. The Commission welcomes and supports Tunisia’s efforts to remedy the situation. An action plan was agreed between Tunisia and the Financial Action Task Force in December. The Commission strongly welcomes the fact that Tunisia is now accelerating the implementation of those agreed actions. We are in close contact and have regular meetings with the Tunisian authorities in this regard, but there is still work to be done, notably as regards regulation and supervision of the non-financial sector, transparency of beneficial ownership and targeted financial sanctions. We count on Tunisia to remove those deficiencies swiftly, on the basis of the action plan agreed with the Financial Action Task Force, and the Commission stands ready to provide support. The Commission exchanged views on this issue in a joint meeting of the Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) committees last week, and the Commission made a formal declaration, describing the situation as I have just done and making a commitment to support Tunisia in this process. Today, I would like to reaffirm that Tunisia is a privileged partner for the European Union, and we commit to reassessing Tunisia’s progress as soon as possible during this year of 2018, with the aim of Tunisia being de-listed both by the Financial Action Task Force and by the EU. However, we are not there yet. There is still work to be done by Tunisia, and until then we have to fulfil our responsibility to protect the European Union and its financial system against the risks of money laundering and terrorist financing. I would like to thank the ECON and LIBE committees for supporting this view last week, and I call on this plenary likewise to assume its responsibility.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Madam President, I am a little embarrassed because my group discussed this issue a few hours ago and, unfortunately, we were unable to take a decision. We finally decided that everyone would vote tomorrow according to their conscience. The vote will be free. Then I am a little sad because I see that we are only discussing Tunisia. Of course, we have a lot of reasons to discuss Tunisia, but we also forget another country on this list, Sri Lanka. I would like to recall that, just as we support the democratic process in Tunisia, we also support important and recent political changes in Sri Lanka. We helped this country receive GSP+ and now we forget it a little. So I am very close to Tunisians and Sri Lankans, especially because I believe we need to be consistent. In recent years we have sent many messages of support, we have given money to these countries, and now we see them on this list of high-risk countries, for policies and, more than for policies, for companies in Tunisia and Sri Lanka. It's incomprehensible! Nobody understands anything about what the European Union is doing. If we tell these people that we want to help them and that they are our partners, but if we blacklist them ourselves, they will not understand anything.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, on this matter, I believe that you must engage fully with the European Parliament. Now, we can see it, you approach us with your fingertips, if I dare say. You reaffirmed the priority of combating money-laundering. You know how resolutely this Parliament is engaged in this battle, but you also know that the support you claim to give to Tunisia is a key concern for us, given the strategic issue of the relationship that the European Union will develop with that country. From this point of view, we are not satisfied with the statement you made or made by one of your staff members at the meeting of the ECON and LIBE committees. We would like you to be able to clearly claim the use of your own analysis grid before tomorrow's vote, as you pledged before these same committees. You did so on June 29, in a memorandum, stating that you would use your own analysis grid, regardless of the FATF analysis grid. We also want you to commit yourself not to mix all the reforms you expect from Tunisia and that your decision is only about whether or not this country should be removed from this list. We would like you to undertake to amend the statement before tomorrow's vote.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: Madam President, the European Commission, supported by a recent FATF assessment, classifies Tunisia, Trinidad and Tobago and Sri Lanka as high-risk countries because of serious deficiencies in the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing. It is not intended to stigmatize any of these countries, particularly Tunisia, which is a strategic partner, a democracy that we want to see consolidated on the southern flank of the European Union, a region with great risks and of the greatest importance for collective security. It is important to recognise that this is one of the legacies of the kleptocracy that for decades oppressed and ungoverned Tunisia. The true friends of Tunisia, like myself, should not lower the level of demand in this matter, quite the opposite, just as we do not fall in relation to the Member States of the European Union themselves. This delegated act is, moreover, because it does not cover other countries in the region which, of course, have much more serious problems of governance and technical capacity. Libya was cited. We have therefore asked the Commission to develop its own evaluation process without relying on FATF. The shortcomings in the system of prevention and supervision leading to inclusion in this list can be quickly overcome by Tunisia, and there is so much political will in Tunis and there is a lobbyist effort in the European Parliament. It is therefore important for the European Union to provide all the assistance, including financial assistance, to support this effort by the Tunisian authorities in capacity building. And that is why, all heavy, that I will again vote in favour of the delegated act.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first I would like to inform you about Sri Lanka’s deficiencies. Sri Lanka shows deficiencies in international cooperation, in particular the provision of mutual legal assistance, inappropriate regulation and supervision of the non—financial sector, customer due diligence requirements for designated non—financial businesses and professions, weakness in risk—based supervision in the financial sector with a low level of sanctions, shortcomings in access to beneficial ownership information for legal persons, as well as for legal arrangements or inadequate regime on targeted financial sanctions and some other deficiencies. Turning back to Tunisia, the Commission would like to welcome again the high—level commitment shown by Tunisia and its efforts in addressing its strategic deficiencies in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. Strong rules in the area help ensure security and stability, especially in the current context of terrorist threats in the EU and its neighbourhood. They are also necessary to ensure a sound, stable and solid financial system, which is a condition for sustainable growth. The Commission is therefore fully committed to support Tunisia in these efforts. This is something I can promise in this place. We are committed to support and to help. The European Union and Tunisia have a privileged partnership and we are here to support our partners. It is in our mutual interest. Our experts are in close cooperation to provide this assistance.  I hear the concerns expressed by Members of this Parliament today. I also confirm that we will work together to ensure that Tunisia can be rapidly removed, but the actual timing will depend on Tunisia’s own efforts. At the same time, I want to reassure you that the EU listing has no punitive intention. It will not hinder our development policy, it will not restrict trade relations, and it will not block financial transactions. Finally, Parliament has called on the Commission to have a more ambitious and autonomous assessment of third countries’ risk. We have to ensure the success of this important process by showing from the beginning that the EU’s autonomous assessment is objective and based on facts.
