name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this is a very important issue for us, with the Commission currently undertaking a regulatory fitness and performance REFIT on the Motor Insurance Directive. As a result of the ECJ’s Vnuk judgment, chaos could be caused for the insurance industry in the fields of motorsport, children’s motorised toys and lawn mowers, as they could all be compelled to take out very costly insurance. This is a very important point and this is what sometimes happens when judgments are given on a particular case, leading to unintended consequences.  The Commission is close to coming forward with a very sensible suggestion, which is option 3 of their proposals. I am asking the Commissioner to bring forward option 3 as his favoured solution, because I think the vast majority in the industry would see this as the best way of dealing with the unintended consequences of the Vnuk judgment.

name: Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: — Madam President, equal opportunities mean not just getting a job, but equal and real opportunities for higher education, so that women's access to decision-making functions is a guarantee. There is still an inequality in the field of qualification, which positions the woman unable to get to a leading position. We want the European institutions to create effective mechanisms that offer real professional development opportunities for women and ensure their access to the top of public or private management. At European and global level, women in high-responsibility positions, such as Prime Minister or Head of State, are still quite rare. On the one hand, we have states such as Finland, which had both the president and the female prime minister, but on the other hand, there are still 13 Member States of the European Union where a woman has never held such a position. Recently, Romania is an example of good practice by sworn in as Prime Minister of former MEP Viorica Dăncilă. In the Romanian Government, 8 ministerial portfolios are occupied by women.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President! It marks another anniversary of the Yaltese arrangements. In fact throughout this term — for three and a half years — we have never talked about it, even on the circular 70th anniversary Parliament rejected this possibility. Meanwhile, in fact, this repair of the effects of that division of Europe, that surrender of the West is a real test of European unity. Europe truly in solidarity is Europe removing the effects of communism and Soviet dominance in central and eastern Europe, and supporting rather than attacking those states that experienced it at the time. Today, every act of silence of Yalta, every pretending it wasn't, is a cross out of European solidarity. It's time we started thinking about this big task that we constantly have to do.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, terrorist attacks have increased in Europe since 2014 and that poses a threat to us. These attacks have happened in London, Paris, Brussels, and now have even reached my own Member State, Sweden. The problem is that terrorists move easily across borders and we are trying to prevent these attacks nationally. We need, therefore, further legislation to effectively counter terrorism. While different measures are certainly necessary, experts agree that increased cooperation between intelligence services is essential.  Today, the intelligence services largely operate within their own borders, but terrorists do not share information and terrorists work across the borders. That is the reason why we need to increase cooperation, sharing intelligence and analyses between the European security intelligence services. That is the only way we can protect Europeans and that is what we have to do.

name: Marie-Pierre Vieu (GUE/NGL).
text: — Madam President, presented as an industrial alliance responding to the challenges of the new generation TGV and curbing Chinese competition, the Alstom-Siemens merger is in fact the absorption of the French company by the German group which, by 2023, will hold 50.5% of the capital. After General Electric, finance against employment, research and development is chosen. The unions refuse this logic, the Anticor association points to the French government, which is organising this dismantling and allows the Bouygues group to pocket 500 million in the operation. I am in support of France's commitment to industry and a European recovery strategy using so-called solidarity protectionism. I call on the European Commission to defend cooperation on the Airbus model which could take the form of an economic interest group.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President. The Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Timmermans, insists that he sees no problem with the functioning of the rule of law and the separation of powers in the Spanish State. It would be because it would seem normal for a Minister of Justice to advance in the media decisions that are only responsible for justice; or for the Government to call the judges of the Constitutional Court to try to influence their decisions. It will be because it will seem irrelevant that such attitudes have led Judges for Democracy today to denounce these interference. It will also seem very much in line with the separation of powers that the courts tell a parliament how it should interpret its own rules; and it will undoubtedly seem very consistent with the fundamental rights for a judge to keep members of the Government of Catalonia in pretrial detention for their independence ideology, as he recognizes in their records, which for this and other reasons are a real demolition of the rule of law. There is no blinder than the one who doesn't want to see. The problem is that Mr Timmermans, as Commissioner responsible for the rule of law and fundamental rights, is not only obliged to see, but also to look, and to do so without double standards.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I take the floor in this House of the European Parliament to denounce, for the umpteenth time, the adverse consequences and negative consequences of a partnership agreement economic, of a free trade treaty, this time with Cameroon. I found myself last week in Sicily, my region, and in Pachino, in the land from which the extraordinary tomato, the date, are found in supermarkets tomatoes from Cameroon. Local producers can no longer stand in the market, can no longer produce and have a decent life. Here, this globalization at all costs, this will always favour multinational corporations and large distribution is absolutely inconceivable and unsustainable. Moreover, the same Italian parties represented here have ratified and voted this agreement on all sides, and this is absolutely unacceptable.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: — Madam President, Tunisia has been suffering from chronic instability since the 2011 revolution. In recent weeks, severe riots have even erupted in several cities. Tunisia must be helped, not by good words as President Macron does, but by action. This is in our interest because this instability facilitates the movement of terrorists. Interpol has just revealed that 50 Tunisian jihadists have landed in Italy. One is already in France. This confirms the accuracy of the National Front analysis. Economic aid to unstable countries is needed, but it is not enough. We must denounce the Schengen Agreement and restore state control of their national borders everywhere.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Madam President! We're watching a strange spectacle at the moment, namely the Polish government issued a strange law protecting Poland's dignity, and strangely enough, even weirder the government of Israel reacted, protesting the fact that the Polish government doesn't wish it could talk badly about him. It is said that it is a playmate for the government of Israel to demand reparations from Poland for property left by Jews who died unposterously as a result of German actions. Well, I would like to point out that this demand, which is repeatedly made, is completely extreme nationalism, because the Jews who were murdered for occupation by the Germans were citizens of the Republic of Poland, not Israel, which was not there at the time. Therefore, it is only one thing I would like to point out that whoever supports these types of demands supports extreme absolute nationalism unknown in Polish law, in European law.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE).
text: — Madam President, four years on, we have not yet met the fair demands of European citizens for the refugee and immigration problem that has dealt with us in so many meetings. This is a human rights issue of the utmost importance, since hundreds of thousands of people come to Europe in search of a decent way of survival. In my country, Greece, flows continue mainly from the coast of Turkey to the islands of the NE Aegean. The pressures on the islands are enormous. Asylum services are unable to respond to the number of applications and the inhabitants of the islands, despite their proven hospitality, are in a plight. The Dublin review plan is being delayed while certain countries are refusing to show solidarity for a proportionate reception of refugees. We have not been able to manage effectively this problem which is shaking our cohesion. We must all assume our responsibilities immediately, respecting European ideals and human life, because otherwise there is no need to debate the future of Europe on the basis of its fundamental values.

name: Wajid Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, today is Kashmir Solidarity Day. It is a time for us to reflect on the many Kashmiris who are being killed, raped, tortured and injured and their fight for self—determination over the past 70 years. They are not asking for charity. They are asking for their rights, promised to them through UN resolutions.  The world cannot turn a blind eye to the grave human rights violations suffered daily in Indian—controlled Kashmir. The use of pellet guns on children as young as nine is despicable and has been condemned by Amnesty International. Their use must be banned and the Public Safety Act needs to be reformed so that Indian soldiers are accountable for their actions. We need change, progress and action, not just words, on this issue.  If we cannot get justice for the Kashmiris, then there will be no regional peace. Markets and trade can never be more important than lives and human rights. I pay tribute to all those people that have given their lives to the cause and I salute the Kashmiri resilience to this oppression. Their sacrifices must never be forgotten and we need to support the occupied Kashmiris to stop their persecution and suffering, as well as finally giving them their right to self—determination.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: — Yesterday's grand rally in Athens for Skopje sends a decisive message to the ends of the world, that Macedonia is one and Greek. It sends a decisive message that the Greek people do not tolerate the usurping of the name of our Macedonia and our history by Skopje. The mass rallies in Athens and Thessaloniki noises the centers of power in the US, the European Union, NATO and Skopje. Skopje must stop using the name of our Macedonia, abandon its irrepressive claims against Greece and must stop sucking the candy of the so-called Macedonian ethnicity. Our movement, “Greece - The Other Road”, is opposed to any use of the term Macedonia by Skopje, as well as any geographical designation that refers and uses the word Macedonia in the name of Skopje. We demand a referendum on Macedonia and we are opposed to Macedonia's accession to the European Union and NATO.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, today I launched ‘The One Thing’ campaign, aimed at giving young people a space to let us know the one thing that concerns them about Brexit. This is especially important now, as the British Prime Minister has confirmed that Britain will not be part of the Customs Union nor of a customs union. The December joint EU-British report on Brexit is clear that there needs to be ‘full regulatory alignment’ between the North and South of Ireland. The British Government must now explain what the ‘specific solutions to address the unique circumstances of the island of Ireland’ are. For Sinn Féin, this means designated special status; for the Irish Government it is designated special arrangements. Whatever it is called, it must ensure that the North of Ireland remains in the Customs Union and the single market. The assertion by Sammy Wilson of the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) that a brutal Brexit border would result in only a few checks on cross-border trade illustrates either gross ignorance on his part or an underlying desire to see just that, which is what I believe it is. It must be ensured that the current legal framework retains our rights, and it must be ensured that application of the Charter of Fundamental Rights is also maintained. This is about upholding the Good Friday Agreement in all of its parts.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I again denounce the judicial catastrophe in Spain. Tomorrow marks a hundred days of the forced exile of the legitimate Government of Catalonia; today, one hundred and twelve days from the prison of Sànchez and Cuixart, worthy and peaceful social leaders, and ninety-five days after that of former European parliamentarian and Catalan vice-president Oriol Junqueras and Joaquim Forn, responsible for Interior. All without trial and ideological accusations. Spain abandons democracy in Catalonia. And it is also left by the Mexican state. Twelve journalists killed in 2017 and more than one hundred thousand have disappeared since 2006. With total impunity. Two states in democratic decomposition: Spain and Mexico. And the European Parliament, which condemns hundreds of cases, remains silent. How long will Democrats have to be embarrassed because of an institution like ours that clearly violates its founding commitments?

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Madam President! At a European Parliament conference held in the autumn of 2016, we discussed the modern abduction of Europe in the metaphorical sense of ancient mythological history. This was done in the 20th century by totalitarian regimes, namely Soviet communism. The globalist power forces that threaten our continent through the programmatic support, promotion and extension of migration — this contemporary mass migration — are also striving to abduct Europe in other ways and means. In our view, Hungary must remain a Hungarian country. It is in this sense that the Union and its Member States must defend their European and national identities against all kinds of world power attacks.

name: Răzvan Popa (S&D).
text: — Madam President, recently, signals have been emerging from the European Commission regarding the introduction of additional criteria for granting development funds to Member States. We are talking about political criteria, subjective and hardly quantifiable, which can function as a pretext to reduce funds for Member States. I know the efforts Romania is making to ensure its citizens a better life and I know how much these efforts depend on the cohesion funds. I wish that any decision being discussed at the level of the European Council and the European Commission should take account, first of all, of the development needs of the Member States. The stronger their economies, the stronger the European Union is. I also want the European Parliament, the forum representing the citizens of the Member States, to act in such a way that, at the basis of any decisions, is respect for the principle of solidarity, on which the Union is based, and nothing else.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Madam President, no one congratulates us, Czech Members, for the re-election of our President Zeman, unfortunately there is nothing to congratulate us. The elections in the Czech Republic were referred to as a referendum between heading west or east. Yes, President Zeman pulls us a lot east and is welcome in Moscow as well as Beijing. But his election was still related to something else. The Czech Republic is well off economically. Still, many people aren't happy with their situation and feel that they don't profit from economic development, that they don't actually participate in it. GDP in Prague highly exceeds the average of the European Union, but in many places in the Czech Republic people have wages that are half that of the minimum wage in France or Germany. People are afraid of unmastered immigration, the current and future. Even as Central Europeans, we may have become accustomed to a higher standard. But I believe that our citizens understand both solidarity and the problems faced by people in other parts of the world. Madam Vice-President, I wanted to congratulate you, Finland and you personally, that you have elected a president and have not succumbed to the trappings of populism.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Budget Commissioner Oettinger recently announced inevitable cuts to cohesion policies in the post-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. I believe it is a mistake to reduce the funds of the Union's main investment policy, in a Europe still rehearsed by the economic crisis, which has heightened the disparities within itself economic, political and social. For poorer regions, such as those in southern Italy, it would mean losing between four and six billion euros, considering the CAP cuts announced by the German Commissioner. On the contrary, we should strengthen investment, also adding new resources on security and defence, excluding national co-financing from the Stability Pact, bind the disbursement of all funds from the European budget for respect for the rule of law and intra-European solidarity. Rather than subverting and frustrating cohesion policy, let us strive to provide the European Union with adequate resources through serious reconnaissance and identification of own resources. Only in this way could we make an extra effort in finding resources and we can afford to avoid painful and counterproductive backward steps.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, during this parliamentary mandate, this House has repeatedly called for the so-called EU blacklist of non-cooperative jurisdictions. This list has finally been published by the Council in December last year and this is a step in the right direction. I welcome the decision by the Council, but there are a number of doubts about firstly, the criteria that have been used in order to establish this list. Let me remind you that only 17 countries or territories have been included on that list, whereas we have evidence that many more jurisdictions should also be considered. But more important is the fact that just after one month, in January, the Council has removed eight countries from that list. So my proposal to the Council is, firstly, to give us a precise list of criteria and, secondly, to tell us how this list will be developed in order to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance across the world.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the UK arts sector is a hugely significant industry, contributing over GBP 87 billion to our economy and providing jobs to more than two million people. It returns more than the automotive, oil and gas, aerospace and life sciences industries combined. Our membership of the EU has been key to that success, with the majority of the sector voting to remain. So Theresa May’s hard Brexit will have a devastating impact on our creative industries. For example, music tours are programmed years in advance and the UK Government’s negative position on key policy areas, such as membership of the single market and the customs union, is very damaging.  Already, we have seen two top orchestras leave Britain because of Brexit, relocating to Belgium and Italy, and more will follow. I recently attended the Association of British Orchestras’ conference in Wales, where the sector made it clear that freedom of movement is vital. The costs of a hard Brexit will fall directly on producers, with many tours becoming unviable, and this scenario will be replicated across the whole of the creative industries and mean fewer concerts by our favourite bands and musicians. As Billy Bragg says, ‘music can heal the wounds of Brexit’. Let’s ensure it can.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: — Madam President, according to all analyses and statistics, in the last 3 years, there has been a worrying increase in cases of HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis C. 2017 has been a record year on infection with the virus of the three diseases, rightly considered the most aggressive. In the case of HIV alone, according to the Office of Surveillance of HIV-AIDS cases, in 2017, there was an increase of 5.9% per thousand of the infected population. In this context, I believe that we need to raise an alarm signal in the direction of the urgent review of the European Union's health policies and we need to get the EU Health Commissioner to speed up the implementation of the recommendations of the European Parliament resolution of July 2017. Without a generalised programme applicable across all Member States and without subsidising tests and treatments for disadvantaged categories, in a few years it will probably be impossible to control the spread of these diseases. It is inadmissible, in the European Union, considered the most important political building of the old continent, to discuss today the alarming increase in cases of tuberculosis, HIV and hepatitis C.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: — Mrs President, Mrs Commissioner, colleagues On January 23, this year, the Government of the Republic of Latvia — the Cabinet of Ministers — has adopted amendments to the Education Law. These amendments actually provide for the closure of secondary education in the languages of national minorities and from 20. For the 21st academic year to provide for secondary education in Latvia only in Latvian. Colleagues, the official slogan of the European Union is “United in Diversity”. Diversity is our wealth. This year the Republic of Latvia, my country, will mark the centenary since its proclamation and founding, and before the war Latvia was a truly outstanding example of democracy, when the country, imagine colleagues, guaranteed secondary education in eight minority languages. Colleagues, it is our responsibility to maintain secondary education in the languages of national minorities, to act actively, to colleagues, not to be silent here - in the European Parliament. Thank you.
